description:
I love coming here, Japantown has so many stores. From cute shops, Anime, Car accessories,  tea sets, bento boxes, stationaries, boba & pastry shops and even crane games. 

I come here often and I never get sick of it.
Plus, they have a bunch of restaurants, obviously majority is Japanese.
author: Teena N.

description:
Great place outside of actually being in Japan. They have the east and west 
Malls that are filled with shops for all. From jewelry to souvenirs to toys, anime, swords, books and many more. 

The place is full of ramen restaurants to sushi and desert and coffee and ice cream shops. 

They also feature the Cherry Blossom Festival which is always the best time to visit, which I believe is always around the month on April. You might want to google it to find out the exact dates but it is a great festival with music, food, drinks, shows and more food. The festival runs for two weekends. A must place to visit it great and great way to enjoy and support the many fund raising booths from the sale of food at their food booths.
author: Andrew M.

description:
I have always enjoyed San Francisco's Japantown since I was a kid. It was our every Sunday evening after mass. It was either go for some tempura or go for some sukiyaki. I have many fond memories with my parents near the intersection of Post & Buchanan. There are the 2 main shopping areas that are on either side of the Peace Pagoda. One is a little smaller but now has a huge Daiso market in it. The other side has bakeries such as Andersen Bakery, restaurants such as Marufuku Ramen and Japanese car accesories store Auto Freak. 

But the sights arent limited to this area. You have a few city blocks across the street that have Yasukochi's Sweet Shop and their terrific coffee crunch cake, Benkyodo for authentic mochi that sells out by morning and Super Mira Market (where Yasukochi is located) that has Japanese groceries and ready made food to-go. 

There are Hawaiian stores, other ramen and izakaya shops that you just have to walk around and see it for yourself. There is plenty to see and taste. There is a parking garage but I always try and find street metered parking first.
author: Chuck D.

description:
It's not often that I visit Japantown since I have to travel across the bay via public transportation to get to this site. The only time I do so is during the Cherry Blossom Festival Parade. The last time I attended the parade was four years ago. However, I made sure to attend the parade this year with my two sisters, being that this was the 51st Annual Cherry Blossom Festival. It was something for us to do on a beautiful (weather wise) Sunday. Besides, it was my younger sister's 63rd birthday and we celebrated the occasion at Crown & Crumpet Tea Stop Cafe.

It would have been easier for us to catch the 38 Muni to Japantown from Union Square, but we opted to walk from the Civic Center BART Station to our destination. It was a challenge, but the returned walk was a little further - we ended up at Westfield Shopping Center near the Powell Street BART Station.

As usual, Japantown was packed with parade spectators, tourists, food vendors, merchandise vendors, live musical entertainment on the Webster Street Stage. Darn, we missed the Big City Revue and Jest Jammin' bands. I love both those bands and they certainly can get the party going, as in "get up and get down, get up out of your seat; get up and get down, get up and move your feet..." (Song by the Dramatics).

I couldn't pass up on BeeFy Co, a vendor selling Hello Kitty Warriors t-shirts. I already have a black one, but not a blue one. Quick - $25 out of my pocket. No regrets in making the purchase. The next stop was an origami exhibit on Post Street. My sisters and I did not stay long. Reason: It was packed with wall-to-wall people and I don't do well in an enclosed crowded area (indoor). I'm okay if the crowd is outdoor and I can breathe. 

Our final stop was Daiso. I picked up a few items for purchase, but when I saw the line of customers from the front of the store to the back, I told myself "never mind". I will return another time when Japantown is not crowded; preferably on a weekday where I can stop in at either Yasukochi's Sweet Shop for a slice of coffee crunch cake or a croissant from Anderson Bakery.
author: Carol C.

description:
San Francisco J-Town/Japantown ....... made it finally, WHEW! WHAT A WALK!

Great place to look around and enjoy some great Japanese cuisine, be it udon, ramen, sushi, sashimi, bento box, proteins, or whatever you prefer.  The shops are pretty cool with items you can not buy outside of J-Town or from Japan.

Visiting SF?  Been to Chinatown? Visit Japantown. It is different than Los Angeles by a long shot.  I would highly recommend visiting if you are visiting the area for a week or a few days.
author: Randy L.

description:
Japan town made Top 10 must-visit places when I was jotting down plans for a weekend trip to the bay

Although I wasn't blown away, there were some picture worthy items and sites to see. Sadly, there isn't much to do here besides grabbing some food and seeing a few iconic architectures. The stores here are decorated in a humble but cute-sy manner, but like most of your Sanrio and Tokyo Central look -alikes, it's more for window shopping and light perusing as everything inside is pricy. There's a Pika Pika- photobooth store, a Manga Bookstore, and a Tony Moly -cute drugstore makeup where I picked up some Pokemon hand lotion as gifts. 

Theres also a cute Animal Crepe store called Belly Good and some Ramen eatery that garnered an okay rating so we ate elsewhere before coming. Check out the Japanaese mini tower too! Stationary and boutiques close around 5/6 so plan your visit accordingly

It's one of those one and done places in my honest opinion. While a lot bigger than Japan town in LA, it seemed a bit run down and not as robust in activities like SF Chinatown.
author: Christine H.

description:
Japantown is one of those unique points of cultural intersection in San Francisco. There is the large outdoor central space in the middle of the facility where various events are held or people can just sit back and enjoy the ambience. Then, there is the shops and restaurants in the interior section. Both of the spaces are very nicely designed and are inviting.

Japantown has a great Japanese/English bookstore that features books and magazines that were published in Japan and books that feature and discuss Japanese culture. This is truly one of the mainstays of Japantown and I highly recommend you visit it because you will truly find unique publications.

There are also several shops that offer unique culturally orientated items and art. Simply by walking through the facility you can venture into these shops and find great gifts or those unique items that you never knew you needed.

In terms of the restaurants and/or cafés, there are a number of them. Each of them has a unique Asian flavor and you will not be sorry if you try them out.

Overall, this location is one of the essential places to check out in San Francisco whether you are a local or tourist. It is always a fun and informative place to visit.
author: Scott S.

description:
"The perfect cherry blossom is a rare thing. You could spend your lifetime looking for one, and it would not be a wasted life." - Katsumoto 

Japantown in San Francisco is the closest you'll get to Japan if you haven't been to Japan. It's by no means spectacular, but like Captain Algren (Tom Cruise) square-dancing with Katsumoto (Ken Watanabe) it's the best North Hollywood version of Ginza District. And yes, I find comfort and why I've been here more times than I can remember. 

I've been to Japantown in San Francisco many times, and probably in many life times as well. The beauty of this Japantown is that some businesses have been here forever, like Benkyo-do which opened it's doors after the great earthquake of 1906, the award-winning mochi & confections is heaven to one's lips. Old businesses like Soko Hardware is still family owned and pre-dates the WWII era. Other "from Japan" businesses include, Kinokuniya Books, Daiso Japan, Sakura Sakura, Moritaya, etc., etc. Nijiya Market is located here too. Then you count the endless Japanese restaurants, bakeries, and omiyage shops. How about Katsura Gardens for all you aspiring green-thumb'rs! And to anchor Japantown you can find Sundance Kabuki Theaters, Kabuki Springs & Spa, and Hotel Kabuki. 

My very first traditional tea ceremony was held at an old tea house on Osaka Way. Back when I took Japanese in college and my instructor invited a group of us. It certainly was an experience I'll never forget. For a moment I felt like Tom Cruise sipping tea with the dead Samurai's widow, but then I woke *snap* to find my dozen classmates staring at me. Mimi ni tako ga dekiru lol!

This Japantown is as Japanese as you can experience outside of Japan. I should know too, since I've been to Japan and can use the "things Japanese" philosophy as measurement. I admit Japantown, San Francisco is my semi-secret place to hang-out & zen. Eat a bowl of real Japanese noodles, or a handful of the most divine mochi. Sometimes you can find me browsing a book in Kinokuniya, or admiring a 19th century Hiroshige at the art gallery. Sometimes I'm incognito as the Last Samurai, under the 100-foot Peace Pagoda, a friendship gift from Osaka, Japan, sister city of San Francisco. Ah be humble, shoulders relaxed, no mind, no mind... my Bushidō instructor once taught me. A warrior does not give up what he loves, he finds the love in what he does. Hai, Sensei!! 

Towards the end of the movie, it was only then, as Katsumoto lay dying, he looked up at the cherry blossoms above him that he realized... "Perfect. They are all perfect..." Perfection was everywhere.

The End. 

"They are an intriguing people. From the moment they wake, they devote themselves to the perfection of whatever they pursue. I have never seen such discipline." - Algren, The Last Samurai
author: Eric R.

description: I love this place its really fun. There's a Japanese market that sells Asian grocery with variety of goods. Too bad the eel was 31$ for a small piece i couldn't afford it. So I went some where else and got eel to make sushi. Daiso store everything was not a 1.50 some stuff cost more than a 1.50. But overall the daiso store was worth a trip. I got loads of goodies from the Diaso store and the Japanese market. There are plenty of Japanese markets if you look around. They use to sell triangle sushis but not anymore I think they have it at a different japanese market.
author: Chen C.

description:
The 2018 San Francisco Cherry Blossom Festival was what brought me out to SF J-Town today, on this perfect beautiful sunny Bay Area afternoon.  The festival has been around for about 50 years. The live bands and cool food booths, offering both traditional and trendy Japanese food contribute to this lively, party-like outdoor venue.  

 Although I've attended this event many times in previous years, it's always fun to explore the various food stalls, and stroll through J-Town when it's totally packed.  Emphasis on totally packed. Think no parking to be found anywhere remotely nearby, along with jam packed restaurants.  It's actually an anomaly for J-Town.  When you visit on any non-festival day, I wouldn't describe it as even busy, and definitely not packed.  On a "normal weekend", there's a good amount of customer flow, but nothing that would make the news.  On the other hand, festival weekends are a completely different story. This was definitely a fun-filled, but also a crowd-filled weekend.  Having said that, we did arrive today on Sunday, in the middle of the closing parade, which is a huge attraction of the festival.  Again, just be ready to endure the kind of crowds you'll never encounter here on any other given day.  

Of course, you'll always experience Japanese food galore here.  Endless sushi spots, ramen restaurants, etc.  Anything and all Japanese food related items can be found.  However, interestingly, given the vast amount of Japanese restaurants throughout the entire city of SF, most locals don't head to J-Town for Japanese food.  Perhaps because it's considered a tad touristy here?  Not sure, but none of my personal favorite Japanese restaurants, high or low end are in J-Town.  

I've frequented SF J-Town countless number of times.  It's interesting if you've never been here, and I easily prefer it over the J-Town in San Jose.  You can easily spend half a day here, browsing the various shops, having a nice lunch, or you can extend your day with a stop at Pearl Spa, a women's Korean spa, which I totally loved (refer to my upcoming review for deets).  As a visitor, if you have some extra time to spare and enjoy Japanese culture, definitely make your way over to SF J-Town.  Or if you've never ever experienced their annual Cherry Blossom Festival, I'd say it's worth doing, at least once. Same time, next year.  Plus, all this fun is free too!
author: Lori N.

description:
Best Japantown outside of Japan?

Don't get me wrong, it's not a must see in SF and not the same as Japan, but the closest anywhere will come to Japan. It's also one of the biggest. It spans a couple small city blocks. Bigger and better than the JTowns in LA, Van and TO.

There's a stretch of restaurants, inside and outside the mall. High end restaurants and lower end / food court restaurants, as well as dessert shops. There's even a few Korean restaurants. There's a few bargain shops for knickknacks, think Daiso, as well as a sizeable bookstore. The most isn't huge, but bigger than another community mall. Probably the most impressive feature is the tower in front of Japan Centre/Kintetsu Mall.

I felt like the Japanese culture (or any culture for that matter) is fading in the USA (melting pot), so I love how they're trying their best to preserve it here.
author: Vincent H.

description:
Loved walking around Japantown.

Plenty of restaurants, bakeries, dessert shops, mom and pop shops, spa, Japanese American National Library, etc. They also have a Daiso Japan here, where most things in the store are $1.50. Sweet! If you're visiting San Fran, Japantown is a must-see. 

Come hungry!
author: Kimberly J.

description: The Cherry Blossom Festival is a fun event. Great music and entertainment and good food. Lots of great options for shopping.
author: Juan V.

description: Since I'm from Japan, sometimes I just crave an environment reminiscent of where I grew up. The San Francisco Japantown is one of the better American renditions of a mini Japan that I have sent thus far. Sure it's not really much like Japan but it's nice to see your Kinokuniya, Daiso, & Japanese style foods even if it's a bit of an Americanized version of it. There are lot's of restaurants, a beauty shop, Asian toy shops, some boutiques, & more. I will definitely be back next time I'm in SF.
author: Chelsea B.

description:
Japan Town in San Francisco is still the cultural, social, religious center for Japanese Americans in the Bay Area. Although many of the Japanese restaurants are no longer run by Japanese Americans, there are still establishments run by Japanese which still can offer authentic flavours & cooking techniques. You just have to do a bit of research & nose around to find these fine establishments. 

Benkyo-Do-, the Japanese Mochi/pastry shop comes to mind, & it may be the longest, continously run Japanese shop along w/So-ko Hardware which sells traditional Japanese ceramics, metal utensils, objets d'art, etc. Go to Ichiban Kan, which is equivalent to a Japanese 99¢ Store. Nijiya, Japanese Supermarket. 

Some of the higher end Sushi restaurants feature Japanese trained Chefs who wield their knives as expertly as they present comestibles steeped in Japanese culinary traditions.  

Went on Sunday, August 27th where they conducted a Origami/Japanese paper folding contest to introduce Japanese culture & art to all who participated. The end results were displayed in a large room. Many Origami on display were created by youth while one impressive scorpion was made by the instructor. 

Talked w/ one of the hard working volunteers who said that the Cherry Blossom Festival in April was the big happening where the community put in extra effort to create an extravaganza. I suppose January 1st, Japanese New Year would also be celebrated as it is in Little Tokyo Downtown Los Angeles.  

Pleasant place where there is a concentration of Japanese influences  in a large square block bounded by Geary, Laguna, Bush, & Fillmore.
author: Gary I.

description:
Seriously there is no review here written by me??? Omgosh I'm seriously shocked. Why?  Because we always end up here in this part of town especially during the CBF. We've been here countless times too.

Can you believe it rained this past CBF on the parade? Yes I didn't make it on that day. I'm not that die hard fan! In fact the year before it was so hot in SF I didn't even bring the appropriate clothes for the warmer weather in SF. I had to even buy some new clothes for the hot weather. Gosh I hate doing that! LOL

We ultimately ended up here even though we were doing our best to venture out and explore sights of the City & ocean views. Love shopping in the shops of Japantown bc you never know what you might find and can't live without it. 

There are so many places to eat here too besides the two Japanese markets in this area with one of them encapsulating the infamous bakery Yasukoichi & their TDF coffee crunch cakes! I missed out the weekend of CBF that I made sure I got some yesterday! Yay for selling individual slices!

It seems that they always are having events here on the weekend. We just so happened to come when they had Japan Day. They even provided shuttles to the Soy & Tofu event which was held close by not in Japantown but a trek away if you were to walk. 

Currently the Hotel Kabuki is undergoing renovations but I think they are still opened to the public. It's ideal to stay there & enjoy Japantown. I'm sure we will be back to shop, eat & enjoy. This San Francisco Japantown is the largest & oldest one in the USA. Sounds like we are pretty blessed here in Northern California! Yay!
author: Karen K.

description:
So excited to actually be able to go and look around today. Many different things to do and eat.
The only down side is every place closes at 6 or 7 or is not open on Mondays. But still had a wonderful time.  I will be back
author: Melissa O.

description:
Japantown is a neighborhood in San Francisco that has a cluster of Japanese focused restaurants and stores. It is bordered on the north by Bush St, the west by Fillmore St, the east by Gough St, and the south by Geary Blvd.

It's a fun neighborhood to walk around and take in the sights and grab some ramen for dinner. I tend to think of this neighborhood as some place that is nice to spend the evening rather than where I like to hang out during the day. There are no vegan focused restaurants here, but I have come across a few options that are reasonably good. I still mainly come for the atmosphere though and not the food.
author: Regina W.

description: went there to see the annual cherry blossom festival. Lot of people and foods. other than japanese restaurant and grocery, nothing much to see or do.
author: Choy T.

description: Probably one of my favorite places to visit in San Francisco. It's always changing! I mean always! I've been coming here for 10 years and sometimes it's sad seeing old places go, but nice that there are newer places bringing Japantown back to life. I love the book store, daiso, and the cute plant shop that's hidden. There are so many gems here, it really does feel like another world.
author: Jessica F.

description:
Was in the Bay Area taking a break from the killer Phoenix heat with a friend and she said hey let's check out Japantown. Now everyone visiting SF always says lets hit up of China Town, I have never heard of or been to Japantown so I was down for the adventure, unsure of what we would find, but ready to go.

Japantown is apx 6 blocks of specialty shops and restaurants and SF Japantown is one of only three Japentowns remaining in the US.

I really enjoyed my time exploring Japantown, so many places to eat, was kind of bummed we already ate before we got there and so many places to shop.

If you are in the area, I highly recommend checking out Japantown, you won't be disappointed.
author: Monica O.

description:
Japantown must be my favorite place to visit when I was in the Bay Area. Feel like you are the main character of an anime movie, it gives a completely different vibe. 

Best ramen shop in time, matcha ice cream, $1 stores with many "kawaii" stuff. There is a grocery market down the block to pick up some to-go foods or Japanese groceries. 

Plenty of restaurants, shops, events are going on. As a tourist, I very much enjoyed my time at Japantown that I came back pretty much every day to explore more. I think they should not close all the stores at 8 pm :(
author: Stephanie L.

description:
I've been coming to Japantown since 2001, both as a tourist and now resident of the Bay Area. It's been fun to see it evolve and over time, see more locals & tourists alike visiting the area. The center of this neighborhood is the Japanese Peace Plaza with it's iconic structure and where events are often held. You can find parking at the Japan Center Garage, on the street or if you are ambitious it's not a bad walk from Civic Center BART up to the area (recommended when there is a festival happening.)

In addition to shops and restaurants, the area hosts a variety of free festivals and events. You can see what's coming up via their website: http://sfjapantown.org/ Each April, the crown jewel is of course the Cherry Blossom Festival with free admission, Taiko drumming performances and a parade through the area. 

Japantown is also where to go for a dose of cute-all types of shops provide endless browsing opportunities of all kinds of Japanese toys, stationery, books and anime. Everything is in close vicinity between the New People Mall and the Japan Center Malls, East & West-plenty of dining and snack options as well the more practical (but fun) housewares meccas of Ichiban Khan & Daiso. I like to take out of town visitors here and find myself coming back time and time again to see what's new. One of my favorite SF neighborhoods.
author: Jennifer N.

description:
Things change so quickly around here nowadays.  Staples that I grew up with have gone or evolved into something else.  Perhaps it's an indication of the high rent here or the volatility of their customer base, but I never take for granted a good restaurant or shop.  One day it could be there and the next, it's gone.

However, that being said, it's a great place to roam.  From the delicious aromas to the interesting display cases, one can immerse oneself in this little corner of the SF.  I love hanging out here with friends, chatting, eating something delicious, and finding a cute item to take home.  The parking isn't crazy expensive and it's usually not that crowded unless there's a festival going on.  It's worth a good afternoon for fun and good times.
author: Angela K.

description:
I have just returned from my second visit to Japantown. My girlfriend (who speaks Japanese) loves this place. I am always impressed by the quiet efficiency of the people who work in the shops and restaurants within the different malls and side areas of this community; the crowds may swell and the noise levels might rise, but the servers keep on ticking with a certain calmness.

Yesterday was Kimono day; a very talented choir of kimono-clad ladies sang in one of the 'squares'. When my girlfriend was in a cosmetics shop, I looked in the display windows and noticed action figures, robots and spaceships intermingled with the sprays, perfumes and powders - all perfectly normal in JTown.

Street parking near the malls can be scarce or completely taken all day long. Last year I drove all the way from Fresno and found a spot right opposite the East Entrance. Friends told me that the gods had smiled upon a completely unprepared person; knowing that miracle was not likely to happen again, this time we arrived in a Lyft car and evaded the difficulties of parking and snarled up road traffic completely.

I can spend hours wandering around JTown - just looking at the shops and noticing the different rhythms and patterns of life within this transplanted piece of Japan.
author: Jack W.

description: One of the last three remaining Japantowns in the US. Poke your head into all of the small, family-owned shops and restaurants! There's something for everyone! And, block out some time to visit the Japanese American Museum is San Jose, too! Need a break? Head to Roy's Station for a latte!
author: Jason H.

description: If you like Japanese food, Japantown should be on your list. Multiple restaurants with the typical ramen, udon, sushi, tempura, curry...you get the point. There are also many shops with Japanese goods, and an excellent grocery store where we shop regularly for Japanese staples.
author: John C.

description:
A great place to go and shop. Make sure you shop around as many stores sell the same thing, but charge very different prices. On this trip we found some tiny plates that matched our set and had lunch. Most lunch places serve about the same thing. We went for the one that had some people eating there, but not too crowded that there was a wait.

If you are looking for something unique go into the arcade. It's full of picture booths with all different kinds of backgrounds. Also make sure you down the side streets. There is an assortment of different clothing stores that are uniquely Japanese. There is also a very cute tea shop that serves a very elegant afternoon tea.
author: Melissa S.

description:
I had fun roaming and driving around the streets. You can definitely tell it's japantown because of the people and the signs. Parking is not hard to find and is inexpensive.

My sister and I were able to find some good places to eat. We also saw some interesting things in shops. It was a fun experience. I thought it was going to be bigger, but for the amount of time we had to roam around I'm not complaining.

I really want to attend the cherry blossom festival one day. The event looks so festive and fun.
author: Anh L.

description: It's always nice visiting this place on a weekend and when there's a spring festival. There are plenty of options for food and the shopping is plentiful. If you like Japanese food, films, manga, and anime collectibles, this place is for you. The restrooms are small and cramped and definitely not suited for big crowds, which can lead to lines right outside the doors.
author: Tyler H.

description: JapanTown.... good for food, so so for parking depend on the hours of the day, but I notice lots of shops and restaurants are closed or change ... by the way, on the Saturday the 7th of July, the whole building restrooms are OUT OF ORDER!! Yikes!!!!
author: Louis W.

description:
I use to come here all the time. Maybe once a week when I use to live here and once every time I'm visiting ever since I moved to SoCal. FIRST...I recommend if you are planning to stay longer then an hour...im not sure how much the garage costs are but it's probably most likely a lot cheaper to park in the lot then to park on the street. I can't believe how expensive meter parking is now. It was literally $5 an hour on a thurs-DAY. I came here in the morning when everything was starting to open and am SHOCKED at the meter prices. I still wonder where all the money goes when there's tons of pot holes all over the city.....

I have my ups and downs about this place. I just like to come here shop around at some of the boutiques to buy hello kitty stuff (reallllyyyy sad to see they closed the sanrio store here) as well as buying ice cream for my kids and mochi for myself. Given I didn't have much time at the meter either... I didn't even bother to go to the bookstore since we have it in LA already. Their mai do store use to be FULL of kawaii stuff until the last few years they started to carry a lot less of the cute stuff. I've eaten at the restaurants here countless of times and have even seen the worker kill a mouse in front of us at one of them. Overall..its not too much to do here any more. If you're here just for an hour or less ... finding street parking is no problem during the day.  But given the prices are sky rocket high....I may not come as often any more. Maybe once every blue moon.

Yelp Review 2017 Challenge 37/100
author: Linda L.

description:
Many are familiar with the pagoda on Peace Plaza, which is the landmark of San Francisco's Japantown or Nihonmachi. San Francisco's Japantown encompasses the area bounded by Laguna, Fillmore, Geary and Bush Streets and is one of only three existing Japantowns in the United States. 

The heart of Japantown consisted of the indoor Kintetsu and Miyako Malls, which houses shops and restaurants.  There is an AMC theater and hotels in the area as well.  Should you drive here, there are two parking garages with discounted validation from many of the businesses.

Whether it is grocery shopping in Nijiya and Super Mira supermarkets, shopping for cool nic nacks at Daiso, eating some mochi at Benkyodo, desserts at Sweet Stop or eating at one of the many restaurants that encompasses Japanese, Korean and Chinese cuisines, Japantown has something from everyone.
author: Al L.

description: Lovely little shops, especially the stationary stores. I just love buying expensive pens and pencils from Maido (the one at the Union Square Mall closed down like last year) However, it's a pain in the butt to take the bus-- it's ALWAYS crowded. Unless you're an old person, you will probably have to stand for the entire bus ride.
author: Anna L.

description: Always a fun place to visit. I try to make it down every couple of months. It's gotten a lot busier over the years and the upgrades around the facility have been really nice. I recommend looking online for different events they have planned throughout the year to get a fun and unique experience out of your visit.
author: Cliff H.

description: The whole environment, people, decorations, buildings and food in Japan town making you actually feel like you are in Japan ! I love coming here, everything's is so cute and unique. If you ever would wanna go to Japan, you can come here :)
author: Helen L.

description: From the moment you arrive to Japantown you instantly feel the culture. The smells are delicious!
author: Kristina B.

description: Love love love this place! I always stop by here whenever I'm in the area.There are a lot of great things to see. Love all the Knick knacks and snacks that they have. The only reason I'm giving it 4 stars is because the restrooms are always always dirty. Maybe I always go in at a bad time but restrooms are always a mess.
author: Cheyanne M.

description:
Growing up I always enjoyed Japantown because of the environment, the cool things you can see, the people, decorations, and the food. Located in the city you can find either street parking or the garages they offer. [NOTE: If you do come during the cherry blossom festival, come early because it is very difficult to find parking if you come later in the afternoon] 

This place has a variety of asian cuisine ranging from bakeries (anderson), cafe/crepes (Sophies/Hana/Marys), Benihana, Isobune sushi, Moyo Froyo, Takara, Seoul Garden, etc. Depending on what you want this place definitely has a variety of food ranging from Korean, Chinese and Japanese. Not only do they have restaurants here, but they have small shops that offer little toys, make up, hair products, car products, mochi products, manga books, etc! 

It has two "malls" that they consider as the East Mall and the West Mall. One could easily spend hours here if they wanted to. Whether it be to hang out with friends, eat, shop, or go to the events they offer this place is a great place to just spend some time in the city!
author: Nadine Y.

description:
#6/2016

Being a San Franciscan for more than 2 decades, I've begun to see a pattern to my shopping and living while I spin around the city running errands and exploring the city in search of places new or necessary: All of them now pivot around my child.

The nursery school years meant our little world was largely centered around the Inner Richmond: the Safeway on 7th & Anza (the *only good Safeway), the Cal Academy, Ton Kiang, Nagano Sushi and the Carousel by McLaren Lodge.

Preschool was all about the Inner Sunset: Andronico's, Art's Cafe, Crepevine, Mothers' Meadow in Golden Gate Park, Giorgio's Pizza, 19th Avenue 76 (hello, Joe!) the Irving Street Post office and the shops along Irving Street.

But Japantown has always drawn me to it again and again since the first month I lived here. I'm not here seasonally but rather cyclically. I return and I'm reminded what I've missed: Soko Hardware, Nijiya Market, Sundance Kabuki Theater, Peace Plaza and all the shops and restaurants in Japantown Center. 

Japantown is evergreen and since we drive past it constantly we tend to forget about its place (its beginning after WWII, an ugly chapter in U.S. history), its treasures and San Franciscan-ness. 

I wonder what it will be like once the Board of Supes decides to finally fill in the tunnel of Geary Boulevard so people really see and travel through Japantown by whatever means of car, foot or bike and not just whiz past it 60 feet below at 50 mph on their way east towards Union Square and the FiDi.
author: Jennifer O.

description: Fun and so much to see went during Chinese New year celebration everything was fun and so busy but no wait can't wait to go back
author: Ciara K.

description: I love coming here! They have so many cute little shops with Japanese Goodies! They have a Daiso store that anchors the place. There are multiple Japanese restaurants, I'm pretty sure they're almost all really good and authentic. I've eaten at the Restaurant on the Bridge and Ramen Yamadaya before both are good. They have a parking lot down below and I believe it's around $2 an hour.
author: Ramona G.

description:
Kon'nichiwa San Francisco Japan Town. 

It was the last day of my San Francisco trip and I felt like I have done most of the touristy stuff in San Fran. So, I decided to search on Yelp and found out about this cool place! Coming all the way here from Downtown San Francisco, it was definitely very different. Around this area, I saw a lot more of the elder generation and school kids.

After walking around for a bit, we saw a bridge and the five-tiered concrete Peace Pagoda. We knew we made it! Walking in, I don't think we were at a normal entrance, but it was kind of sketchy, because there was a paper sign that said take the stairs or the elevator. We were debating between the two options, when literally 10 massive flies were in the small space and then flew closer to the elevator where a mop was blocking it. Guess the elevator was the only option. Going into the mall felt like Pacific Mall in Toronto or Aberdeen Center in Vancouver. It wasn't nearly as big as either of them, but it reminded me of them because they had little stores and restaurants in a little section of the malls.

There was honestly SO much to eat, we couldn't decide, so we literally just walked around until we were so hungry that we just walked into a restaurant. HIGHLY recommend coming here to check out DAISO, everything is only $1.50 there! Loved it so much. JapanTown's "malls" are also not all connected, so there's a section that you have to walk outside before you reach the West/East Mall. We walked a little outside where the main entrance of Japan Town was as it had an arch. The shops outside are very cute as well, I loved the origami shop which also sold Tortoro backpacks. Outside on the sidewalks of this street, there were unique sections to sit in.

Definitely a cute little area in San Francisco. I wouldn't say it's completely Japanese though because I saw a lot of Korean stores in there as well!
author: Kristy N.

description:
For most of my life, I've detested this place. Just boring and dull, like the rest of the city. Then I guess, I "discovered," or maybe rediscovered, Japantown a few years ago. It's the only place in the city that's "Asian," yet upscale and cool instead of ghetto. It's not that Japanese, except for the bookstore, Daiso/Ichi Ban Kan, some restaurants, and the festivals. I'd say it's more pan-Asian than anything else. Most of the businesses are owned by Chinese or Korean, probably. With the popularity of Korean beauty products, there are a few Korean beauty stores here now, but Tony Moly is so creepy it makes Sephora seem accessible in comparison. 

Overall, Japantown feels like an oddly comfortable part of the city, with much less hipster and elitist pretensions than most neighborhoods. You probably won't see rallies of the moment here, whether Occupy in 2011, or Bernie in 2015, or BLM in 2016. It feels comfortably Asian, like you can be yourself instead of trying to fit into SF pretensions. 

Chinese places in the city tend to be painfully ghetto, like Chinatown, or almost working class, in an ugly way, like Irving, Noriega, Clement, etc. But Japantown is chic, clean, and cool. Japanese pop culture as well as traditional culture reign supreme here - one of the Asian cultures that has managed to be upscale and trendy, instead of ghetto in this city. 

The festivals here have always annoyed me - too many people, anime/cosplay types that look godawful, politicians riding in cars, garish floats, and uninteresting food. I remember when Ross Mirkarimi was in a car in the parade, happily waving, as if he were free of the wife-beating scandal that made him infamous a number of years ago. A lot about SF is much worse than it's made out to be. I've always gotten a depressed feeling coming to the Cherry Blossom and other festivals in the area. 

Kinokuniya Bookstore - the top level has lots of interesting stuff, all laid out in a clean, well-lighted way. It's actually a chain, which might come as a surprise to most people. Like all bookstores in SF, it has its own unique sort of selection. It's not renegade or edgy, but it does has a good amount of art and design books. It has none of the scary, uninviting vibe of many bookstores in the Bay Area. The bottom level, though, seems strictly for hardcore manga, anime, or Japanese pop art fans.  

Nijiya Market might be a decent place if you're really into Japanese food, grocery items, and toiletries. Otherwise, it's good for a new and novel sort of visit and not much else. I never found staff to be pleasant, in contrast to the "nice and polite" stereotype of Japanese people. 

New People is like CAAMFest - full of Asian American hipster types who think they know a lot about film and cool culture. It seems the various stores here are always changing, probably due to high rent, lack of business, and overpriced, niche merchandise. I'm not sure how much the New People stores and offerings "represent" Japan. I'm sure Japantown represents Japan as little as Chinatown represents China. Which is 0%.
author: Valle H.

description:
I really enjoy Japan town. All the Japanese food, desserts, and anime themed products. I wish there were vegan options.
I finally got to experience the annual cherry blossom festival. It was wonderful, lots of great performances, tents and vendors.
The first time I came here I didn't realize where I was going or how to navigate around the area so it was a short and unsatisfactory visit. But never again, now that I know.
author: Paloma P.

description: Home away from home ! I specially love najiya market. I can find all the Japanese food that you had back home. it brings me joy to come to this market every chance I get. reminds me of home
author: Yoshi K.

description: I liked this better than Chinatown because it's a little more organized and easier to navigate. They have a lot of cute shops and foods.
author: Ellen L.

description: Every time my husband and I are in SF, we always look forward to going to Japan Town rather than the Piers. It's just about a 20 minute walk from the BART and/or you can Uber/Lyft your way there. Either way, walking really isn't too bad. We love the feel and always love stopping by all the little shops and eateries they have here. Not to mention.. it's CLEAN here! We've never really attended any of the festivals they host here, but hope to at least be able to attend their Cherry Blossom Festival. Some of their shops contain shirts, collectibles, knives, car merchandise and lots of little knick knacks. I personally love going here as they seem to have tons of good restaurants and artwork.
author: Kaye T.

description: One of my favorite places to visit in SF. Amazing shops & restaurants. Check out the Sushi Boat place!
author: Adam A.

description:
TGIF ! The weather in Sacramento has been in the high 90's all week so my wife and I decided to take a drive to the Bay Area for some fun and relaxation. Our destination today is San Francisco. To be exact Japan Town off of Webster Street. 
A parking structure is provided for parking and there is also additional parking on the street. Be aware that when parking on the street, they are metered 7 day's a week.!

Japan Town is not only comprised of the 2 shopping malls but also all the businesses that surround the center. They have many restaurants, a hotel, a book store, bakery for your morning coffee and unique one of a kind gift shops. A must place to visit if you are headed to the Bay Area! 

We enjoy coming here for the Nihonmachi Street Fair which is held in the month of August. This fair is to celebrate the Japanese heritage. Traffic is blocked off and the street is lined with information booths, food venders and live music for your enjoyment. Lots of fun!

 Not to mention Cherry Blossom Festival which is held in the month of April. This year  the Hello Kitty desert mobile was here! You should have seen the line for that! They also had a large children activity area for fun and games.
Entertainment on 2 different stages. Food venders lined the street. Companies giving free promotions of sample products.They even had a Anime Cosplay contest for those who like to dress up.
Make sure you stay for the parade on the last day of the festival. IT'S AWESOME!

Fun and amazing things happening here throughout the year so the next time your in the area , make sure you stop by .Who knows I might be there.
author: Kenneth K.

description: Always a delight to stop by San Francisco's Japantown. It's pretty big with a large variety of shops and restaurants.  Also if you're looking for some snacks or desserts, they've got plenty of that here as well.  Japantown usually isn't too crowded, except during festivals.  The festivals are usually worth the crowds as there'll typically be special booths and vendors along the streets and shops.  But if you're looking for a more peaceful experience than any time outside of that should work. There's a pretty decent amount of parking available too located underneath the main shopping mall area.  This place may not be the most easily accessible if you're coming from the Caltrain/South Bay for instance, but it's doable.
author: Bryson L.

description:
TOURIST BEWARE!!!!

So mad...my friends and I rolled up for ramen after the Giants game one night a couple of weeks ago. A lot of the places/shops were already closed with the exception of some of the late night Japanese restaurants. As we weren't from SF, we drove around a couple of times to look for parking. After finding parking off Geary (in a POORLY LIT area off the street), my friends and I parked and went to grab some late night ramen. 

After an hour or so, we came back to find a burned out trash bin by the Japanese monument, and 2 car windows broken into off Geary. When we rolled up to our rental car, we found out our car was broken into as well (window broken). The street was poorly lit and no one was around on a Saturday night. 

After returning the rental car, they lady asked if we got broken into in San Francisco. Apparently it is an epidemic and daily occurrence in the city. What a bad way to end the night..let alone end our trip up to SF (they stole our SF Giants toys and memorabilia).
author: Ticha B.

description:
I love Japan Town in SF~! 

Maybe its because I love cute asian things and food!! This is the best place to come to get your Japanese food fix. It's also my favorite place to go shopping! I love love love the Daiso store, pika pika, milk tea, and the anime shops!

If your lucky, you might even see some cosplayers doing a photoshoot here!
author: Ariana M.

description: this is like the Little Tokyo in LA, but bigger! there are a bunch of cute shops all throughout, making this a great stop for tourists!
author: Jamie C.

description: My favorite J-town in the West Coast! They've got a traditional looking, beautiful plaza filled with ramen shops, boutiques, crafts and goods. They've got a mall which has DAISO, gigantic symbolic pagoda (from Japan), cultural centers and several annual events, inc the Cherry Blossom festival & sumo wrestling matches! The clientele is very diverse as well and there are also Korean & Chinese restaurants in the area. I only wish it was bigger-like 10 more blocks bigger, lol! I also wish they staged traditional Japanese theater such as Noh, bunraku and/or kabuki (inc dinner and drinks) to offer more variety & entertainment in J-town! Definitely worth visiting if you're in the area!
author: Hu L.

description:
Let's be honest here: This is Korean Town now, with just bits and pieces of the old Japantown left. That in itself is nothing bad, but ritzy commercial gloss now permeates every single facet of the buildings. If you have only been around in this century, it probably is a positive evolvement, but for those of us who have seen this since the mid-60's, it is a disappointment.

However, the single star is not for the shops but for the lack of professionalism on the part of the security staff. One of our party of 7 had his SmartPhone stolen, which happens, but not only were the uniformed "security" person unhelpful, our member was told to "just forget about it". Even worse, even though he explained again and again that all he needed was an official report that did attest to the theft ( for insurance purposes ), he was refused.

Before people start ranting about the fact that security people are not really the police, I would like to point out the fact that 8 years ago, a similair incident occurred with a mobile phone, and the security staff at that time, especially an elderly Japanese man, not only helped search for it, but also gave us a report that fulfilled the insurance requirements.
author: George T.

description: Japantown is the best. I'd recommend going to Daiso/Ichiban Kan to pick up some knick-knacks, Benkyodo for mochi is a must, and Nijiya Market for snacks and food. There's also a good bookstore near Benkyodo that has alot of interesting books from Japan.
author: Judy S.

description: So many things, I can say about Japan town sf. The festival's, all the little shops during the festival's... Also, even with out the festival's it's worth coming here... every one is super friendly (at the restaurants and the shops that they have there in general... just love coming here... can't wait to come back again
author: LeAza D.

description:
As requested by Peter L, I'm writing a review about Japantown. I haven't explored many Japantowns in the US, but I do adore this area of SF. There are so many cute shops, restaurants, etc. After looking through Japantown's directory, I realized I've visited a number of establishments here.

*Benihana
*Benkyodo Company
*Daiso Japan
*Do Re Mi Music Studio
*Dosa on Fillmore
*Festa Wine & Cocktail Lounge
*Mogura Lounge S.F.
*Nijiya Market
*Playground Korean Fusion
*Ramen Yamadaya
*San Wang Restaurant
*Sophie's Crepes
*Super Mira
*Tanpopo Restaurant
*Town Music Studio
*Waraku Ramen Dining
*Yakini Q
*Yasukochi's Sweet Stop
*Yoshi's San Francisco

Though I don't get to Japantown as much as I used to, I still stop by for the occasional night of karaoke. Festa is the bar of choice with some of my friends, but you can also go to Do Re Mi, Mogura, Playground or Town Studio if you're in the singing mood. I have another group of friends that prefers private rooms, so we used to go to Do Re Mi all the time.

Food wise, there's a bunch of options. You can go to Benihana for entertainment while you eat. Dosa for delicious Indian food. Yamadaya, Tanpopo or Waraku for ramen. San Wang for korean chinese food. Or Yakini Q for korean bbq. If you want something sweet, there's plenty of places to grab dessert. Benkyodo has the best mochi. Sophie's got delicious crepes. And Yasukochi's coffee crunch cake is to die for. You MUST try this if you're in the area.

Parking is typically easy at night, but during the day, it can be a pain. If you can't find a spot after a couple of loops, just park in the Japan Center Garage. The roommate and I drove around for 20+ mins once before giving up and just parking here.

Such a charming Japantown. One day, I'd love to check out the Cherry Blossom Festival. So pretty!
author: Elena N.

description:
One of my favorite neighborhoods to hang out in.  Like Chinatown the architecture is different here.   It a short bus ride away it feels much farther.

For my visits the center is around the big  mall.  With its shops and restaurants.  Kabuki hot Springs around back.  The hardware store across the street.

It's fun and different here.  And when I am one San Francisco it draws me like a magnet.

I first came for Kabuki Hot Springs, quiet. Warm, soothing.  It is a retreat within the city.

From there I discovered the mall and the plaza with the pagoda where if I am lucky school kids are playing.  Then there is the Japanese version of the Dollar Tree.   My final stop is the hardware store selling odds and ends just hard to find.
author: Mark B.

description:
I would rather go to Japan town than China town! Clean, great food, unique lil store and you can find authentic japanese bookstore. Since I love Japanese food and reading, this is perfect for me.

Like other reviewers said though this "town" is small. It may look unimpressive size wise but size isnt always the most important thing. Quality is also important and this town delivers it.
author: Dee W.

description: I love the sushi boat, dessert stands and the tiny shopping center! You can find so many different cute things there!
author: Mary T.

description:
***************************** 1423 ***************************

   Japan Town Nihonmachi in San Francisco is spanned about 10 blocks.  SF Japantown is one of only three Japantowns remaining in the U.S. today, I didn't know that!

  I've been here for years and dined at a few places. This time, I got to show my 11 yrs old niece around. She's at that age where she's into Japanese Anime, comic books, and anything Japanese!

  I love how on their website, they show the parking spot availability on Japan Center Garage, Entrance on Geary between Laguna & Webster and Japan Center Annex Garage, Entrance on Fillmore between Geary & Post. You can check it out before you are heading there.

  Plenty of shops, restaurants, and things to do, Japantown History Walk, and much more. They offer street fairs, festival, community activities, and more.

  We went to the East Mall, the West Mall, Ramen Yamadaya, Ramen Underground, Kinokuniya Bookstore, Daiso, Auto Freak, Amiko Boutique, and a few more stores. We had such a great time. My niece got to learn about other culture, enjoyed Japanese cuisine, got new shirts, and toys. She told me when can I bring here back. It was a good day.
author: Manda Bear B.

description: Since I'm half Japanese, I really like any area dedicated to them.  SF has many Japanese immigrants so I'm not surprised to see a section of the city centered around their culture.  Small in comparison to Chinatown, but a good place to explore all Nippon type shopping and restaurants.  Little Tokyo in LA, I think is better, due to the fact it's bigger.  But this is the nicer looking one.  Not easily accessible from the BART, but a couple of city buses pass through here.  I always visit this place when I come to the city.  I will come back again.
author: Darrell K.

description:
So, I'm going to give this a solid three stars. At this point, I dream for one big thing regarding this location in San Francisco: For there to be more Japanese ambiance here - and I don't mean cutesy-cutesy stuff, or stuff that is simply "good for the kids" - no, I mean a good Japanese vibe that goes on within the City. Upon going here as a teen, Kinokuniya was and still is a great store and my favorite. I'll tell one at the moment, it's a big part makes Japantown as good as it is. So yesterday was the second time I've been here just in the last month, and my takeaways are that there a bunch of good places to just hang out both outside and inside of what I'll call the "Kinokuniya Property" - due to the mall being named after the bookstore; there are plenty of places to eat, but my personal favorite, although it is available in other locations, is Benihana: I love that place and everything about it as long as I'm next to the hibachi grill. Daiso is a great nic-nac store, but I like the one next to the Powell Street BART better.

Now that was just some of the good about Japantown, so here are some of the not-so-good stuff that I can recall about it in my head: Although there are lots of restaurants, much of Japantown is consisted of restaurants that sell similar offerings - it's literally like a "who does it better" kind of thing from what I can tell. I know though, that there are some confectionary stores within the mall, but the thing is, I don't eat foods with added sugar, and for those who thoroughly care about what they put into their bodies like I do, there aren't many options. With that said, there isn't much of a variety in regards to restaurants. Also, the nic-nac stores aren't exactly the most practical things in the world; although you can find a few hidden gems within those stores, so it isn't a total red flag. But one thing about Japantown that is very much a red flag these days is Japan Video. I wrote a review about it if one is curious, and I'm very annoyed and disappointed with that store at this day and age.

Some more good things about Japantown though are that it designates a spot so you can get food or something from a different place delivered while you're hanging out over there. Also, I noticed that if you're walking here all the way from one of the BART stations, all of the sudden, around the time you hit Cathedral Hill (like say if you're walking from Powell St.) You might notice the sudden decrease in the angry beggars and the rest of those loonies that you'd see on Geary and O'Farrell. I don't know if they're chased out of there, but I must say, "Keep it up" when it comes to not having creeps surrounding the Japantown mall. I also hear that the grocery stores and the bars seem decent from what I hear, and I've got a good vibe about 'em, but I haven't been in them as of yet. I would like to visit Japantown again in a few weeks, or even sooner, but that Japanese ambiance.. it is very much missing: I heard that there were once "old time" Japanese stores from reviews. In addition, I remember there being cool places like that as well as video game import shops, but I know, these "beauty places" and nic-nac stores being the only places here in Japantown aside from Kinokuniya, isn't cutting it, and most certainly isn't for everyone. Until then, I'll go to just Kinokuniya and perhaps a Japanese restaurant, or something slightly different located in other parts of the City, or Oakland, Emeryville, or Berkeley. I'm glad I know Japanese well enough to purchase and read the books, and hold convos, but that's just me. Maybe I'll also see if there's anything else good going on in Japantown, but until then, Peace folks.
author: John S.

description:
Whenever I'm in town I always stop by here. I can spend hours just browsing and looking around.

Lots of great restaurants and little shops
author: Leionette O.

description:
I wanted to have a great experience here, my being Japanese and all, but it felt a bit empty.

Oh, sure, there are many, many, many restaurants but there doesn't seem to be any Japanese life in the area.  You can eat and buy and remember about Japan, but it seems as though the Japanese-ness is gone, somewhat like the fake pagoda outside.
author: Nobuyuki S.

description: Purely reviewing for the bathrooms. Everytime I've used the women restroom, a male janitor has entered opened the door and started cleaning. I wouldn't care if it was a female. Or if they didn't do it in such an invasive way. It was awful, and if you have little girls with you I'd recommend avoiding using the bathroom. Not to mention how As I was walking outI saw him drop trash into the bag then out of the same bag filled with trash pull out seat covers?! So gross. It's a shame because it's a nice place to shop and eat, and I'm so happy they try and clean the bathrooms but the way they do it is just wrong.
author: Katie B.

description: Japan town is nothing spectacular to that of China town.  It's literally a strip mall with a pagoda in the center.  Little quirky quaint shops here and there with a food court that pretty much sums it up. Walk across the street to the other side and it feels like a ghost town.  I thought the bookstore inside the mall was probably the best thing.
author: Phung L.

description:
I loooooooove Japantown SO much. So very, very much. It is a 6-block area in SF and is well worth visiting if you have any love for Japanese food or shopping. I have much love for both of these things so I've made three trips to Japantown so far. The first time I walked there from SOMA but I would recommend a taxi unless you're staying close (I always think distances in SF look quite small and am completely wrong every time). 

I've never eaten at one of the restaurants in Japantown (horror) but have had crepes which were pretty good. The area is a shopping centre split over two halves - one of which is mainly a Daiso (100 Yen store / $1.50). Daiso is good but the one upstairs is better. 

On the other side of the shopping centre there's more shops and restaurants. My picks are the Kinokuniya bookstore and Maido for stationery, and there are some really sweet gift shops too. Definitely pay the area a visit - this is where I got most of my gifts/presents for myself to take back home.
author: Briony C.

description:
Lots of nifty stores and restaurants. Almost feels like your in Japan. 

Loved the outdoor pavilion. Grab a snack or coffee and sit outside and soak up the sun. Very cool temple looking structure provides a nice shade too. 

Daiso was my favorite store to go to. It's like a Japanese dollar store. So much stuff to buy at a good price!
author: Mo M.

description: Only come here for the andersons bakery, the many japanese restaurants, and mochi! other than that, i'd pick chinatown over this spot. the mall is overly crowded BUT at least they have bathrooms. the hubby loves getting ramen and sushi in the area.
author: Janet D.

description: Lots of restaurants & shops, but what people might not expect is how diverse the clientele can be; I love it!
author: Matt L.

description:
Great place for the whole family, for strolling and some shopping .A lot of shops  to choose from ( small item, collectibles ,beauty products and etc)  , restaurants and more .

We went to:
Daiso  
Misfune (for our dinner)
Kinokuniya Mall, East Mall, and West Mall. 
Belly Good Cafe & Crepes ( yummy dessert, ordered crepes with strawberries and chocolate )
Playland ( for kids , games / Arcade)
Katachi Japanese Gifts  ( we bought  wooden katana for my son ( they have real ones), and  key chains)
Japan Town Collectibles ( cool toys and small collectibles here)
Andersen Bakery and Café (  ohhh pastries & bread!)

Great experience and its a beautiful place!

Directions: Just north of Geary and south of Sutter, between Laguna and Fillmore.  Yo can also take Muni buses #2, #3, #4, #22, #38, and #38L (Limited) take you to Japantown. You can't miss its landmark--the Peace Pagoda 

Japantown San Francisco Website: http://sfjapantown.org/
author: Liza G.

description:
Japantown oh sure I love everything about the Japanese stuff such as some anime characters & even their video games such as final fantasy and their food. 
So I was super excited to visit japantown in SF especially to buy some plush from my favorite characters and of course for some foodie & Japanese snacks. 

We parked in japantown parking structure which was very convenient. 
We were surprised to see how old & empty and dead the place was. 
Not a lot of stores to choose from only one store that had one of my fav character. No Crayon Sinchan or doraemon characters, FF characters such as squall, lightning figurine or a cute danbo. Very dissapointed. 

Walked into Daiso Japanese store like a dollar store but nothing fun, it was only stuff that we are not gonna use ( note maybe for some teenagers who like some cute /  Kawaīdesu / kawaii girly stuff ) 
So ended with buy nothing from this store. 

It seems wherever we went, we got bad looks from some older Japanese women, note only from the older women not the young people. 
Oh yes the prejudice eyes and manner. 
I am not a racist but geez cmon this is America. I knew it since they do the prejudice with their own race too if the people are born mix race not pure Japanese. Not believe me? Just watched the movie about it. 

Wow ladies really? First of all I'm not a Japanese and second y'all now live in USA a country with a freedom so please get rid off your mind set from your origin country.  

Actually, there's not much here to enjoy here, little boring. There were few of restaurant choices. 
We picked one and a dissapoinment.  
We thought what better place to get a tea than in japantown but what a dissapoinment  The best that I can say it was mediocre. No mochi shop inside the building only outside which wasn't that good and bad service seemed like they didn't want to serve us. 

The only highlight of the adventure was the Japanese market. Everything of Japanese that you can think. So I bought many Japanese snacks such as kitkat that you baked in the oven, green tea and dark chocolate kitkat & and some instant ramen.

And the kinokuniya book store hmm disappointed. This book store was my fav place to go every weekend while I lived in my original country so I was excited to find out what they'll have in real japantown and real Japanese book store but nada. Booo

The bakery shop inside was good, a small shop for some snack. 
Unfortunately this japantown in SF isn't my favorite to hang around, I prefer japantown in LA because it's far superior with a great food, stores and pleasant atmosphere & close with Japanese museum.
author: Claudy H.

description: Japantown was pretty cool. I've never been to a Japantown before, so I thoroughly enjoyed it. One of the malls seems a bit abandoned--not too much to do--but the other side was much more lively. I liked all the little shops and food you can eat, as well as the cultural and historical pieces. Very important for community members to know about and understand Japanese history in the United States.
author: Tony A.

description:
Nothing compared to LA's Japantown! Not only is it tiny but most of the shops look dead. The restaurants in this area don't have too many good reviews, not a very cute place to walk around, and all the slightly interesting stores are in the compact mall. Even in broad daylight, the whole area looked a bit eerie. 

There aren't even any good Pokemon to catch in this area! Come on Japantown!
author: David H.

description:
Went during the Cherry Blossom Festival, so part of the road were blocked and there was whole bunch of people- though it wasn't worst like I imagined. 

Soo hard to find parking, seriously took my brother 30 mins or more just to find parking and took my friend 30 mins just to get her potatoes on a stick snack. Those who's reading this needs to understand that I went during a festival so this is expected, but it's still a hassle

This "J-town" is pretty small, but looks cute. I suggest going when there isn't a special things going on; it's so much easier to find parking and don't need to wait a long line just to eat some sushi or some noodles 

I love the foods here, so delicious. I also think Japantown has some cute and Japanese-like stuffs, but in about an hour and a half or so I was done looking around. Anyways though, This was the closest interaction I could get of Japanese culture
author: Hye L.

description:
One of my top 3 fav neighborhoods in the city!!!

Has great selection of Asian food, stationary, dollar store, entertainment, and is relaxing! I go here to get away and the great thing is I never run into anyone I know. Haha 

I used to study here and even if it's a Mall --- it's pretty great for it!! Usually safe as well!
author: Alissa H.

description: I love Japantown. I've only been here twice now and I still haven't explored every corner. I'm very interested in the Japanese culture so it's nice seeing buildings, stores, shops, food and people here. It's a definite spot to stop by when you're in town. Especially when there's festivals!
author: Cindy H.

description:
Japantown (to me) is a state of mind.
not physically but mentally.
i've spent many post teen hours here
-first enjoying the booze, the nightlife
then the cultural apects of Komochi, JACA. et al.. 

the  WW 2 concentration camp experience.
was a topic not spoken of by the Issei, nisei
but the Sansei wanted to know. 
their quest has kept japantown alive  culturally and spirtually

the world war 2  hysteria didn't wipe out j-town,
despite executive order 9066,
evacuating all persons of japanese ancestry to camps.

beyond the eateries and the shops, there is a japanese community in Japantown.
author: Victor G.

description:
This is a great place for strolling and some shopping. It's definitely one of the more popular tourist attractions here in SF. There is a shopping center on each side of the tower (not sure what that's actually called). There are quite a few shops, but I usually just window shop and sightsee. Those shops include your typical Daiso, several small Japanese/Anime shops, a few bookstores, clothing stores, food stands/shops, and some restaurants. Most of these places are pretty affordable in my opinion. Some may be cheaper than others. But since this is a tourist attraction, there are some places that could be a little more expensive. 

There are also a supermarket down the street and several restaurants and shops around the area (like across the street). I honestly only come here for one thing and that's food. I come here for the Belly Good Crepes that is located in one of the indoor mall area. To me, there aren't very much to do around here. People walk around, take some pictures, and eat mostly. 

Overall, I do recommend coming here if you haven't yet! It's a nice place in the area even if you're a native. It's a nice place to take a walk without having to spend any money! I will most likely be back soon (to try out that Mitsu Teahouse that everyone is raving about).
author: Wendy Y.

description: My absolute favorite part of the city.  It's a tiny neighborhood but if you're infatuated with Japanese culture like me, it's a must!  I always stay at the Radisson Miyako when I visit SF and I just love it.  Shop at the Japantown Mall, marvel at the Peace Pagoda and have some great sushi or ramen at one of the many restaurants in the area.  It's a great place to visit.
author: Anthony G.

description:
We walked to Japantown from our hotel just west of Union Square and it took about 20 minutes.  Am glad there were no major steep hills and it was a good walk.  In the mall, there are stores that sell everything from cosmetics, toys, housewares, and more.  Lover of Pocky? Ichiban Kan has lots of variety for Pocky and other snacks.  We did most of our shopping in SF at Japantown for items we haven't seen back home like cute rice bowls and dishes.  The Daiso store ($1.50 for most items) was super crowded and long lines but it's bigger than the store on Market.

There are many small restaurants in in the mall which were crowded on a Saturday evening.  We walked around the streets around the mall and found many of the restaurants had a line up too.  Was busy for a Saturday and saw some Cosplayers shopping too.
author: Violet P.

description:
Japantown is a piece of heaven both for the locals and for the tourists.  There are plenty of shopping experience to explore, endless restaurants in both East/West malls including nearby areas outside within .5 mile radius, and an outdoor ginormous courtyard with a pagoda to bask in all that year round weather in San Francisco (no snow for my Minnesota friends). 

Daiso Japan I was told opened a few years ago where tourists gets a sample of "Japan!"  They sell pretty much everything you can think off other than grocery items.  Their pricing starts at $1.50 on up.  Cheap for a huge ceramic soup bowl.

There is a parking garage underneath which also connects directly to the Hotel Kabuki for that added convenience including direct access to the both malls.  If you stay here, you must try their Hot Spring Spa!!  It will do wonders!!

In addition, one of their annual highlights is the Cherry Blossom Festival (around April/May) and said to be "the second largest festival outside of Washington, D.C. to celebrate the blooming of cherry blossoms."  I was told buy one of the participants, this year's event included one of the largest "Anime" homemade costume celebration.

If you are looking for that one of kind Kimono, you will find it here but for the added tourist cost.  I suggest walking several blocks away doing business with the locals as it  will reduce your cost significantly up to 50% or more!  I did buy a Samurai sword here awhile back only because the owner was retiring and was selling his business.  He gave me a great deal I couldn't pass up! :p  So do ask for added discounts if you are here to shop.

For the coffee lovers (like me),  Andersen Bakery is also located inside this mall.  A treat after having enjoyed those delicious sushi from "Isobube" across the hall.  And I save the best for last ---- for the Karaoke lovers and party goers, there are several Korean BBQ restaurants outside this mall with  private rooms where you can belch to your hearts desire and be a "mega-star" for your friends and families and have a nice sit down dinner too.  

Just so you know -- I am that one in a million Filipino Dude that CAN'T carry a tune.  So yeah -- not all "Pinoy" can sing, but I sure got the moves!  :p

Enjoy ~
author: Edwin R.

description:
Ok, so Japantown basically has a mall and a few stores along the streets. It was really meh. 

Inside the mall, you can try the dragon's breath dessert, crepes or bubble tea. Maybe pop into daiso, but this is really nothing special.
author: Candy L.

description: This place is really great, when you enter you totally forget that you are in San Francisco. Many shops, great restaurants, and some awesome pastries ( you really need to check the Japanese crepes). If you have some time to spare in SF I definitely recommend + its wakeable to Fillmore street which is really great place for shopping or having a drink.
author: Julien R.

description:
Okay so have you seen Big Hero 6 ? Big fan? well then you need to stop by this area when in San fran. I mean the city in that movie is called  "San Fransokyo"  so it's pretty fun to pretend you're in the animation haha ( always a kid at heart) 

I absolutely loved this place. Being Half Japanese, anything to do with the culture is always something that interests me so this spot is pretty much a dream. With tons of Japanese restaurants, stores and snack shops within the mall buildings and surrounding areas you can always find a reason to check it out. 

I will say that it's a sketchy area at night, so be careful and never leave valuables in your car if you drive here. Other than that it's gorgeous and one of the highlights of my trip here.
author: Kenny O.

description:
Super touristy, but we had so much fun here!

The shopping center has dozens and dozens of stores for you to choose from, some of them super cutsie and novel, and others that lean more on the traditional side. Massive selection of food, whether it be deserts, restaurants, or drinks.

Definitely go try the Mitsu Teahouse for amazing boba!

Cheap stores, expensive stores, and mediocre stores. They have it all! This is probably one of my favorite go-to places in SF now. I only hope I'll be able to come back sooner than later. There's still a lot to see.
author: Molly M.

description:
Shake it Off - Dedicated to Japantown

I stay up too late,
Got Japantown in my brain. 
That's what Pika Pika say,
That's what Japan Playland say,
I go on too many SF trips,
But I never make myself stay. 
At least that's what Kinokuniya says,
That's what Kissako says.
But I keep cruising,
Can't stop, won't stop eating. 
It's like I got this mochi,
In my mind, says it's gonna to be alright
Cause I am getting fluff, fluff, fluff,
And I am going to take selfie, selfie, selfie.
Sophie's Crepes, I am just going to shake, shake, shake,
Shake it off, Shake it off.
author: May Y.

description: Went to Japantown for the first time and enjoyed on of the restaurants inside, I finished off my Japanese meal with a fresh made crepe filled with banana, whipped cream, vanilla bean ice cream, and some yummy Nutella! Emm! You can smell them as soon as you come in to Japantown and Sophie's Crepes was quite busy! They had the coolest art, gifts, etc. It was really fun!
author: Faith S.

description:
San Francisco may be known for housing the largest Chinese population outside of China, and having a great Chinatown, however; I was thoroughly impressed and excited that SF also has a pretty decent J Town (personally think it's better than LA's)! Love, love, love Japanese! 

Several blocks of Japanese storefronts and restaurants, including 2 long interior malls on each side of a Japanese courtyard called Kintetsu Mall (Japan Center). Sure, there were a few tourists there during a weekend afternoon, but it wasn't overly crowded and the shoppers and diners consisted mainly of Japanese people. Not nearly as touristy (not a "trap") as Chinatown. Instead, the stores all carried various imported traditional Japanese merchandise - a few highlights: Vintage (aka "gently pre-owned") Happi Coats at Asakichi for about 30 bucks each, which is what they charge in Asakusa, Japan! Quite the bargain! Playland Japan with all of the funky Japanese arcade games to play. And of course, Daiso Japan! Such a score and brings back great memories. Just like the 100 Yen stores all over Tokyo, except here maybe 150 Yen (aka, most items about $1.50), but still great stuff on the cheap! Stocked up on chopsticks, fans, some kitchenware, food items, and fun things for the nieces. 

If you like culture, Japantown is a must when visiting San Francisco! Be prepared to spend some time. You can easily spend half an afternoon if you want. Truly a small taste of what it's like to visit Japan. Just be sure to skip dining at Benihana! Really?! Really.
author: Dawn H.

description:
My 300th review! Might as well be one of the few places I love to visit.I love this place. Oh I really do. I try to come here at least once every 2-3 months if possible. 

When I visited Japan and missed the darn place, I would often myself coming back here. So many stores, food, movies, books, and even the kitchen sink. There is so much beauty here in the heart of SF. 

There is a lot to do here even though it's not a very vast area. I never seem to get bored of this place. If you're into the Japanese culture, then this is a great place to visit. I'm sure you'll find something you'll like.
author: Benny H.

description: Japantown is so cute! So many shops and resturants and shops to explore! Parking can be a pain. Definitely eat at Benihannas when you're here!
author: Tina H.

description: Cute place with lots of Japanese treasures to discover! Restaurants, clothes, manga, movies, etc., this place has a lot to offer!
author: Nicole B.

description:
Japantown, more commonly known as J Town or Nihonmachi, is 6 square blocks of Japanese influence in San Francisco. It mirrors Little Tokyo in LA, but is much bigger and older than Sho-Tokyo. 

The area is like a rectangle, with the following streets surrounding that section - Sutter St to the North, Geary Blvd to the South, Fillmore St to the West, and Laguna St to the East. Webster St cuts thru the center from North to South and Post St goes thru the middle from West to East.

Visiting Japantown is a must for me when visiting the Golden Gate City. It's quiet, relaxing, and there's tons of stuff to see and shop. Not to mention all the good eats and restaurants nearby. The Peace Pagoda is quite a sight. It's a five tiered concrete Buddhist stupa. It's a part of the Japan Center complex, designed by Japanese architect Yoshiro Taniguchi and presented to San Francisco by the people of Osaka, Japan.

Japan Center is the main shopping plaza in Japantown. Opened in 1968, it's composed of three malls - the Kinokuniya Mall, Kintetsu Mall, and Miyako Mall. The two major festivals held each year in J Town are the Cherry Blossom Festival (April) and the Nihonmachi Street Fair (August).

What I also like about this place is that there's some Chinese and Korean influence within the surrounding area. It's not just about Japanese culture, with Little Tokyo in LA having that same attitude. A good mix of Asian diversity. Hanging around here makes me feel like I'm that much closer to SoCal, even though I'm hundreds of miles away. Exact reason why Everybody's Favorite City is my all time favorite city in CA, outside of the City of Angels of course.
author: Chris C.

description:
I like this 4 blocks small neighborhood.  Lots of Korean and Japanese restaurants. Such as shabushabu, tofu ya, sushi plate etc.  make sure you read the reviews of some of the restaurants and make a sound judgment lol. 

I also like the bookstore in japantown, which has lots of imported books and magazines from Japan. (I wish I could work in that bookstore! It hired bilingual staff all the time- Japanese and English) 

And yes, I like the hair dressing shop(Japan beauty salon). Their hair stylists are FROM JAPAN!(who know how to cut Asian hair), though it does a little bit more than you get in Chinatown lol.  

Last but not least, I love Nijiya market, where you can get tons of authentic imported snacks from Japan. I love sweet stuff :)
author: Alanda B.

description: I absolutely love this place! . First of all let me tell you, it is NOT very big but its so pretty and full of random Japanese things and restaurants to go and explore. Also some corean ones. Its a fun place to go if you like Japanese culture, there are some stores with fun activities like kawaii photo booths for your friend and you. The restaurants I haven´t had the chance to taste but I did try some interesting snacks. Its a fun and cute place to go to on a weekend with family or friends.
author: Jaqueline G.
