description: Lived in Japan and Japantown transported me back there. There is a Kinokuniya which is the best bookstore ever!! I'll be visiting Japantown the next time I'm in San Fran. And make sure you get a Japanese crepe with a happy face when you go!! Yum!
author: Jay F.

description: I've been hanging out in Japantown for over 20 years and I can't believe it hasn't really changed. This is a good and bag thing. Some of the stores are still cool such as the Auto Racing Store and Bookstore and Mifune and Isobune are great but the lack of restrooms amazes me. Why haven't they added more restrooms??? For as old as Japantown is, it has been at least kept up and I love hearing Japanese people speak their language. They've kept the culture alive here.
author: Jen L.

description:
Japantown often gets overlooked when there's the famous and huge Chinatown in San Francisco. Many tourists don't even visit and it's quite an empty place. Most tourists don't even know Japantown exists.

Well, sucks for them because Japantown is fucking awesome and anyone who disagrees is wrong plain and simple.

Even though Japantown is relatively small, what it lacks in size it makes up for in quality. It's a lot different to Chinatown - it isn't dirty, busy, and cramped. In fact, it's the exact opposite. It's spacious, relaxing, and "zen". I regret that I have never been able to visit Japantown during the Cherry Blossom Festival but I hope to someday in the future.

NOTES:
~ Take a walk through the Japan Center - a large shopping mall filled with awesome Japanese shops and restaurants.

~ Japantown isn't only home to Japanese things. There are plenty of banging Korean BBQs here as well - don't skip over YakiniQ for it's bomb AYCE.

~ It's relatively close to the city, only about a 30-40 minute walk or a 10-15 bus ride.

I really hope that Japantown expands in the future rather than shrinks. It's a wonderful place that deserves a lot more credit than it gets - anyone else who has been there can testify!
author: Clarissa Y.

description:
Japan town is pretty neat, in the way that the Americans decided to make friends even after they had small little fight in the 1930-1940s.

Parking is plentiful on the streets.

There were a bunch of Japanese restaurants in the area, but other than that and the cool-looking pagoda in the town square, you almost can't tell this place is anything out of the ordinary.
author: Edward L.

description:
KAMEHAAAAMEHAAAA!!!! Naruto fans, you know where I'm coming from.

For everyone else; Konnichiwa and welcome to Japantown! 

Here you will find your absolute Japanese obsessions from Japanese animation and cartoons, Japanese clothing wear and martial art weapons, to authentic Japanese food and sake.

This is considered one of the largest and oldest Japantowns here in the United States and proudly holds a yearly Cherry Blossom Festival to celebrate its rich heritage. Japantown was started in 1906 after the major Earthquake while the actual Japan Center was not open until 1968. 

During WWII, many of the Japanese were forced to leave their homes in this particular location because of the attack on Pearl Harbor made by the Japanese. This was unfortunate because many of these citizens had no part in the attack. 

Today, Japantown features many different Japanese, Korean, and Chinese restaurants as well as Nijiya Supermarket, Kabuki hotel, and other various shops located throughout.

There is a parking garage with discounted rates if you validate your ticket at one of the many shops.

Definitely a fun place to visit and explore when coming in to San Francisco! I hope you enjoy this culturally thriving community as much as I have!

Arigato and happy shopping!
author: Ann S.

description: Japantown is awesome!  Lots of shops and restaurants!!  I thought it was just going to be a small little plaza with only a handful of stores.  Boy, was I wrong.  Japantown spans several blocks and it seems the area is well maintained.  I could easily spend half a day here.  It us totally worth checking out J-town if you haven't been here before.
author: Steven L.

description:
I am a big Japanese gadgets freak so here's where I found one of my paradise corners in San Francisco. The place is a commercial store full of small Japanese shops and restaurants, although you can also find Chinese products everywhere. I recommend you to save an hour to look around and check some of the spots like the photo booth stickers place, OMG it's amazing! You can personalize your headshots with crazy cartoons, Japanese letters and colorful designs for only 10 dollars. 
Another shop I love is the  one dedicated to Japanese ceramics, even though I never buy there because of the long trip, we all know they play soccer with the luggage between flights and connections.

And last but not least... the T-shirts and million useless gadgets store! from cuddly toys in a shape of a smiling nigiri to spider shoes, you would want to buy everything! Be careful with the prices because sometimes is not that cheap and here you can get excited easily, but here you'll see the most funny chop-sticks ever, get them!

I'd refurbish some old parts of the store that doesn't fit very much with the clean, colorful Japanese style.
author: María Q.

description:
I used to be a hardcore geek (I'm more of an elder geek at this point), one that was fascinated with everything from the land of the rising sun. Japantown seemed like the mecca I was looking for back then, with video games, food, and a giant pagoda.

Nowadays it just feels like a tourist trip. There are some awesome things around here (the 21+ Kabuki 8, Kabuki Springs, Mums), but the mall itself feels...like a mall. Lots of inauthentic food shops, overpriced tchotchkes and more -- they even have a Benihana's for chrissake!

If you know what you want, Japantown's worth it.
author: Casey S.

description:
One of my favorite spots in SF. A wealthy amount of novelty shops, a good collection of specialty stores, and a delicious shindig of traditional Asian restaurants. 

It's a good get-away from the norms of the city. The atmosphere here is humble, yet lively and rich in culture. They even have dances going on at their tiny square by the man-made pond. I don't know how regular it is, but I've been lucky enough to catch it on the weekends. It's definitely a popular go-to for tourists and locals alike. 

Visit Cako and Sophie's Crepes while you're in the mall! My favorite dessert spots here.
author: Kurt C.

description:
Japantown in San Francisco is much bigger than it looks and if you really want to savor the culture, you should allocate at least one to two hours to explore this complex, in addition to the time spent dining.

The center piece of this town is the Peace Pagoda, a symbol of peace.  The original Peace Pagodas were built in Hiroshima and Nagasaki after the atomic bomb attacks in WWII.  Now many of them have been built in cities and countries in Asia, Europe and America to signify and to promote World peace.

On the south side (the side near Geary) are the 3 main buildings: The East, West and Kinokuniya Malls, which are connected in the upper level.  This is really nice on a cold and rainy day where you can park in the garage and explore all 3 buildings without venturing outside.

Dining:  You'll find eateries of all sizes and flavors - from Benihana to small bakeries, from sushi to ramen, from seafood to steaks.  There are also several small coffee houses as well as a few crepe shops, where local gems are often found.  I highly recommend Sophie's Crepe. Too bad we ate so much already and we couldn't sample every store.

Shopping:  The 2 main anchors are Daiso and Kinokuniya Bookstore.  This Kinokuniya is large, almost the size of a Barnes and Nobles.  There are many small boutique stores selling everything from fashions to dvd's and souvenirs.  You have plenty of opportunities to purchase numerous items that embrace the Japanese culture.  There's also a grocery store at the corner of Post and Webster (the far west end of the complex).

Across the street on the North side is an outdoor pedestrian complex separated in the middle by Osaka Way, a stony walkway which looks like a replica of the streets of Japan.  The pathway is lined by more shopping and dining establishments as well as a small multi-level fashion complex.  There is also a large home furnishing store.

Parking:  There are both street metered parking as well as garage parking.  Before you complain that it is expensive, don't forget that you are in San Francisco.
author: Rob L.

description:
I have been a fan of this Japantown since the first time I visited over a decade ago. I love Japanese food and the culture and of course there is a ton here. Prices are a little above average since this is a touristy spot. 

Stores here include Daiso, restaurants (Japanese mainly), grocery stores, cafes, bookstores, etc. My favorite ones are Sophies Crepes and May's Coffee Shop for their Taiyaki. Nothing has changed since my first time here!
author: Juan F.

description: My son's favorite place in SF!!  Great place to explore for Japan fanatics.  Anything from Sushi, Mochi, Boba, to Manga art and fans, bamboo plants, and katanas.  Beautiful artwork throughout the mall and great events throughout the year like the Cherry Blossom Festival.
author: Rosie M.

description:
Whether you're a foodie, anime fan, or just love those cute Japanese gadgets, Japantown is probably the place for you. I particularly enjoy the restuarants - ramen, shabu shabu, izakaya etc. Remember to check out both East Mall and West Mall for a greater selection! 

However, Japantown is usually pretty quiet at night, so definitely come when there's still daylight!
author: Christina N.

description: This place was so cool! I' d come here again. Not many people know its here. But alot of places close at 8pm or earlier
author: Ashley P.

description:
The Japan Center is composed of (from north to south) the Miyako Mall, the Kintetsu Mall which is filled with nice shops such as dais which is a 1.50 store but do have some items over that price but noting over 5 bucks. they also have some other stores and restaurants in this building but the mains tore everyone loves is the dollar fifty store. the Bridge inside the mall is a nice asian Japanese tea garden style of bridge, i always thinks its nice to photo shoot inside here with some asian outfits or costumes. the Kinokuniya Building- all of which contain shops and restaurants. some amazing shops i recommend is the yogurt shop where you get to create your own sweet and i do recommend their green tea fro yo because its amazing. the crepe spots with ice cream in them are so fatty good. next they have tons of Japanese food restaurants from sushi to bento to teppanyaki which is a live show from the chef on your table cooking your meal with all kinds of tricks. also amazing pastry shops around in the mall. they do have quite a few of the anime shops which sells anime to Sanrio items and great for people who are looking for cute items. (The Peace Plaza, with its signature pagoda tower landmark, lays inbetween Miyako and Kintetsu.)

outside the malls there are also coffee shops and ramen shops on land and  underground as well. there are lots of asian restaurants on Geary blvd as well and goes all the way to ocean beach. anyways japan town is a small compacted place with lots of shops which gives you the vibe of being in japan and introducing you to the asian culture especially the Japanese culture. 

also parking shouldn't be an issue if your worried about that because there is an underground parking structure. most places do accept credit and atm, there are also some atm machines nearby but might be a extra fee for it. be prepared and have fun. 

i give this place a 5 star because i just love it and try to stop by here when i come to SF. its one of the most amazing peaceful and calm place. some reasons i would stop here is because 
1. i like coming here for the best green tea fro yo in one of the yogurt shop only one of them. 
2. coming here to get origami paper which is located outside the malls. 
3. coming here to look at the stores with anime and cute stuff animals and etc. 
4. coming here to the one and only kinokniya stationary shop which sells nice expensive pencils and pen made in japan and yes it does make a difference when you hold it and write sooooo tracking smooth too. 
5. coming here for their crepes with ice cream right next to the stationary shop hint hint since there are multiple ones. 
6. going to the sushi boat place and no its not all you can eat. 
7. going to the underground ramen shop.
8. taking photo shoot with the pagoda. 
9. going to diaso the one and only 1.50 store with some made in japan items. 
10. coming to the tea shop to get new tea pot and cups too.
11. coming to the anime shop to read their manga and collect the whole series. also a nice book store with lots of choices to choose from. 
12. the instant photo booth place with friends to take cute pics 
13. going into the shops with nice arts if your an art person. 
14. going to bennihana with friends or family or with the kids to give them an experience of cool cooking. 
15. lastly is staying here in the nice hotel which is arm and a leg and is nice. 
16. coming to the cherry blossom festival very year during april on the first and second weekends. 

i hope this list is somewhat helpful and help persuade you to come check out japan town in sf. also hope it helps you realized something you never thought of coming here to do. hope you enjoy my review and have a great day and stay positive and happy yelping! don't forget to vote for this review and if you like what you read don't forget to follow me or add me as a friend. thanks for your time.
author: Alex T.

description: Every year during this month only have a Japanese festival in J town I love coming here for the food and for the culture remind me of home like I said earlier sf review there's a lot to do in the city today well if you're coming out to this festival parking is a little hard to find and the parking lot is kind of full well I hope you guys have fun if you come here if not hope you have fun wherever you are and enjoy your day have a wonderful evening take care and be safe
author: Miko A.

description: Great destination for everything you might need - fantastic hardware and cookware at Soko Hardware, lots of eateries, a great bookstore and the best stationery store. They also have wonderful festivals here.
author: Marco M.

description: This place is especially beautiful during Springtime when the cherry blossom trees bloom. It was a number of Japanese oriented stores and several Japanese restaurants including Benhana. Parking is either on street where you feed the meter, max time is 2 hours or there is a parking lot at the center. There is a pretty good Japanese Supermarket which caters to all your Japanese cravings. I would be careful coming out here at night though, sketchy area across Geary St. They also have had car burglaries so don;t leave valuables out in the open.
author: Dirk D.

description: One of our fave places places to shop and dine in the city.  It has a Daiso, what more can one say?
author: Ted C.

description: As someone who has been to Japan, this district of SF is very authentic! It's quieter than Chinatown, has more kind people and is very authentic to the culture of Japan. You can browse gifts in the mall or the shops, visit a temple, or eat some tasty Japanese food.
author: Margaret P.

description: A bit pricy for a "cheap" import mall. Picked up a small stuffed animal from a bargain market and it was $28.00 and half the places you went in the mall where CASH ONLY. Parking is a pain, and to enjoy the mall you have to get there before rush hour
author: Mikaela B.

description:
This place is huge! You can spend a whole day here, just shopping and eating!!! I had no idea there were 3 distinct buildings here, and also adjacent streets. 

Kinokuniya Mall, East Mall, and West Mall. 

Plan your day accordingly!
author: Elsie W.

description:
Awesome hang out area to go with friends, even if you go alone there is a bunch of sight-seeing to do that is if you like photography and have a good camera. Not too many bookstores exist where I live, so I love visiting the bookstore when I go to Japantown. They have some nice shops where I can find stuff like Rilakkuma stuff instead of me trying to buy it online for way more! 

The only other places I went to with friends were the crepe shop and Pika Pika (photo booth place) and the crepes were yummy.
author: Scott F.

description:
I have been to Japan Town probably at least a hundred times, and never seen this place so packed!  I was there with my hubby and my son for Ramen Yokocho (Ramen Street).  Arrived at 11:00, major congestion everywhere, no parking, parked 5 blocks away, but the street festival was packed and sea of people!  It was as bad as Harauku on Sudays, or maybe worse.  Lines for the ramen booths were at least 3 hours long, maybe longer, so gave up and left.

The good news is that when there aren't festivals, the parking is decent, and foods are too.  Kind of nice and quiet relaxed place.  Avoid festival days if you don't like the crowd.
author: Yoshiko D.

description:
SF Japantown.
Food, shops, events, film, plaza.
Always lots to do.

I eat here too much.
Watch way too many movies.
Need more Jiu-Jitsu.

38 MUNI.
Good, but you know what's cooler?
The 38L.

It was New Year's Eve.
We walked to the waterfront.
It wasn't that far.
author: Dan B.

description: Japan town mall has been going downhill for years. Its probably corrupt management, and the security SUCKS SO BAD.  Ive worked here for years and the company now is the worst out of the last 3 companies that have been here.  Utterly useless and not concerned with your safety or your personal property.  They just want an easy ride.  Don't ever depend on them if you have an incident at the mall. Call real police.  I constantly feel unsafe when there are shady people allowed to prowl the mall and I hate notifying them because they are so useless.
author: Kitty O.

description:
I WANT MORE JAPANTOWN

Okay so it's not like I grew up super far away from here, but I had never been until a month ago. Well, I'd been in Japantown once for the Cherry Blossom Festival in 2010. I had heard about the Fest and wanted to check it out, so we walked around the crowded streets until we were overwhelmed by people, and then we went home. I had no idea there was so much more to this part of SF until I returned a few weeks ago. 

I absolutely fell in love with the Kabuki Hot Springs/Spa after a night at the Kabuki hotel. And I'm a trinket person. It's a horrible habit, browsing and buying stuff I like but don't need. I'm getting better at 'just looking' but then I come somewhere like Japantown Mall with so much awesome going on!  Lots of good food, boutiques, and unique shops here.

Parking was easy and relatively inexpensive. Everything we wanted was walking distance. Milo's Lounge was a little disappointing but The Social Study was a wonderful bar. Japantown won my heart! Definitely a beautiful part of San Francisco. I cannot wait to explore it some more!
author: Amy S.

description:
Japantown may have a limited selection of stores in the Kintetsu Mall, but the neighborhood itself is colorful and vibrant - believe it or not, Japantown isn't just the stores confined to a building, as most people here seem to think. 

During the spring, the Cherry Blossom Festival held in the neighborhood brings out thousands of people and vendors ready to celebrate the opening of the cherry blossoms and the welcoming of the season, with food, entertainment, a wide array of goods for sale, and my personal favorite, the Sanrio booth featuring games based around Hello Kitty and all her friends, with prizes to be won as well. Childish? I like to think of it more as having a shamelessly good time, even if the majority of people in the Sanrio booth are like, ten years old. There's also a parade during the last day of the festival every year.

There are many restaurants in Japantown, as well as small stores offering an array of Japanese goods, and part of the fun is going back to discover which ones your favorites will wind up being. The Kintetsu Mall features restaurants, the Kinokuniya Bookstore, stationary shops, food booths, gift shops, pottery, boutiques, an amazing shop with tons of imported anime, video game, and manga merchandise/toys, and a Sanrio store, to name a few things. 

Japantown is a small neighborhood, but it's incredibly charming and has plenty of things to check out to fill an entire afternoon. You can get here on MUNI or there's a two level parking garage if you choose to drive over.
author: Angela M.

description:
Oh I so need to come back here when it isn't the Cherry Blossom Festival.  

There is so much here I want to explore. I know a few of my friends on facebook and in Tampa would just cry with joy if they saw all the Manga & Anime stores I passed while going through the mall!

The town is lovely, the folks were sweet and polite. I certainly think I could enjoy the atmosphere for a couple of days!
author: Dianna B.

description: They need more EV parking spots. One is not enough in a town as green as SF. Oh, and you can get Japanese food and stuff here.
author: Scott S.

description:
Japantown is one of my favorite places to visit when I'm in SF. I love all the stores that they have and I can usually get my fix for Japanese food, groceries, and shopping! They also have several festivals throughout the year and it's very fun to check out the booths. Love the street vendors. 

Places you should check out here
- Daiso
- Nippon Ya
- New People
- On the Bridge
- PIka Pika
- Sophie's Crepes
- Kinnokuniya 

Also, the parking structure here isn't too expensive. Only $2/hour!
author: Cindy K.

description: Very neat shops! The east mall is not nearly as exciting as the west mall. I would recommend this place more than China town which has largely become a huge tourist trap, offering the same trinkets as everywhere else.
author: Nelanne C.

description:
Few good restaurants around here.  Always good to come shopping here with the convenient parking garage.  But don't park in the streets especially on Geary if its at night.  Many times you'll see broken glass on the ground and its from smashed car windows.  My friend's car window was smashed along with two others this past weekend.  Its the loser people who live on the other side of Japantown, like Safeway area.  Don't want to be racist, but you know who I'm referring to.  Those people who break windows suck because now our Saturday night is ruined and our friend with the broken car window is sad and "just not in the mood anymore".  Thanks to the dickheads that break windows, may you burn in a boiling pot of Shabu Shabu or Soon Dubu.

Anyway, we had a great dinner that night at Sushi AKA Tombo!
author: Kevin L.

description: Just a fun place to be rather small, but they make it work always and you get the feel of culture for what is fit in here
author: Joe L.

description:
One of my favorite areas to shop and eat in San Francisco!  While there are a plethora of your standard sushi spots, they also have more specialized Japanese foods, such as the exquisite omakase menu at Kappa, to the more casual establishments that have foods such as okonomiyaki and takoyaki.  The bookstore has some really cool books and magazines, both in English and Japanese, and I absolutely love the little stationary store here. For those with a sweet tooth, there is a wide variety to choose from, whether it is mochi, pastries, crepes, or the scrumptious cakes from Yasukochi's.  

For more everyday items and services, they also have hardware/household good stores, and grocery stores to choose from.  

Japantown is definitely a good place to do some fun shopping, and also get some great food, if you know where to look!  If you're here, please skip Benihana's and try one of the locally owned restaurants.  Your taste buds will thank you!

One of the only things that I do wish they would improve on are the hours.  The shops here do tend to close early for a big city, although the restaurants are open later.
author: Karen W.

description:
I have such fond memories of Jtown when I was growing up.  It's still the same but different now. A lot of the old time Japanese stores are closed because the owners most likely retired. 

We wanted to park in the garage but they would only accept small cars.  Unheard of. So we had to park on the street and use those SF rip off credit card meters.  It was $4.50/hour so unless we lugged a briefcase of quarters, we had to charge it.  

Place was not busy but I still enjoyed browsing here.
author: Wendy H.

description:
Still one of my favorite spots in SF. Tons of food options and even now, they hold tons of events there.

-Anime
-Tofu festival
-Japanese Heritage celebration..

also parking there is great.. still.
author: Roger A.

description: There are so many stores to look around. The parking is way too expansive park in the two hour parking instead. Most of the stores inside sell Japanese products and food.
author: Ivania M.

description:
A rich area in San Francisco with lots of history stemming from WWII. 

There are many fun shops and heritage sites that you can visit here. Make it a day trip. You're sure to have great Japanese food and a relaxing time. 

Try the Spa inside of the Kabuki hotel. It is magical.
author: Megan S.

description:
Everytime I visit SF, I enjoy visiting Japantown.  Japantown is basically what you'd expect, a collection of authentic Japanese shops and restaurants.  There are grocery stores, bookstores, gift and souvenir shops, sushi bars, noodle houses, bakery/cafes, etc.  Nothing in Japantown ever seems to change.  All of the restaurants and shops seem to always remain the same.  I like the architecture and the buildings/stores are clean for the most part.  There is an old fountain with fish in Miyako Mall and the water is always so clear.

I've tried at least 4-5 different restaurants here and they are all pretty good.  I also like visiting all the stores to explore, whether it's a random Japanese folk store or a video/DVD shop.  They have the biggest purikura (photo booth) store I've ever seen - it's so big that it needs its own map!  Japantown even has its own movie theater (a Sundance theater where you can buy lunch and eat it while you watch your movie!) and its own hotel.  If you're visiting SF and it's a rainy day, Japantown isn't a bad option to check out.
author: Daniel B.

description: Love it as always! I tried street parking last time I went, found it is almost the same or more expensive than the garage.  I also worried my car so much during those time.  My recommendation is to park in the garage.  It is safer.
author: Meme L.

description:
I felt like almost every single store was just about the same as the next. There are of course Japanese restaurants everywhere...with of course, the same dishes. I can't seem to stay here for too long. 

But it was fun to tour around, nonetheless. I love playing in their stores. Like not literally eff around in their stores...! In fact, I highly WOULD NOT suggest that. lol But you know, just browse around and check out a few wonderous things each little shops has to offer.
author: Thanh B.

description:
Back in the times when I use to live as an American naval aircraft carrier fighter.
I would miss the days of Japan, Udoh, the cherry blossoms, gun-dam mechs, and Bunyan cubes. 

Japantown brings me back to these many memories when I was the Last samurai
in feudal Japan times...I was awaiting the "perfect" blossom.

But Enough with all that!!!!

These area around Fillmore is so retro, I have actually went to Japan.
And part of the architecture is exactly what you see in Japantown streets.

It's touristy, and often overlooked as compared to China-town
but it still holds heart with the different shops which sell Anime, Watches, Car items, and even groceries. 

Its one of the place I love to take visitors, 
Thier is also a cousin "Japantown" In San Jose.
But I don't think it fares as well. 

Go to The Bookstore It think it's spelled "Kinokunoya"?

Tell them Tom Cruise, sent you.
author: Michael R.

description: Japantown is so beautiful I love how they have cherry blossom festival every year. They have variety of restaurants here that you can pick from. I love the vibe here it's a great place to hang out.
author: Neera S.

description:
Great place to walk around, sight seeing, buying oriental souvenirs, and buying really really cute things.  Unlike Chinatown, Japantown is cleaner and doesn't smell like piss.  Seriously, I can drop something on the floor and want to pick it up.  It's not as crowded as Chinatown too because not a lot of people know about this place and it's a far walk with all the hills and stuff so taxi it.

I love the little shops they have here.  The have an East and West side of a mall.  Very small but doesn't skim on quality and cuteness.  No two shops are the same.  They are all different and sell different products.  Beautiful view and beautiful trees.  I'm glad I came here.  It was worth the visit and I would love to come back here again.
author: Jackie N.

description:
I learned of Japantown a couple of days before showing up there, since I was going to be heading to San Francisco for the weekend. I was planning on checking out the whole 6 blocks in an hour or two, but that turned out to be more like around 4-5 hours in total, which is great lol. 
I mostly went to check out the stores with manga/anime and all that, but a lot of the other stores seemed so full of merchandise and content imported from japan (excluding the restaurants which I did not get to check out) that I had to check them out as well; it was a really neat trip, I liked how many of the stores were inside two malls, instead of in the streets since the weather in San Fran can be pretty chilly. 
I was also pretty impressed with how nice and friendly the people were when I went inside each store, always being greeted with a smile. 
Overall I was pretty pleased with my trip to Japantown; I would definitely recommend going there if you happen to be in San Francisco and would like to experience some of the Japanese tradition that resides in the area. Cheers!
author: Daniel T.

description: Japantown is a simple and small place, full of food places (especially Korean 'cause I see those a lot around), so it's a easily and quickly explored. There's a small mall that sells anime, manga, posters, and similar sorts of things along with dessert places, such as ice cream or crepes. There's a huge Daiso located in the mall as well and a small supermarket located nearby the mall, which sells a lot of really good snacks and products that can't be found even in Ranch 99. Small events also take place at Japantown for celebrating Japanese culture.
author: Angel N.

description:
It's starting to get a little boring here. They don't have much stores open. In fact The Sanrio store is gone! Sad face. There are a few Japanese restaurants here. My favorite are the ramen spots across the shopping center. Theres a store where they sell bonsai trees, a store which sells Japanese books. A spot to take as much photo booth pictures as you want. 

  A few stores that have those cute anime characters and stationaries.
author: Michele C.

description:
Japantown (also known as Little Osaka, Funayville, or J Town) comprises about six square city blocks in San Francisco and is the largest and oldest such enclave in the United States. Built and settled as part of the Western Addition neighborhood in the 19th and early 20th century, Japanese immigrants began moving into the area following the 1906 Earthquake. (Before 1906, San Francisco had two Japantowns, one on the outskirts of Chinatown, the other in the South of Market area. After 1906, San Francisco's main Japantown was in the Western Addition, with a smaller one in the South Park area. By World War II, the neighborhood was one of the largest such enclaves of Japanese outside of Japan.

After the Japanese attack on Pearl Harbor, the neighborhood experienced "Pogroms" or violent attacks on residences and businesses. In February 1942, President Franklin Roosevelt signed Executive Order 9066 that forced all Japanese of birth or descent in the United States interned. By 1943 many large sections of the neighborhood remained vacant due to the forced internment. The void was quickly filled by thousands of African Americans who had left the South to find wartime industrial jobs in California as part of the Great Migration. 

Following the war, some Japanese Americans returned, along with new Japanese immigrants and associated investment. However, many did not return to the neighbourhood and instead settled in other parts of the city or out to the suburbs. This was further exacerbated by the city's efforts to rejuvenate the neighborhood initiated by Justin Herman in the Western Addition in the 1960s through the 1980s. In my opinion, the result is a concrete ethnic enclave that has may of the expected trappings, but lacks a certain unifying energy or soul. Even the remains of Manzanar in the Eastern Sierras or the Oregon Nikkei Legacy Center area (including the Memorial Garden) in Old Town Portland offers more spirit or Ruach. 

The area is home to Japanese (and some Korean and Chinese) restaurants, supermarkets, indoor shopping malls, hotels, banks and other shops, including one of the few U.S. branches of the large Kinokuniya bookstore chain. Most of these businesses are located in the commercial center of the neighborhood which is a large shopping mall built in the 1960s as part of an uninspiring urban renewal effort. I still enjoy coming here, but wish there was more continuity that would encourage me to linger.....
author: Eric B.

description: Japantown is not as big as San Francisco's Chinatown, but the food here is authentic and yummy, if you find the right place. There is not much energy going on here - at least when I visited, it was very quiet and peaceful. However, the shops can be quite entertaining to browse.
author: Ally M.

description:
Japantown gets the honor of having my 1000TH REVIEW!

Japantown is a fun place to hang out, from the restaurants and shops to the frequent festivals held here (love the Cherry Blossom Festival!) or near here (Fillmore Jazz Festival).

I had no idea how special Japantown was until I looked it up on wikipedia and found that it's one of 3 Japantown's left in the US (and all 3 of them are in CA, with 2 being in the Bay Area!) -- http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Japantown

That makes me cherish SF Japantown even more. This is a much better Japantown than San Jose's, which is smaller and not as bustling. SF Japantown is the place to be.

Some of my favorites here:
- Daiso -- the Japanese $1.50-and-up store (always a long line!)
- There's another $1.50+ store inside the mall upstairs that isn't quite as big but isn't as crowded if you're claustrophobic
- Sophie's Crepes -- THE BEST CREPES EVER.
- Tanpopo -- pretty good ramen
- Nijiya -- Japanese market (pretty cramped, but gots the goods)
- Kinokuniya -- Japanese chain bookstore

Where else is it acceptable to dress up as anime characters for no reason?
author: Esther Y.

description: So much great food in this area!!! And so many little shops for accessories and books and all kind of things at super low prices!!! I could walk around here forever :)
author: Foodie M.

description: I love coming to shop in this place. Lots of cute stuffs with delicate wrapping. and there is a good spot to take pics between two malls. you will love the inside and cant stop taking photos. Japanese supermarkets, makeup stores, and salon. and so on. of course FOOD!!!!
author: Yuzhen S.

description: Its really sad that Japantown is in such decline. Most of the restaurants are owned and run by non-Japanese people, and the food is very mediocre or bad across the board. If I want to eat good Japanese food, I definitely do not go here: I've been disappointed time and again. Although this area could be such a great resource, it is such a shame that the quality of the restaurants is so poor. I left some stars for the fact that there is a kinokuniya and that some of the art/tea/household item shops are OK, though expensive. I hope whichever entities responsible for managing Japantown see this review and step up their game. Not many cities have a Japantown, and it has the potential to be such an awesome place. Please make it good again!
author: Scott S.

description:
Pretty much one of my favorite places to hang out!

- I've been going to high school up the hill near Japantown, so this was pretty much my second home after school. Great place to just chill and do homework or hang with friends indoors. And now that I work at Japantown and I still go to college near by, it really is like my second home. 
- It's always fun to go inside the stores and look around. I always manage to see new things here despite the fact that I'm here almost 4-5 days a week.
- The only thing not great is that everything is expensive. But once you get used to it, you can pretty much know which restaurants and stores are expensive vs. inexpensive. But generally, they're all expensive.
- The arcade is the best place by the way :D 
- There are many great places to sit around and eat a delicious snack like mochi, crepes, bread, dango or onigiri! 

Overall, I really love this place.
author: Samantha Y.

description: Hmmm... In all the years that I've been coming to San Francisco, how have I never been to Japantown?  On a recent visit, we decided to finally check it out.  We loved all the cute little stores with all the cute little things.  Expensive tho so shop with caution!
author: Judy S.

description:
I love Japan town and have been going to the restaurants and stores since I was a kid.  There are quite a few new, good restaurants over there and some good Karaoke places.

What I don't understand is why the management of Japan town doesn't remodel the bathrooms and clean it up a bit.  The bathrooms are all ragged and deteriorated  and in desperate need of a remodel.  It really isn't fair to the businesses either in the mall to have such dilapidated restrooms.  

I don't know who manages Japan town facilities but they need work.
author: Mike L.

description: What I love about the city is how diverse it is and how different districts are a window into what it is like to be from another culture.  Japantown is great example of that.  Unfortunately, I have never been to Japan at least for now, so I cannot tell you if this is how it is there, but I know it must be somewhat similar in some ways.  The mall is a cute place with many different shops filled with various nick knacks that are fun to look at.  There are tons of restaurants with yummy food.  I went to Mifunne onetime and it was delicious.  This is a definite most for anyone to check out at let once.
author: Megan M.

description:
Who knew that there was a Japantown in San Francisco? Not me! I have been to Chinatown multiple times for Dim Sim, and somehow it has never come up (I guess I never asked) that there is also a Japantown. What a pleasant surprise!

Before you judge me for my total ignorance, please know that I do not live in San Francisco (although I visit several times a year).  And  please note that my friends that DO live there, although they knew Japantown existed, and is even within blocks of where they live, had never been.  So this was a first for all of us.

Well, just like the difference between Japan and China, Japantown is clean, organized, and not overly crowded.  And parking is not a b*tch to find.

We picked a random spot to grab dinner, and were very pleased with the fresh seafood, low prices, and honest server that cautioned us "not to order that".

I'm looking forward to exploring more that Japantown has to offer.. the movie theater, the Cherry Blossom Parade, the shops...

If you, like my friends, like in San Francisco but have never been to Japantown, get your butt out there ASAP. You are doing yourself a disservice!
author: Flora H.

description: I've seen better days of this place. Now the streets here are littered with garbage (including personal artifacts) no one seems to care. I would suggest business owners here to chip in and hire a regular clean up crew. There are some interesting Japanese shops and restaurants. Despite the fact that JT is mentioned in many SF travel publications, it's not worth the visit.
author: Steven T.

description: Come here at least a couple times a year. I love seeing all the cherry blossom trees and going to the festival every year. I also like the mall with tall the stores that have what every you can imagine! A great place to just walk around and enjoy your surrounding!
author: Candi L.

description:
As one of the only 3 Japantown's left in the US, SF Japantown probably has the best set-up. With the nearby Kabuki Theater, Nijiya Market on the outside, a line of restaurants, the pagoda in the center, and cool places to shop in the mall, you can easily spend your afternoon here. It is also a cultural hub, with the JCCCNC facilities nearby, the Buddhist Church of SF, and various festivals that are held throughout the year.

Wooo! Keep our Japantowns alive :)
author: Brandon Y.

description:
Wow !
We soooo loved it here ! we did 2 days .
We stopped into Isobune Sushi, Benihana ( reviews to follow) and great shops like Amiko Boutique and the lovely Katsura Garden .

Clean, peaceful and lovely area .
GO!
author: Denice Z.

description:
I visited Japan Town during the Ramen Festival - so probably not the best time for a first impression. 

Sadly, the shopping mall really doesn't look well looked after and the restaurants (in the shopping mall) are so dark and not particularly reasonably priced. Perhaps my negative experience was just because so many people had traipsed through over the day, creating more mess than usual. If so, I'll change my review next time I go back.
author: Kira G.

description:
Such a great time and so many wonderful shops, activities, mall, and neighborhood!  My favorite activities were playing the Japanese games in the arcade and taking pictures with my GF at the photo booth retail shop!

Its even better than SF Chinatown and well worth the trip for a rich history, prideful neighborhood, kind/friendly people(even the store clerks) and SF love!

Don't miss Japantown if your in SF for a few days!
author: Blake L.

description:
Always a great place to come! Love the food selections and shopping. Service for the most part is really friendly. If you walk into some of the boutiques the owners tend to stare, especially if you look young. I'm 23 sometimes mistaken for a high schooler and I feel really uncomfortable. So beware of that. 

Overall fun place to visit.
author: Maly B.

description: Great places to shop and hangout for Asian goods. I bought my kitana here. Friendly atmosphere.
author: Chriselle L.

description: A place to hang out for Japanese and Korean food.  Great bookstore and Japanese things... Nice to visit when they have the festivals... But on slow days you see high school and middle school kids roaming around
author: Sandra S.

description: I do enjoy our visits when we are in Japantown. We mostly come during festivals or when they put on fun events. I like the bookstore, some of the snack shops, browse their fun or cute stuff, and visit Daiso because who doesn't visit Daiso when they visit Japantown, right? :)
author: Lisa X.

description: I love it here! Totally worth the trip across two bridges!! Awesome food and shopping!! I love all the $1.50 and up stores like Daiso and Ichiban Kan. I also spend way more than I should. There's also tons of bakeries and restaurants here. Korean BBQ, Ramen houses, sushi, Benihana and other places with Japanese food, like okonomiyaki, chicken karagi, agadashi tofu, everything! They also have The Face Shop here which make really good face products like masks, face washes, both stuff for men and woman. Don't forget to check out the markets here as well! You'll find everything from candies, cake rolls, produce, noodles, gyoza, different sauces and dressings, beauty products, mochi, etc. don't skip out on j town if you're in the area! Parking is cheap too!
author: Jennifer C.

description:
Japan Town isn't necessarily a "town" but a combination of a rather smallish-medium sized plaza and two malls attached to each other attached to a hotel.

You see more "Wapanese" than actual Japanese and for many reasons I'm really not fond of people who say... "KAWAIII DESU DESU DESU" Everywhere I went. It drove me INSANE. The actual mall/plaza is kept really clean and the stairs are really neat. There's not much to write about this place since it seemed like most of the stores are closing down. :/ Its quite unfortunate. Although the couple useful things about this place were the vast variety of Japanese restaurants that touched on almost all the specialties except for holiday treats anddddddddddd... super traditional foods. 

The bookstore looks MASSIVE and the outdoor plaza thing I mentioned about. Looks super amazing if I were out there during the daytime. Oh. Parking is tough to find too by the way.
author: Monique N.

description:
I really enjoyed japan town. I have never had the diversity of Sushi as I did here. A conveyor belt full of sushi options not found in my little town up north. It was really fun to see what you were getting before making a decision. 

Great shopping and food!
author: Kevin F.

description:
What is not to love about San Francisco's Japantown?
The restaurants, the shops, the mall, Hotel Kabuki (formerly Miyako Hotel), a movie theater that has a mini bar IN the screening room, a convenient parking garage... all compactly packaged with love. Also, you must check out the annual Cherry Blossom Parade in April... it is an amazing time.
YOKOSO! :3
author: Summer M.

description:
Japantown! It's basically a series of shops and restaurants, all very authentic, and is often home to festivals such as the cherry blossom festival and wekfest.

There are a few restaurants that I really like, one in particular is Maki. I love Sophie's crepes and I always stop by Daiso. For me, there are stlll a plethora of shops still to be explored, but for the most part, there's not much to do.
author: Kevin L.

description: This place is pretty cool. It's a small area, only a few city blocks,so you only need an hour or two. But it's cute, there are lots of restaurants and stores. Get your fill of green tea-flavored EVERYTHING in the mall and check out the pagoda statue in the center.
author: Ross L.

description:
A little pleasant area that'll give you a tiny insight into the Japanese culture.

got time to kill and looking for a spot to spend 2-3 hours?  Come down for a visit!

There are a good amount of venues offered at Japantown.  come here to learn the history (there's a little underground theater), eat some good food, and/or walk around long enough to see some uniquely dressed people.

the tough review:
-can get crowded, people pushing through you to get to where they need to
-it's not the full japanese experience (but hey what do you expect)
-food can be sub-par
-organization/layout of stores can be a bit frustrating
-buildings feel a bit out-dated

the good review:
-variety of foods, decent service at most restaurants.  
-closest thing you can get to a walking japanese experience.
-a LOT bigger than san jose japantown
-kinokuniya bookstore (another one in sj).  it's not easy finding a japanese bookstore around the bay area.

recommendations:
-street parking is possible.  don't forget this, it's most definitely possible.
-mochi-lovers hit up benkyoudo
-curry on the bridge!
-kinokuniya bookstore
-ichibankan for cheap goodies
-a small goody store that has several handy japanese household goods
author: Chip H.

description:
Ah, my old stomping grounds.

Here you can walk by a crowd of Cosplayers, go to New People and try on Lolita clothing straight from Japan; buy videos, collectibles, makeup, and traditional sweets. 

You can go take silly photos with your friends at Pika Pika, or go next door to the Kinokuniya bookstore to browse the most recent fashion and design magazines while eating a crepe from the shop just outside. 

Just downstairs  you can browse tons of cute stickers and stationary items, or peruse through old-fashioned home decorations. Grab a snack from Mitsuwa or get some fake eyelashes for a buck at Daiso. If you're more hungry than peckish, you can get a huge bowl of ramen and eat while watching some classic anime at On The Bridge.

Great place to spend the day!
author: Veggie C.

description:
We dropped into Jtown for lunch yesterday.  Walked from one end of the enclosed mall to the other, and saw bustling lunch crowds at all the restaurants.  

We were pleasantly surprised at the queues of folks waiting to get a table. Hope it carries over into the following months.  Now if only if the crowds could overflowed onto Buchanan Street, that'd be even better; but some stores were closed due to the holiday.

Two stores drawing in crowds are the stores Daiso and Ichiban Kan.  Most items are $1.50 if no price tag.   Kitchen and household items for everyone, and knick knacks.
author: Shirley N.

description:
I don't come here for the restaurants, oh no. You might as well call them Chinese restaurants. I come here for the ambiance; an escape to another part of the world. Although it's been declining, I hope and pray it gets rejuvenated. This is a San Francisco landmark that needs to be saved. There are a lot of redeeming qualities about this place and part of that is the allure and experiencing another culture. 

Visiting here gives me a sense of peace and a feeling of belonging. I notice the little details that are uniquely Japanese. I love the smell of crepes coming from Sophie's Crepe and the aromatic incense emanating from the bridge. And if you like to people watch, this is the place.
author: John G.

description:
I LOVE Japantown... Has potential to be such an awesome center with the right remodel and new tanants.

I love strolling through the shops and restaurant mall. Always a fun time
author: Andrew V.

description:
How does one complain about Japantown?  Yea, one does not.

It's a cute area. There's a pika pika to take super cute fobby pictures which I love doing occasionally.  The obviously Japanese restaurants + Anderson's + a cupcake store now? I haven't really walk around in a while unless I'm looking for pika pika (I know, I'm obsessed) but it's still the same. I want to try Benihana but I know it's expensive so maybe another day when I save up. There's a parking garage right under the area unless you want to do some street parking, I think it's meters? Either way, it's a great place to go!

And they decorate it in the holidays and it's pretty nice as well :)
author: Lisa L.

description: I love the Japanese culture, the food, the people and their whole ideology. It's a very small area with food, shops and of course the Kabuki Movie theater. It's a clean safe area where you can relax and wander. There is two adjoining baby malls to go to to get Sushi or Ramen everyone is polite with manners and it's just a chill place to go for a few hours. I attempted to go to the Ramen Festival last year and it was toooooo crowded so I dashed into my favorite market and picked up some already made sushi and ubered out with my futomaki in tow. This place is a must also see all your movies here!!!!
author: Cecilia D.

description:
This is more for the central Japantown area with the mall/restaurants.

You won't miss the pagoda and when you get to that, you have arrived.
It doesn't look like much but when you explore the area, there's a fair number of shops and restaurants around.

Many of the shops are very "Japanese" in their wares, which is of no surprise here. Cute things and things you don't need can easily be found here.

Restaurants are poor. This is not the place to come for great Japanese food, it's a bit like Chinatown having mediocre Chinese food, the same can be said for Japantown.

Cherry blossom festival can be pretty and small.

Parking when no major events are on is not too bad considering this is SF.
If something big is going down, good luck finding a spot.
author: Nick L.

description: I can never get bored of coming here. This feels just like, 2nd home to me. The food, the shops, the company, the atmosphere is just simply perfect. If you've been to Japan and feeling a little trip back. I would recommend you to come over here. I recommend you check out the crepe's!
author: Johnny Y.

description: Japantown is to San Francisco as Little Tokyo is to Los Angeles. Yeah it's a tourist trap, but it's a nice place to hang out for a little while. One thing to note is that you have to pay (at a machine or the cashier) before leaving the lot. They are NOT at the gates, so I had to park by the exits, get out, and pay for my parking. King of a pain but such is life,
author: Patrick M.

description:
Japantown is great, though this is for the neighborhood and not just the Japan Center and Buchanan Way.

Japantown has experienced great discourse though the WWII internment and urban renewal that changed the dynamic of the neighborhood.  A once vibrant ethnic enclave, the character has slowly been suffering through both gentrification as well as a changing demographic in local population - with more seniors and foreign students and less families. This means that discount stores like Daiso are doing great, but are replacing craft shops that specialize in kitchen-ware or paper products.

Food here is excellent, as expected, and the place is a cultural center for the community still - with an additional hip scene attributed to the Kabuki theater.

One of the remaining 3 Japantown's in the United States (other is San Jose and Los Angeles).

Learn your history.
author: Jason S.

description:
When I was younger and my parents brought me here, I thought I was in a whole 'nother land.  I was so amazed and engaged in every little corner.  They have many types of restaurants, shops, stores, and everything else.  It is just such a fun place.  Giving this place 5 stars would be me lying and saying that this place can't use any upgrades -- because it really can.  Some parts already looked a bit renovated, but others look too 'rough around the edges'.  But renovation or not, I will still continue to come back here again and again.

I would tell you where to eat, stores to visit, and etc while here ... but I realized that that list would be REALLY long ;X.  So visit everything there!  ;P
author: Pia V.

description:
I love Japantown... for the food. Being the glutton that I am, I find myself wandering over to J-Town when my stomach (named Lucifer) starts growling. I love the variety of restaurants and shops available and even the sticky picture machine store! :)

Parking can be slightly expensive so try to remember to get your parking validated!
author: Vicky L.

description: A great redeeming quality of Japantown is the amount of faires and festivals it holds for the Asian community. There's the Nihonmachi Street Faire, Cherry Blossom Festival, and a Hawaiian one I can never remember the name of. Obviously, there are plenty of good restaurants here too, but they are darn expensive, and parking is a giant hassle. I recommend circling to the outer Pac Heights neighborhoods and walking the quick 10-15 minutes over if you're not in a hurry. There are some cool book stores and funky random sundry stores here. You will definitely find authentic Japanese fare here, but you will pay through your teeth for it. Japantown itself isn't large at all, so you can easily peruse the whole area within half a day.
author: Danny C.

description:
Girls (or boys) at Japantown are very international these days.
Girls (and boys) at Japantown don't have to be Japanese.
Japantown isn't so isolated anymore.
That is good thing.
I'd like to sing for it.

Uptown girl

author: Nobu K.

description: the parking garage is only $1...where can you get that kind of garage parking deal? and in SAN FRAN nonetheless?  Very convenient plaza to shop at...excellent dining options and gives you the feeling that you are actually visiting Japan!
author: Christina K.

description: Japantown is a total misnomer. The entire business area is owned by Koreans and their stores are all over the area. The only places I like are the Nijiya and Super Mira grocery stores and Kinokuniya bookstore which are among the few genuinely Japanese venues still left there. The Daiso and Ichi-ban-kan $1.50 stores are OK, but not as good as they used to be. Nearly all of their wares are from China. All of the wonderful Japanese art studios are long gone, as are all of the great Japanese homestyle restaurants. Most of the cooks now are not Japanese and the expensive food in small portions isn't anywhere as good as it was years ago. Some of it is just plain awful. Impossible street parking, but there is an adjacent garage. If you're expecting something like lively Little Tokyo in Los Angeles, you'll be totally disappointed by dull Japantown in San Francisco. It has zero Japanese ambience.
author: Pam J.

description: Japantown is calming, open, and clean, compared to the hustle and bustle of Chinatown. While there's lots of azn stores and restaurants in the Japan center mall, they all offer the same things. Most of the restaurants all serve noodles, combo dishes, sushi, okonomiyaki (yum), and teppanyaki kind of food. There's also some Korean restaurants, and cute little cafes. There's also a little mochi souvenir store that we saw inside Japan center, which looked bomb diggiittyyy. They also have an azn photobooth store, Daiso, a bookstore, stationary stores, crepe place, and more. Japantown was definitely one of the highlights of San Francisco!
author: Tricia M.

description:
SUPER INTERESTING!

I am a tourist and being in Japan town made me feel like being in Japan. I have only seen movies and pictures of Japan and I guess this is the closest i'd get. Funny thing, because like Japan, everything is so close together.

Amazing experience. Don't forget to get your batch of green tea kit kats :D
author: Ezra G.

description:
Japantown is a fantastic mix of authentic Japanese shops and restaurants, as well as a few off the wall joints. You can find bookstores, crepe shops, bakeries, sushi/noodle restaurants, florists, grocery stores, discount shops and even some medical shops. 

Just a few of the fun establishments you an check out....
 Belly Good Cafe & Crepes 
 Benihana 
 Ichiban 
 Katsura Garden 
 Mifune 
 Nijiya Market 
 On The Bridge 
 Paper Tree 
 Sapporo-Ya 
 Seoul Garden
 Sophie's Crepes
 Takara Restaurant 

Overall...Japantown is great for shopping, dining and people watching. Make to get a  crepe when you're there...you'll thank me!
author: Dru M.

description:
Taking a stroll to Japantown after the ferry building.  Seems like a great plan right?  Take a taxi...trust me it's faster.  Especially when you don't have a lot of time.

J-Town SF is a very cute, relaxing and nice place.  There is a Nijiya supermarket where you can buy your pocky and Japanese drinks.  There is also a mall with 2 separate entrances; one for the food court and the other one for stores (Kinokuniya bookstore, bakeries, souvenir stores, etc).  The food court was kinda cool..it reminded me of the food court in Tokyo.

J-Town looked small but it was actually pretty big; especially when you took a relaxing walk.  There was a Buddhist temple there too.  I really enjoyed being there and actually took my time enjoying the view of the streets.  

Japantown is fun fun fun!!!
author: Maggie C.

description:
This is one of the places where you can find interesting things to see and enjoy some entertainment especially on the weekend. This coming weekend - July 28 and 29 - there's going to be a JPop festival.  What I like are the small shops at Japantown where you can find interesting stuff to look at.

My top picks on my first visit at Japantown:

May's coffee shop - taiyaki (fish-shaped waffles filled with red bean, chocolate or chocolate banana filling) that are only for $2.
Ichiban Kan and Daiso - a deadly combination for all your necessities in your personal and work life. Most items are $1.50 or more.
Nippon-Ya - a shop that sells Japanese sweets directly from Japan. Every item manufactures from different sweet shops in Japan. Unique find and great for gift giving.
JTown Collectibles - a store that sells collectible 1/100 models especially Tamiya automobiles and other transportation models. Gundam, Bandai, trading cards and other fun stuff.
SOHO Hardware - Unique store that sells everything from the garden, kitchen and the house.
Other boutiques are worth the trip too.
author: Jade M.

description: Japantown is pretty small with a few shops to browse and some restaurants. Not a lot to it and it's not very exciting.
author: Bumble B.

description:
Fun Fun Fun. Cute Cute Cute. Yum Yum Yum. Pretty Pretty Pretty. WTF is that thing supposed to do?  Oh I totally need a little thingie with a smiley face that ties my left shoe.

I Heart Japan Town.
author: Susan C.

description:
Not giving it 5 stars only because no restaurants were open at 8am EXCEPT this Korean one! LAME. 

So bf and I were walking around when it was completely dead and no life over there. 

But it was pretty cool. Tons of restaurants to choose from..and definitely had that Japan feel to it.
author: Ayumi S.

description:
Grew up in this place. Love this place to death. Keep this place alive!

Cherry blossom, Nihonmachi Street Fair, food courts, etc. This place is my kingdom!
author: Tim M.

description: Havent hung out around at this place for a long. Decided to come here since there was cherry blossom festival which usually comes one a year, every april. and Of it was definitely busy whenever this festival comes around. Other than that, this mall has a few stores to shop at and plenty of restaurants to eat as well (of course this mall consists mainly japanese restaurants/stores and very few places that are non-japanese). Although its not my type of mall that i usually go to, its still good to visit once in a while if you want to hang out with your friends or family.
author: Julie N.

description: If you have Asian relatives, take them here.  They will love it.  Take a photo in front of the pagoda, let them shop in Daiso, eat a bento or ramen lunch special, and go to the dessert store and Hello Kitty shop.  That's about it.
author: Chris L.

description:
This area is great for anyone and everyone. Shops along Fillmore, a multiplex theater for moviegoers, food establishments along Post, Fillmore & within the malls, and various shops in and outside of the malls. From the Peace Pagoda to the Cherry Blossom Festival each April, Japantown has something for everyone year round. 

This neighborhood is touristy yet often overlooked as compared to other places such as downtown, Chinatown, SOMA, or even the Mission District. This area has a few parking garages & 2-hour zones, but taking MUNI here is a better bet during the daytime, which is maybe why there aren't too many tourists here.

Overall, a great place to take tourists of all ages. Go to Japantown, learn some new culture, and buy some new things that you normally wouldn't see in stores from the local shops!
author: Rob L.

description:
I come here ever so often when I was a little kid. Often to come eat the sushi. It cools how they have a little "town" where you can learn about the Japanese culture and enjoy some of the dining and shopping they offer. They offer many restaurants with authentic Japanese cuisine (Sushi boat, udon, ramen and etc) The have grocery stores filled with products from Japan. They also have bookstores that's filled with cute stationary products!

This is a great tourist attraction for people to come visit and experience the Japanese culture. They have a parking garage for your convenience (slightly cheaper than your downtown SF prices) They have street metered parking. Every year in April they host the "Cherry Blossom Festival" Something you might wanna check out if your in the area. It's a street festival with music and food vendors. Definitely worth it!
author: Jennifer W.

description:
Does that make me a bad Taiwanese because I prefer to go to Japantown instead of Chinatown? 

TBH. San Fran's Chinatown has evolved into an uber touristy locale with mediocre and over-priced Cantonese food. If you really want good Chinese food, drive an hour south to the South Bay (408 Represent!). That's where the good Chinese food is. Not in San Fran.

Back to Japantown, I love it because it isn't what Chinatown is:
- it doesn't smell like rotting garbage and week-old human feces 
- There isn't bird sh!t covering every square inch of the block
- Plenty of parking in the underground garage or park nearby at the local supermarket
- Cool Japanese toy shops and bookstores to get your otaku on!
- Playground, the uber karaoke bar, is in Japantown 
- at least five Japanese restaurants ranging from ramen shops, sushi bars, to teppanyaki bars. 
- It's indoors!

It's too bad that Japantown effectively covers about two city blocks, but they pack so much into that small area that you could really spend half a day easily and not have explored all there is to see. It's also in a great part of San Fran, right by Nob Hill and Pacific Heights.
author: Will C.

description:
5 stars for nostalgia and for simply still being there.

This Japantown, Little Tokyo, or whatever you want to call it makes the one in downtown LA look non-existent.  Wait, it basically is non-existent.  That's not saying much though.  This one seems to have been taken a hit over the years.

Don't let this one die out folks.  I know there aren't many of "us" around.  So do what you can to keep hope alive!  

http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/V_C-9jFxwxyyZk3HcMLApw?select=ZMCgUTKbdXe6K9Pyc2TviA
http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/V_C-9jFxwxyyZk3HcMLApw?select=rqlCbBJxE9zHAddIw4GDgg
http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/V_C-9jFxwxyyZk3HcMLApw?select=RTqxMBhJL-ohvS_uc8UDNg

Walking through the shops and eateries made me yearn for the days of wandering around Japan aimlessly window shopping.  There were a number of vacant spaces.  I really hope that this J-Town doesn't come across the same fate the one in LA is going through.

http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/V_C-9jFxwxyyZk3HcMLApw?select=kojG7_HjJ5TKabqgPQiUtg
http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/V_C-9jFxwxyyZk3HcMLApw?select=jKcJSFAKB9RzGYAi62vgFg

I'm holding on to my memories of the old J-Town with a death clutch.  SF Japantown is but a mere shell of what it was when my parents would bring me here as wee little lad (they have pictures to prove it).  Still, anytime I can get my fill of "nihonjin-ness", albeit watered down, I'm more than happy to take it all in.

BANZAI!!!  
BANZAI!!!
BANZAIIIIIIIIIII!!!!
author: Eugine Y.

description:
A gem of San Francisco! Whenever I'm in the bay, I'm always very impressed by the selection of stores and feel of this community. ALSO, there are PURIKURA machines! Where else can one create cutesy japanese stickers with the faces of them and their friends together? Ah, my furniture is covered in these!
Also, I always check out Daiso, which has a wide range of hip, japanese items for $1.50 or less, including oBento boxes, iPhone chargers, fuzzy kawaii socks, or toilet seat covers. Whether you're a local, or a tourist, you'll find something in this mall.
author: Anne S.

description: Amazing place to hangout and have fun at with anyone! Great stores and food to eat! Try out everything in the malls especially Daiso Japan!
author: Jesse M.

description: Used to live here. Love the neighborhood for its cinema, plaza, and choices in restaurants, karaoke, and shopping!
author: Rich M.

description: It was nice and quiet when I walked there from a friend's condo.  There's not much around really.  There's still a peace Pagoda that stands out.
author: Trynh K.

description:
I happened to come when the cherry blossoms had just started blooming. Japantown's plaza is very interesting, with awesome Japanese touches all over, even embedded into the ground. You have to love the tower and that it can be seen from other parts of the city. 

The plaza itself, a large group of stores with Japanese accents, themes, and products. It's fun to stroll down the halls and window shop, eat some grub, and purchase accessories. The feel is pretty authentic.
author: Jess L.

description: If you're visiting San Francisco, I highly recommend making Japantown your base.  My boyfriend and I spent a long weekend here recently, in town solely to eat at some of the best places the city has to offer.  We rented a car, but only used it once to visit friends in Livermore. With the Hotel Tomo as our choice of lodging for three nights, we hoofed it around the city from there, trying to offset all the calories we were consuming on our weekend of eating.  Our location was perfect as there are several great restaurants and bakeries only a few blocks in either direction as well as right across the street.  Most of the other destinations were only an average of 2 miles away on foot (Chinatown, Mission district, the Ferry Building).  The gym that we're members of was only half a mile away.  We went to mass at St. Dominic's, which was two blocks down the street. We went to the movies at an AMC that was less than a mile away.  Cronuts at Fillmore Bakeshop was two blocks away. Millionaire's Bacon was had at Sweet Maple around the corner.  You get the picture.  I think the furthest we walked was to get ice cream at Bi-Rite Creamery, almost three miles away.  But, we lucked out with wonderful weather and never saw fog once.  What's nice about Japantown is that it's quiet and laid-back.  I've stayed in Union Square as well as near the Embarcadero and those locations have their advantages, too, but J-Town is just your nice, friendly neighborhood with not a lot of people, noise, or traffic.  Consider it if you're planning a trip and don't mind walking around the city; it's the best way to experience it, IMHO.
author: Terri C.

description:
Great place for a gathering for friends to get together and mess around.

It's all neat and clean it just makes you want to mess it up and buy porn.

But for all seriousness, don't mess the place up. Just go to the video stores and buy all the porn off of them. You'll love it. Really =D

If you need a place to play cards, this is also a great place to go since there is a lot of space when the card shop further away is closed for the day. There is also a sword club. Although it's full of older guys over the age of 30, I don't care. I learn more about swords from them than I would from any other place outside of Japan. That is also a plus to go. But applies only for the 3rd Sunday of each month.

Not many places to eat, but still someplace to go if you have no better place to mess around town. Especially for Japanese and Asian Porn that isn't boot legged.
author: Jacen W.

description:
Great place to visit even if you are not an anime fanatic. Easy to find and its almost impossible to get lost, the only thing SLIGHTLY tricky was their parking system but we figured it out pretty quick.
LOVE all the shops and boutiques even though some are extremely expensive, although places like Daiso make up for it!
author: Xjuxnkgd Z.

description: Loved how clean the area is.  LOTS of fun shops for Anime and other Japanese goods.  Sweet people everywhere.  What a great experience to have in SF.
author: Julie S.

description: Went for J-Pop festival. The food is great at most of the restaurants and I love the Nijiya Market and Daiso here.
author: Kajal G.

description: Great place to walk around, check out the bonzai, wonderful spots to eat and drink. Great Japanese curios and other items. Definitely come see and spend time.
author: Brinda J.

description:
One of San Franciscos best Landmarks in my opinion. It doesn't sport a gigantic mall like atmosphere or any major store that downtown would have, but it does contain magnificent restaurants and little shops.

The plaza itself is amazing. How often will you see a tower where during the course of the year events such as the Cherry Blossom festival occur and have this place packed with performances and people. The enviornment here a relaxing one, a place to get some lunch or dinner or even dessert. 

There's a lot of Japanese restaurants, my favorite being Mifune, but if you prefer trickery and appearance over taste there's Benihana. For dessert there's cupcakes and Belly Good Crepes! Also there's a Hello Kitty store and other little Jewlery spots and also the bookstore. Don't forget the fact that Kabuki Theaters is also here which in my opinion is a very good theater. 

Lastly, if your driving, parking is super cheap. I believe is still around $2 if I'm not mistaken ab hour. Definitely a steal in San Francisco.
author: Jesus A.

description:
The boyfriend took me here over the weekend and it was my first time going to Japantown. We were so lucky to have great weather (after it rained super heavily Saturday morning!) so we got a chance to take some "touristy" pictures too. We walked around the East Mall and West Mall -- lots of cute Japanese restaurants, a giant Daiso, and other stories (for accessories, bookstores, etc.). It's also very pretty outside, great for taking pictures and walking around. There were lots of families and couples there. I think it's a great place for a date! :)

I would definitely love to go back during the spring time because I'm sure it'd be super beautiful then.
author: Stephanie S.

description: My wife and I had our first ever date in Japantown, so it will always hold a special place in our hearts.  Great things to browse, and some good food to be eaten.  Things are a bit pricey, but there are so many great things to be found here.  Gotta get back soon.
author: Christopher L.

description: My favorite place in san francisco!  Its never to crowded,  they have amazing stores and out of this world food!!!!!
author: Taylor C.

description: This is one of my favorite places to go in the entire world. I have been here at least 100 times, maybe more. So, why the four star review? When I was there just a few weeks ago, there were 6 different empty stores in the mall. This is disappointing, and slightly depressing. Japantown hasn't had this many empty stores since 2006. I seriously hope that they find new tenants to fill those spaces. Most of the stores that closed, were places that I regularly shopped. Including a Sanrio store with an amazing Badtz Maru collection. And, a clothing and toy store, where I got all of my cool Anime shirts. The more stores that close, the less that people are going to want to patronize the mall. Most of the stuff that you can buy in Japantown is much cheaper on Amazon, but I like paying a little extra for the experience, and to make a memory. Window shoppers, and people watchers will get a kick out of this place. If you are a 3DS owner, this is a great place for street passes. I always see 3 or 4 people hanging out, and playing games. Some of my personal recommendations are the bookstore (Japanese CDs for $3!), Pika Pika (Purikura), Daiso (Japanese Dollar store), Ichiban Kan (my favorite store of all time), and any of the 3 Mifune restaurants for a cheap and delicious lunch.
author: Paul T.

description:
Although I think it has gone down (a lot) over the years, this place is still a solid place to step into a faux-Japan.  Surrounded by Japanese restaurants, a few Korean (similar in Japan where there are a few Yakiniku joints littered among the others), Kinokuniya (a chain Japanese bookstore), a Japanese hardware store and a couple Japanese markets and my fave the Hyakuen-shop aka Daiso aka $1.50 store.

For the Japanese living in the states this place can be a little natsukashii while for others this could be a little educational or cultural journey.  It was sad to see that the Japanese restaurant that we chose to dine at (around 3pm - a lot of others were closed) was owned by an Asian family not of Japanese decent, but oh well, times have changed that is for sure.
author: Shiho F.

description:
I forget how much I enjoyed J-Town as a kid and even now as a grown woman; from their yearly Cherry Blossom Festivals, their gift shops and the many restaurants they have to offer.

You have something for everyone in your family; foodpornographers, animewhores and so much more.. I LOVE the diversity of folks around the area; neighborhood friendlies and plenty of tourist folks flocking to check out what Japan Town has to offer them. 

They have a parking garage, with actual decent fees, surprisingly for San Francisco and even street parking if you're lucky.
author: Anonymous P.

description: Japantown we had a lot of fun here.  The location was easy to get to from the hotel Carlton. There is nothing like Japantown in Pittsburgh, Pa which made visiting this neighborhood a must see.  The mall was great and the everyone was having a good time at the Japanese heritage festival that we attended.  The neighborhood appears to be well taken care of and has great shops like one of the biggest, greatest Goodwill I have ever had the pleasure of shopping in. I would certainly come back here again perhaps to try one of the many sushi restaurants that we walked by. One thing I found delightfully peculiar was that all the restaurants had faux food dishes in the windows on display.  I have never seen anything like it.  Think how subway has the fake hoagie on display. Yes like that you remember the fake food we use to play with children it was so wild I loved those displays and appeared that all the restaurants did this too.
author: Lucretiz C.

description: I love this place! Super clean, great food and even better bookstores. You can just chill here all day and have a great time.
author: Mark A.

description: Food, shopping, arcade, purikura, bookstore, so many things to do here!! I will never get bored of Japantown =D A must visit for tourists and a great place to hang for locals.
author: Sam F.

description: I love going to Japantown, it's just one of those places that will always put a smile on my face. It's enough of a tourist area too that it's extremely fun to people watch.
author: David C.

description:
Japantown is the perfect place for SHOPPING!!! There are a variety of stores here that just about covers everyone's hobbies/interests. There is of course a Sanrio store, a car accessory shop, a two-story bookstore, and anime/specialty shops here! Some places are overpriced but that should be expected since Japantown is another tourist hotspot. I was honestly disappointed with the lack of music stores here. One of the ones I went to advertised some of my favorite Japanese artists in the window, but when I went inside to look for their albums, they did not carry them! 
There a few dining options to choose from if you ever get hungry while shopping here. You have some of your "fast food" type places and your traditional sit-in restaurants. Some of the restaurants I've been to are decently priced with delicious food and good service. They also have dessert places here! They have Andersen bakery, a cupcake shop, and frozen yogurt just to name the couple that I could think of at the top of my head. Simply delicious!
