My only real complaint would be for this years Cherry Blossom Festival. Although the weather was rainy/muggy outside, it was hot & humid inside of the mall! It felt like a very unpleasant swamp since they apparently don't have any air conditioning, or at least it wasn't working that particular day that I went.

Other than that, I highly recommend this place to everyone. It's a great place to shop, hang out with friend, and just indulge in Japanese culture.
author: Paulamertha A.

description:
I travel to this part of Frisco quite often, for one obvious reason. I'm in LOVE with all things Japanese. I have been infatuated with the culture, the island, the music, the anime, and more since I was but a little kid. This place has become close to a second home to me, I never expected to be so taken with anything in my life.

From the food to the shopping, from the sword shop to the anime store (where I used to get most of my anime from), from the car shop to the bookstore in the next building... This place has anything you'd ever need in terms of Japanese culture and cuisine. 

But more than just that, the atmosphere and the people who go here. Makes it the most comfortable place to just relax with a crepe in one hand and a beer in the other. I always have an amazing time here, where be it by myself or with my friends. I'm quite sure you will as well.

Oh, and if you're ever here on a weekend... Look me up, I'll probably be sitting down just outside Sophie's Crepe Shop, chowing down on a delicious crepe. Or in one of my favorite and inexpensive restaurants, Mifune. I'll always be welcome to some new company, so say hi and start up a conversation. It's sure to be a grand time around!!
author: Troy L.

description: San Francisco is known for mild year round weather, Fisherman's Warf, Golden Gate Bridge, and Alcatraz. Most people fail to check out Japantown. Although Japantown isn't that large, the space is well used. Like a Japanese home, it is small and simple with a clear sense of contentment. Cherry blossoms, yakiniku, ramen, Hello Kitty, and everything anime. After enjoying a teriyaki burger and the latest issue of Gothic and Lolita Bible magazine, you can get your hair styled like Gackt all in one day. Saiko da.
author: Pari P.

description: Japatown isn't quite the same size as Chinatown but its packed with stores and restaurants that are also packed with a variety of things. I always enjoy my visits here. They always have activities going on as ewll. Some are better than others but great little area
author: Tao Tao W.

description:
Dear Japan Town,

 I'm so glad that you're feeling better. I know that the last few years you weren't feeling alright since there was a ton of vacancies in your buildings.  But I think that things are looking up for you, especially since there's been a ton of new stores and a good amount of restaurants.  I mean, who would of thought of a great place to find specific items that other Asian Markets wouldn't sell?  Do you need a masubi mold?  Japan Town has it!  What about all the anime that you used to grow up watching?  Guess who has it all? JAPAN TOWN! 

I've been visiting you since I was in middle school and can definitely see the different from what you were back then and what you are now,.  You have grown up to be a very beautiful place to visit with the most relaxing scenery.  

I'm very proud of you and will be looking forward to visiting you again in the future.

Always,
LK
author: Lea M.

description:
If you go for the historical trip, go ahead-might interest you... Perhaps the food is better than my shopping experience. 
No Sanrio, tiny ichiban kan.... Crowded daiso.... And the little boutiques, waayyyyyyyyy overpriced!  I wanted to buy a crepe in this crowded crepe place inside japantown, guess what, cash only! I had no cash, too bab for me.... I only had 3 drls , so I decided to buy a thai tea... Bad decision! It tasted like soapy water ... I wanted to throw up.. Seriously....I've had bad thai teas but I really don't know what they put on this one! 
 I would ve loved to save my time AND money
author: Liz B.

description:
Unless you want Japanese books and you don't know how to just buy them on the Internet, don't even visit Japantown. I am a bit of a Japanophile, having lived there a while. I was stoked to visit this place, but... yeah, I didn't care for it. There is a large San Rio store some people may like, but there isn't even much of a market to speak of. Only ate at one restaurant, and it was awful. Even the Daiso, which is much like a "hundred yen store" in Japan, isn't very good. Don't go there thinking you'll get to practice Japanese language skills either because most people are tourists speaking English or Chinese. I guess actual Nihonjin know of better places to be. 

One last remark if anyone happens to be San Diegan or visiting there... check out the several Japanese markets around Kearny Mesa neighborhood. They're spread and mixed among Korean and other ethnic businesses, but far superior to SF Jtown. Not Japan, but much closer than this tourist trap!
author: Kate H.

description: I have been coming to Japantown for many years.  I have a friend that used to live in the Richmond and one that lives in downtown so naturally this would be a stop for us along the way between places.  Japantown has some great bars and restaurants that can be visited and if that certain level of drunkenness hits you, there is plenty of karaoke.  I know that all sorts of events happen in Japantown but sadly I have never been to any of them.  I will have to try and make it to this years Cherry Blossom Festival.  I would say that if you are in SF and looking for something to do, you can't go wrong by checking out Japantown.
author: Mark S.

description:
My Mother grew up here, as did her Mother. Being 1/2 Japanese American,  I embrace the Japantown of my childhood and the Japantown of today as a significant part of my heritage. 

As a kid, I would save my allowance $$$ and my Mom would drive me down Geary Street  here in her Ford Torino to Goshado so I could buy more Ultraman comic books and figurines. 
Now, when my work overlaps the weekends in SF,  my spouse and I live part of the month at the Hotel Kabuki, formerly the Miyako Hotel.

Neighborhoods are all about change. Before erroneously assuming that J-Town is ONLY ABOUT shops and restaurants, one needs to seriously contemplate and think back, 100+ years ago. As with any section of the City, there really is more, so much more to realize. This was once a place where those in this country, who were of Japanese origin, were allowed to settle, but not own land immediately,  and where they subsequently lived, worked, and died for generations. The immigrants from Japan who came to SF and founded this area over a century ago pretty much set the stage for what exists today.

It is a Metaphor For Life to say that  "There is Always So Much More To Learn."  Try doing a google.com search for the 442nd regiment of WWII or, better yet, pay a visit to the National Japanese American Historical Society of SF: http://www.yelp.com/biz/national-japanese-american-historical-society-san-francisco#hrid:RQgqkT5lHKgyWDGCtDYURQ/query:japanese%20american

Kampai!!!
author: Richard T.

description: NYC does not have an official Japan town so I think it is awesome! We have Mitsuwa Plaza in Jersey and The East Village which used to be largely Japanese but nothing official. I love San Fransisco and Japanese culture so it is a winner for me!
author: Pinky And The B.

description: When I lived here in San Francisco my girlfriend at the time introduced me to sushi here in Japantown. Some of the best food I've ever had, this is a must if you are visiting San Francisco.
author: Luis-armando A.

description:
I enjoy visiting J-town whenever I am in the Bay area.
A good selection of restaurants and grocery stores.  Manga and anime shops, tea parlours and local landmarks.

Don't miss it!
author: Karen F.

description:
One of the best places to visit especially if you're particularly a tourist. You have to visit during the cherry blossom festival. it attracts huge crowds and parking sucks, but it is def. worth it. 

Great food, awesome entertainment, and oh, great food! I love going to benihana but it gets played out after the first two times. then there is the sushi boat place inside the plaza.

they use to have a AMC theatre here too but now its one of those more expensive theatres that play underground movies that are pretty good too.

They also have the urban Fatlace store there that is always a go-to for the fixie heads and the car heads. 

Lastly, hit up the japanese market they have there on the corner of post and webster. they have some fresh cuts of fish thats perfect for slicing up your own pieces of sashimi at home or in the hotel, just make sure you keep that fish cold as ice.
author: Kenny L.

description:
Japantown has definitely seen its share of ups and downs, in attempting to attract more tourists and regulars to the Japanese culture, foods, and retail therapy...I've been coming here since I was a tiny chubby with pigtails and striped stockings.  After my weekly piano lessons at the conservatory, we would always make the habitual stop here to stock up on food supplies, new books at Kinokuniya for my mum and manga for my little sister and myself, and the family dinner of udon and nabeyaki at Mifune.

As a child, nothing is boring.  Everything is new and fresh, especially since I remember pressing my hands against the glass display to look at the colorful and fruit decorated cakes at Marie Antoinette.  Or running through the Sanrio store with handfuls of their pretty pink pens: Hello Kitty characters perched on top, holding on for dear life.  Or the Batzmaru stuffed doll, brooding (it is currently sitting on top of my computer screen) reminding me of bad Mondays.  Most of those trinkets built from childhood fancies have found their way into goody bags for local charities and Children's homes now.  As I have gotten older, it has been thrown into the bag labeled Galakuta, or just a bunch of things gathering dust and taking up space.

Mifune is still there, a concrete nod to the past, with their hot udon dishes.  Benihana is also there, catering to the tourists with chefs brandishing flourishes of their knives and grilling skills (never mind the shrimp that landed in my lap once for humor).  Sapporo-Ya, tucked in the corner across from Kinokuniya is also aging well with their ramen and yakisoba dishes, despite our retraction of patronizing the place after a rude waiter demanded that we leave tip (Native Japanese don't leave tip) so it was a wrong assumption on his part.

Most of the other stores have faded out, as ownership of this mall has changed hands.  The outside pond that use to store treasured Koi fish was filled in with concrete due to vandalism and theft (how low can some people get) and the pagoda a sad remnant of the vigorous and prosperous 80's for the Japanese electronics boom, and now, a lone standing monument casting a long shadow across the vacant courtyard, where large pillars once stood guard, now removed.  

But as I walked along the cobble stoned area between the mall, I realized that Japantown was and will always be that small yet happy memories of my childhood: spent with family, spent as a child, playing hide-n-seek between the supporting legs of the pagoda.

A must for all visitors and tourists.  For me, a place of quiet reminiscing.
author: Miika M.

description:
Japantown has changed. It is still Japanese but gone are the bygone era of "pearl" sellers. The food court has even changed. Some of the old favorites are there like the kimono seller. 

I love the grocery markets, household & dishware stores and good ole Kinokuniya bookstore. There are a variety of restaurants to try. I really wish there was more to tell you about the history of the large and vibrant Japanese community that lived in the Fillmore here at the center. 

I will continue to support the mall.
author: Infodiva B.

description: Tranquility is the word to describe Japantown. It's so calm here. I come here for the different festivities such as The Cherry Blossom Festival or when there are Anime characters running around. The snacks here are delicious and the people are quite polite with their soft voices.
author: Anji W.

description: I really love Japantown because they sell so many cute merchandise,but most of the things that I liked was so expensive.It was fun seeing everything that I liked,like squishies,plushies,stickers,and stuff like that.I think you should go here if you love all the things that I love!!!
author: Carly N.

description:
Japantown is pretty awesome! There are a ton of yummy restaurants, a nice movie theater, and lots of shopping to be had! You can feel free to let go and envelop yourself in the Asianess that is Japantown and squeal over cute hello kitty candies, thumb through mangas, buy a teapot, feel a kimono, and stare at tons and tons of Asians and tourists.

Some of the places in here are tourist traps and way expensive *cough isobune and benihana). There are a bunch of cute little shops here and a kinokuniya, hurray! 

They also hold some pretty awesome events here, if you're lucky to be in the area and check them out. The cherry blossoms are beautiful when they are in season :) 

This place is very Japanese. Duh!
author: Grace Y.

description: The layout is nice, food all clustered in one section, and shopping + daiso on another... the entirety feels so cramped though!  Wish it were bigger.  I guess they do a good job of maximizing the space they have, however.  Nice food court/ coffee place, it's chill.  Christmas decorations are pretty nice, catch the paper cranes on the xmas tree if you're there for the holidays.  Ramen galore.  RAMEN.
author: Christina G.

description:
Japantown is awesome! I could easily spend a whole day here checking out all the cute shops, eating snacks, watching movies, shopping...this place has it all. 

Some people are a little let down because they think just like Chinatown has loads of Chinese people who live there, speak the language, eat there, shop there, Japantown should be the same. Mmmm this isn't exactly true here. The last big wave of Japanese to the US was a long time ago. So if you happen to see a Japanese person, they probably don't live there and most likely speak fluent english. Don't be the dumb ass that goes up to any random person waving and shouting "Konnichiwa". Please save yourself the embarrassment.

My favorite places are the corner grocery store, the waffle place and the bookstore.
author: Judie H.

description:
Everything is here!! its a nice neighborhood with cool shops and eateries. you can have an awesome crepe inside the mall or have a great time with some karaoke,food and drinks at Playground. its definitely an awesome place to just walk around and hang out.

the parking is abundant....if everyone died and left their cars at home.... but if you do get lucky on the street then AWESOME for you.. i never get that lucky. there is always the garage or not being lazy and just parking a bit aways and walking and getting your workout on!

i have heard awesome things about this place during the cherry blossom festival but i have yet to go and super excited to see that! i just love coming here and enjoying the atmosphere. its not as chaotic as the rest of the city!
author: Carl T.

description: This local site is smallish, but has an adequate assortment of shops to keep your wallet and interests busy. I still like going to Soko Hardware, for some interesting houseware finds. Asakichi Incense is my go-to place for my buddhist items. Nijiya's is a market I frequent often for my sushi-grade sashimi and other asian staples.  Kinokuniya's is still there if you want to browse into some high-end books and magazines. During the last 15 years, there has been an influx of Korean restaurants too, which comes alive at nighttime. Way cleaner than Chinatown.
author: Derek N.

description: Great place to visit its a definite bucket list for anyone with a shred of interest in the culture. Loads of neat shops with imported novelty items and then some like the authentic kimono and yukata shop. Though be warned like most imported goods they are double the price. Still as an otaku the crepe stand was like omgomgomg moment.
author: Taylor S.

description:
It's pretty dead here, but once a festival hits, this place is jammed packed. I mainly co me here to eat. Mifune for soba, Tanpopo (outside the mall) for ramen and takoyaki, Izumiya for okonomiyaki and spicy tuna handrolls, Isobune for sushi boat, Sophie's Crepes for Japanese crepes, Cafe Hana for the "Green Tea Geisha Float", and Benkyo-do for taiyaki. So many restaurants, too little time!

JONASAPPROVED!
author: Jonas T.

description:
Japantown has been hit by the economy being down. Not only in the same way as most retailers have but by the fact that many of the stores sell imported goods from Japan and the exchange rate the worse in 20 years with the dollar in the toilet. This has forced several stores to close, but in most cases new shops have moved in.

However it remains a good place to shop for a gift for  impossible to buy for persons. After all it is very likely you will find something here that person does not have.

I also always recommend folks take visitors, it is below the radar of most tourists and a pleasant place to walk around.
author: Gilles P.

description:
For my 100th review, I'll choose Japantown San Francisco. 

I really liked -- wait, i mean LOVED -- this place for several reasons:

1. Kyuushuu chashu ramen at Tanpopo
2. 7 days a week karaoke at Festa Karaoke
3. Piano sheet music for Japanese songs and Japanese CDs and magazines at Kinokuniya
4. Pika Pika Store full of purikura machines
5. Korean BBQ and karaoke rooms at Playground
6. Knickknacks at Soko Hardware 
7. Drawing supplies at Ichiban Kan
8. Yummy fruits and Japanese make-up at Nijiya
9. Delicious desserts and pastries at Cafe Hana
10. A lot of the restaurants stay open pretty late
11. Very Japanese cultural atmosphere with the Japanese street signs, entrance gate, origami fountains, and Peace Pagoda
12. I get to practice my limited knowledge of nihongo. 
13. It was across the street from the hotel I stayed at
14. The convenient bus stop (with 3 buslines that stop here)
15. Just the fact that there are 3 Japanese malls in this one spot is like heaven to me. Lol.
author: Julie A.

description: What is it about Japanese culture and Japanese people that is so lovable and huggable?  Is it the explosion of Hello Kitty?  All things tiny and pocket sized?  Is it raw fish?  I can't put my finger on it, but I'm also under its spell.  I love to visit Japantown.  Something about this place makes me feel all warm and fuzzy inside.  Typically, I'll get some $1 items at Ichiban Kan, get a crepe from Sophie's Crepes, stop by the Auto Accessories shop to buy one of those extra-long rear view mirrors for my Honda/Toyota/Nissan/Mitsubishi,  buy some Sanrio pens and post-its and walk around to see the many different types of people who come to this place.  The last time I made a visit, there were a bunch of white people in Dragon Ballz costumes, just hanging around and all I thought was 'Good for you.  Enjoy yourself, in your fun costumes.'  And I bet they did.
author: Gracie A.

description:
Very neat area for the City.

The area is small, but packed with quality shops and restaurants.

There are often mini-street festivals.
author: Ayall S.

description:
A perfect day:

A big bowl of steaming noodles at Mifune or Suzu or Iroha
A walk through Cottage Row
A crepe or two after browsing books at Kinokuniya
A stop for groceries at NIJIYA

All this can be yours too in Japantown.
author: Miriam W.

description:
They call it Japantown.  But Japan it is not.  I agree with Helene K that there's something not right here.

Let me clarify.  I think it's pretty cool that SF has one of the 3 remaining Japantowns in the US, but to me it doesn't really capture the essence of Japan.  They have a bunch of restaurants that serve Japanese food.  (Not all good, though to their credit, the restaurants that are bad are actually bad because they're mediocre Japanese food, they're not bad because they're Americanized Japanese food, except Benihana.)  There's a few stores that serve miscellaneous Japanese doo-dads, and a few grocery stores.

There is one bookstore.  Granted, it's a good one, in fact, Kinokuniya is your one-stop shop for J-Lit. (Is that a term?)  Too bad the US branches of this do not feel like the Japanese stores, they feel like an American retailer that sells Japanese books.  Whatever.  Beggars can't be choosers...or maybe they can.  Book Off, please come to SF!!!

The grocery store triumvirate of Nijiya, Super Mira, and Uoki K. Sakai closes too early and is too expensive and does not hold fun special food tastings.

And finally, the blockage of Starbucks that was supposed to be built on the 1600 Post building was ridiculous.  Japan was Starbucks's first overseas market and now it's ingrained in their culture.  But no, Japantown wouldn't have that and insisted that an empty storefront is so much better. :rolls eyes:

I shouldn't even get started about the mall, but here I go.  That's one of the ugliest, most hideous malls I've ever seen.  3 buildings, two of them are on stilts and are connected by some sort of walkway, the other one's...not connected.  wtf.

Maybe we're just jaded in SF because we have Chinatown, and Japantown is not to Japan what Chinatown is to China.

Or maybe I'm just jaded because I was expecting a slice of Tokyo (or at least Osaka), meaning a bustling centre and a tall buildings all lit up and Karaoke on every floor. (The only Karaoke bars here seem to be Korean! Nothing against Korea, but wtf) In Japantown SF on the other hand we get signs on buildings that say "2F".  That's all fine and dandy, but where's the remaining 6+F??  And everything here closes way too early.  The CD and bookstores in Japan are largely open til midnight.  Or at least past 8.  In Japantown every non-restaurant is closed by 8 (or earlier).  The restaurants, with a few exceptions, close at 9 so they're not that much better.

There are a few things about this place that are truly cool though.

The big death ray-like pagoda structure in Peace Plaza, especially at night.

The kanji, hirakana, and katakana on most of the buildings.

The restaurants, bad or not, which serve mostly homestyle (meaning non-sushi) Japanese food at good prices.

The restaurant clusterfuck in the middle of the mall, which does resemble what you might find in the Tokyo underground.
author: David A.

description:
FOOD!! FOOD FOOD!! Is that all that's here?? Oh yeah overpriced anime shop, over priced hair cuts, overpriced book stores,,,and guess what more food!! It's not even that great really..bunch of depressing shops places looks like its full of mindless zombies on a shopping spree. Nothing here unless you hungry and even so go somewhere else you will get a meal and go "meh" not worth the money you spent for it.
 Guess if you never been here it's nice to look at.
author: Wooka W.

description:
Came here today. Left in a hurry. This place is worse than L.A.'s version and that's really saying a lot.

I'm not Japanese but have been living in Japan for a couple of years so while I don't think myself an authority on all things Japan, I do know what's a "Japan as seen from Western countries" vs "Japan as it actually is" and Japantown is definitely a tourist trap from hell.

There are more restaurants than there are shops, none of which (except one, of which I don't recall the name) actually look like an authentic Japanese restaurant. I can't speak for the food, but the atmosphere was all wrong.

Even though it's Japantown I think I heard all of 2 couples speaking Japanese while walking around. Everyone was either Korean or a weaboo.

Speaking of weaboo, Minus 10 billion stars for the group of weaboos hanging on the benches outside a crepe shop complete with hair dyed pink, CAT EARS and HOBBIT EARS (on different overweight chicks..) and other nerd cosplay accoutrements. Don't get me wrong, I like cosplay- when done right, in Japan, at conventions. I like Akihabara maids, and the girls who dress as lolitas and take the train dressed that way. It's just that they're actually in Japan, and they're actually Japanese, so they can do that. I think if I'd come closer to this group I would have heard a lot of "OMG THAT'S SO KAWAII!!!" and "DESU DESU DESU". 

Of course, all the shops cater to that kind of person....lots of fake kimonos, lucky cats, and other similar goodies for those taking Japanese 101 at the community college.

The only two redeeming stores: the purikura shop with authentic machines, and the Rilakkuma shop. The crepe shop was tempting but when I walked by and saw other people's crepes, it was clear by the thin, soft texture that these were French-style crepes, not the thicker, crunchier Japanese style crepe that is actually made for holding pudding, ice cream, cheesecake, or whatever else you can fit in there. These thin crepes were bursting all over the place. Not appetizing.

It seems like Japantown has a lot of history...I liked the monuments outside. But what is leftover of the mall are a bunch of souvenir shops for the anime loving dorks who think they should go live in Japan because "no one understands them" here. Desu.

To anyone who says the shops here are authentic: just, no.

Also, props to the Asian guy in the video rental shop who didn't understand when I requested a title in Japanese. I've never had issues at video stores in Japan so I'm pretty sure the problem was with him. Extra points for saying they only carry movies with subtitles. Are we sure Japantown caters to Japanese? Video rental shops in Japanese ares in the L.A. area *never* have subtitles. Why would I want them? If I'm renting a Japanese movie then it's because I want to see it in Japanese. I guess they're for the hobbits and cat girls inhabiting this place.

I really can't voice how much this place irked me. Never again.
author: Love X.

description: The best tourist place for some in San Francisco.  All the buses and so forth that drive through town on their tours need to stop here as there is really great stuff and at every price from the Daiso to the restaurants and food concessions to the authentic Japanese grocery, to the bookstores and other goods stores including souvenirs, other objects and even furniture for sale.  Really nice people hang out here and visit here, too ... .  Great!
author: Thomas H S.

description:
Omg, otaku central puh-leeze!

way overpriced (not like it wasn't before)

And.. i dunno, do we live in a 5th dimension or something? because last time I was here, I saw Ash, Misty, Brock, and Charmander.

And a giant pokeball.
Maybe an eewie was in there.

I don't like this place anymore. I got to give it credit for entertaining me with queer* people here, though, thus the 3 stars.

*queer as in rather odd
author: Frankie W.

description:
First, let me include a few words that might get this review to rank well on Google: Japantown, San Francisco, landmark, shopping mall, things to do in San Francisco, visiting San Francisco.

Yes, this review is primarily for out-of-towners and tourists.
If you are into Japanese art, antiques, toys, animes or mangas, or if you are visiting the city with your kids who are into that, then Japantown, and more specifically the Kintetsu Mall, is a must see.
You might also want to allow a couple of hours in there.

There are a lot of little shops to browse through, from Japanese bookstore to Japanese supermarket and other car-tuning, toys and collectibles shops.
There are also a lot of places to eat, from coffee shops and crepe houses to sushi boat restaurants.

Pretty much all the restaurants there are very good, even though the best Japanese food in San Francisco is definitely not in Japantown. However, I wouldn't really recommend Sushi Boat or Benihana, which are overrated and overpriced.

I always thought the mall looked clean and nice, but it's even better since they remodeled and have all these little pools with waterfalls and fish!
author: Vithiet L.

description: Nice collection of shops and restaurants in and around the mall. Great place to people watch
author: Steve A.

description: A great place to go to shop, eat & hang out if you're tired of SF Chinatown.  This place is more relaxed and has less tourists.  They have a number of stores you can browse around and prices are pretty decent too.
author: Reggie S.

description:
J-town hasn't been the same since some sub-genius demolished Japantown Bowl for a neophyte's idea of a housing complex. Gone are the days of beer, bowling, blacklights, and booty bass nights with Shadow and Z-Trip. All that's left for SF Bowlers are the midget lanes in the Presidio and Yerba Buena.

At least there's still the Kinokuniya Bookstore (to kill time before dinner or a movie), Nijiya Market (for lunch treats), J-town Video (for anime), and the annual Cherry Blossom Festival (and Parade).

For me, Japantown killed it's 4th star when it lost J-town Bowl. (Damn, I never thought that I'd miss those nasty a$$ red 'n blue bowling shoes.) Though in all fairness, I still enjoy going to J-town every now-and-then, especially for a grilled cheese & fries at May's Coffee Shop. \(^o^)/
author: Be N.

description: It's cute but Japan itself is a lot more authentic.  :)  I think most of the girls were Chinese.
author: Greg D.

description:
Japantown has seen a lot of changes in the last 20 years. 

There used to be more Japanese restaurants, more character, and landmarks like the old Japantown Bowl. Although there are some very good Japanese restaurants now, the quality of retail stores has gone down. 

I'm glad to see Kinokuniya bookstore has expanded in all directions and is a decent source for Japanese books and books on Japan. The Peace Plaza was remodeled to make it modern and relevant, but it's too sterile in my opinion, kind of like a big empty space. I'm confused that interesting furniture stores have closed down while places like the dollar store are still standing. Some gems are Asakichi on the Kinokuniya side of the building (Japanese pottery, dishes, etc.), the Mashiko pottery store in the same building, Uoki market (one of the first grocery stores in Japantown), Benkyodo (old mochi store), and Soko hardware. Tampopo is very good for ramen, and Takara is great for all-round Japanese food. The number of Korean restaurants has increased over the years, and while this is fine and normal, it has led to a sort of identity crisis in some parts of Japantown.

I wish Japantown would breathe new life, and I think this will happen if new retail stores come in to draw more people in. Sadly this hasn't happened in a long while..
author: Al B.

description: Not too big but has a lot to offer. Cute shops, stationary, origami, anime, books, food, and everything Japanese related. Also holds the popular Sophie's crepes. It is a nice place to spend half a day.
author: Sarah C.

description:
I can't believe I've been to San Francisco as many times as I have and visited neighborhoods like Chinatown and North Beach dozens of times and never been to Japantown! I immediately fell in love with Japantown and I want to live here!!!! it's a peaceful neighborhood without the chaos and crowds.
 
The peace plaza is such a great connection point. We sat there, enjoyed the fountain and the warm breeze (but not the pigeons... I don't like birds, but there were only a handful). It was a very pleasant place to take a load of and relax. While we were there we saw a few groups of guys pull up in cars, run and take a picture of themselves here and then ran back to the car and take off. It was a scavenger hunt. How fun!

I also love the Miyako mall with all its cute stores and restaurants. It's a very walkable neighborhood and from now on I'll be visiting Japantown during every visit to SF and enjoying  a meal at one of the many restaurants here!
author: Lori K.

description:
I love Japantown.  Isobune, book store, pretty location, parking in all directions.Cool events now and then.  A SF treasure!  

In the main building the ladies room toilet seats always covered with piss though.  Nasty.

Denny's is pretty lame also.
author: Cynthia B.

description:
You've got to try that one picture booth shop. So much fun. My BFF and I didn't think it would be so fun. Honestly, we were hesitant cause we both thought it would be kinda lame but it was the opposite. You take about ten shots in a photo booth then you decorate them.  It was definitely cheesey but something you've got to do.   

Also we bought a bunch of random nick-nacks from the the little convenient store (ichibankan) upstairs. Super cheap random things that you'd only buy in Japantown. Yummy little treats and cute useless toys for kids.  We spent hours there just looking at everything and deciding what to buy because it was so cheap.

I'd definitely return to Japantown for a day of randomness!
author: Alicia A.

description:
Unbelievable.... every time i visit J town there is always something new... 

this area of San Francisco is a true gem... I love coming here!!! and bringing a date here makes it all the more fun!!! 

The shops are always filled with the most amazing, one of a kind, hidden little treasures... that you just can't pass up, and you wind up spending 20 or 30 min trying to justify what you could possible use that for.... or where you could put that.... sometimes you just have to tell your self to put it down and walk away.... 

My addiction is the little tricked out automotive store... with all its little enticing bells and whistles that keep calling my name... i still want them all even though i don't own a car... how sad is that!!!! 

and then Oh oh oh.... they got a new store i hadn't seen before that had all kinds of cool guy things... like swords, knives, and all kinds of things one could impale ones self on.... 

and of course my date and i had to stop at the bookstore to look at the cook books...they are just some of the most jaw dropping creative cook books I've ever seen.... my date introduced me to this cute and quiet funny little book i think it was called... "angry little girl" we both had a good laugh... 

they even have a new noodle restaurant that my date and i were gonna try but as always sushi triumphed....
author: keith p.

description:
I love this place.

My favorite place is the Japanese book store. Oh and the grocery store.
author: Alexa D.

description:
Man there is nothing bad about this place... Well mayb--- NAH NOTHING WRONG.

This place is PERFECT. You have a lot of shopping, there is a Kinokuniya, (2 stories) for all your japanese books and manga needs. There is a LOT of places to get your grub on here. And I ALWAYS have problems deciding on where to go for food. There is a Daiso for all your shopping needs. Oh and a Nijiya (Supermarket) for all your bento, snacks, drinks, and what nots you need to get.

This place is truly one of the best places to go for snacks, food, and entertainment. A lot of friendly folk around here. I say if you live in SF - you should visit here once.
author: Matthew K.

description: I love Japantown! Every store, restaurant, and thing in this mall is so culturally enhances that it literally makes me happy to be there. Many of the places might mirror themselves, but that means every time you come back, you can try a new restaurant or shop at a new store with interesting items such as sushi clocks for sale.
author: Carlos H.

description:
It's always fun here. I love the ambiance, location, stores, food and bookstore to see. The festivals are cool too. Love coming here as well for art exhibits :)

Defnintely one of to-do list of rewinding places in San Francisco
author: Pierre B.

description:
This place looks like the midtown west in NYC too me -- too many vacant shops!

But still I got things I can't find in New York - the cute sticks, and decent letter papers with light background and lines in it. expensive but worth it.
author: Angela L.

description: I was afraid Japantown would not deliver on the high expectations my oldest son had for our stop.  It did!  He is somewhat obsessed with Japanese pop culture...anime, manga, etc. and he could have been there for days.  We all found the stores so fascinating.  The mall was extremely quiet with very few customers after school let out on a weekday.
author: Amy R.

description: Japantown offers some of the better (not best) Japanese food in the City. It's great for exploring the bookshops, having a crepe dessert, buying some bonsai or housewares, and all with cheap parking. Oh and don't miss the cherry blossom festival!
author: Calvin W.

description: Only place worth going out of yoru way to visit in San Jose, especially if you go during one of the festivals. Like all the Japantowns it's dying but not as badly as Los Angeles. It's also one of the better communities to live in near downtown san jose. Parking can be a pain but it's near the light rail and there's really a peaceful atmosphere there compared to downtown san jose where I lived for 5 years.
author: Jonah H.

description:
Origami supply shops.
Happy-time lunch sets.
$1.50 store of greatness.
Tea cups & sets.
Pocky.
Sushi
Ramen.

You will love Japantown if you like any of those above things ^_^. 
Plus it's pretty!
author: lauren p.

description: It's always fun to visit Japantown. Who doesn't like going to the 1.49 store and buying little things. One can only guess what they are as the writing on most items is in hieroglyphics. In the U.S. we have .99 cent stores but with the currency change it's the $1.49 store - LOL. Japan town offers a little bit of tradition with a modern twist. It's like going to Japan. The food is hit or miss. I've had better sushi in Marin County. Ask around where you might find a good restaurant. Cheapest is not always the best. Don't be disappointed ask around.
author: Veda F.

description:
Having been born in Japan but moving away before I could develop any great memories, this is probably as close to Japan as I can get. 

I love the shops and places to eat. Japantown sure as hell beats Japantown in LA... Please forgive me for even making any sort of comparison. :(
author: Allyson M.

description: I totally forgot how much I enjoy Japantown.  It's not the largest attraction in the city, but it's still a cool place to stroll, shop and eat.  Very clean and welcoming, it's very touristy, but it's still cool.
author: Joel M.

description:
The San Francisco Japantown is one of the few Japantowns around the United States.  Japantown SF consists of three buildings.  Most of the retail businesses are restaurants and snacks.  The main retail store is Kinokuniya, a bookstore.

To be honest, Japantown needs major renovations and a new look.  I have visited Japantown since I became an anime fan.  Japantown has been the same mostly on the inside and all of the outside.  Parking is limited.  San Francisco rarely gets hot weather.  When it gets hot, Japantown gets hotter.

My favorite areas in Japantown are the Kinokuniya bookstore and Peace Plaza where the pagoda is located.  Peace Plaza has cherry blossoms trees and an open area to be at peace.

Japantown is worth about an hour visit as a tourist attraction.  People can walk around the retail mall in 45 minutes if you window shop throughout your visit, take it slowly, and eat a snack.  Don't have high expectations.
author: Raymond M.

description:
I had a great time at Japantown, but there is a lot of stuff to wade through to get to the fun.

Honestly, the only things worth going to are:

1.  the ceramic store (sorry I can't remember the name, but it is only dishes and cooking things in the outdoor-entrance part of the mall, opposite side of the street from the Kinokuniya mall side) which was an utter treat with very nice ladies running the place, carrying everything from inexpensive melamine to high end teapots.  I left with an armload!

2.  Soko Hardware, for general fun and cool stuff.

3.  Andersen bakery for a cheap and yummy snack.

4.  Nippon-ya for a variety of fun candies... bean paste ones are the best!  

5.  Relaxing in the plaza... one of the few calm outdoor spots in urban SF not in a park.

I thought a lot of the stores had the same things as one another, and much of that was also in Chinatown for cheaper... especially the cast-iron teapots and that sort of thing.  

I was very sad to see on Yelp that most of the restaurants there are only 3 stars or so... I didn't end up eating there apart from the bakery as I was not very hungry... but next time I think I will.
author: Sarah C.

description:
I want to see Japantown in the Pre-war era.  It had to have been soooooo much more familiar to most people.  Believe it or not but the development across Geary Blvd and further was all considered Japantown before Geary Blvd snaked through. Sigh. Kinda depressing. I understand this neighborhood is trying to stay alive and thrive off of what they can possible call their best but it's so hard. It's so hard to have a sense of community but there is hope. Cherry Blossom wasn't going to happen if there wasn't a fundraiser put on by my best friend's brother and his crew. Our younger generation who still appreciate our heritage is still trying their best to keep this neighborhood as a community and as a whole. But Michelle A does have a point that it's definitely losing it's authenticity. Some shops are owned by Chinese or Korean mom and pops, some things are getting way overpriced such as some of the food (I do not trust Mifune and their food... it used to be good when I was younger but now it just SUCKS). I know that a lot of stores have overpriced commodities but realize that they are trying to give their costumers the best they can offer when it comes to representing the Japanese. 

I used to play basketball all the time at the JCCCNC for league and tournaments which I'm sure they still do. I love coming to Cherry Blossom and Street Fair to see and taste the local fair and see ol' faces like a mini high school reunion ha. But lately these festivals have been struggling inside and out. 

Japantown is one of those at risk neighborhoods in the city that plays a part in the unique diversity of the city. We need to love and support it like it's one of our childhood toys that we want to treasure and cherish for the rest of our lives. Our American-Japanese community is trying their best, why not the rest of the city of SF? With the help of New People and newer development coming in, hopefully Japantown will revive and become a neighborhood everyone will be really, really excited about.
author: Marie G.

description:
I just LOVE Japantown...my family LOVES Japantown...we could (and have) made a day hanging out, shopping and eating here. So many wonderful choices for both shopping and eating. 

Maybe it is me but I feel like when I am here that I have taken a very short (and not so expen$ive) trip to Japan...hey, a girl can dream can't she?? 

Anyway, if you just walk through the indoor mall it is still nice but you need to step outside, cross the street and venture up there a little. Yes it is more shops and restaurants but there are some very cool shops..there is a very interesting hardware, yes, I said hardware store and a very cool origami shop. How they survive in SF by just selling paper I will never know!

Inside the mall is a very cool bookstore that sells a majority of Japanese print books and mags BUT there is also reading material in English. They have so many beautiful cookbooks and craftbooks in Japanese that always make me think "if only I could read this...." oh well, here I go dreaming again!

Not sure about all the comments regarding the cleanliness...I have never seen it in the 15+ years I have been coming here. And YES, there are other Japanese here other than tourists (regarding another odd comment).

It is a wonderful place to go and take the family and get a small feel of the Japanese culture and some really good food!
author: Melody K.

description: This is the must-go place besides Golden Gate. Good for eating, shopping, window shopping or just walking around. I love Kinokuniya (Japanese book store), Daiso (everything 1.5$), Japanese stationary store, sushi boat restaurant, ice cream yogurt shop and lots of Japanese character cartoon shop.  LOVE this place!!
author: Suvida N.

description:
I've been coming to Japantown since I was little.  They have the coolest shops and some great restaurants.  Every time I visit the Bay Area this is one place I always have to walk around.

Some of my old favorite places in Japantown center are: the Hello Kitty shop (where I used to drool over all the Gundam models and toys), the Taiyaki stand (tasty pancake shaped like a fish with sweet red bean inside), and the Kinokuniya Bookstore.
author: Anthony L.

description:
I've been taking trips to Japantown since I knee high to a pigs eye....or 8 years-old. :) Honestly it's still one of my favorite places to go in the city. Any of my friends who haven't gone I take there so that they can expierence something outside of the piers and the clubs. 

I alaways end of stopping by the malls. Most of the stores have been there for years, especially the video rental place which seems to get smaller by the minute. :( However they get new vendors all the time like Amiko and Sanrio. 

It's a great place to just walk around even if you don't have any money, however if you do end up going you'll probably end up wanting to spend the money. :P Pika Pika is the place that absorbs the most of my money and that comes second to the manga store downstairs. 

If you're looking for something more cultural, New People across from the malls is a great new spot. They have 3 stories of varying artistic delights. Fashion, movies, paintings, sculptures, etc. 

If you have the time it's worth stopping by! :D
author: Molly B.

description:
I really like Japan Town. It's just one of those necessary stops you must make especially if you don't live on the West Coast and visit very sparingly. I like this place more because we don't have Japan Town on the East Coast. I think St Mark's is supposed to be NYC's Japan Town but it's not the same. They're both awesome, but both very different.

Actually last year when I visited Japan Town it seemed a little emptier than the previous year. I'm never lucky enough to be in the area when they're have Cherry Blossom festivals or any other type of functions. / This area of San Francisco is just very cute, clean, and relaxed. And full of Japanese goodness.
author: Geraldine T.

description: The more we go and the more we learn about the nooks and crannies of SF Japantown, the more we enjoy being there. Having an Uncle who pretty much lives there and is able to show us around helps a lot also. Especially, since he's one of those guys everyone seems to know as we walk along the streets. This past holiday season we went there and it was a very busy place. Tons of people going every which way and not just to eat too! It was the busiest I've ever seen the area. Great place to visit for a change of pace from the main attractions in San Francisco.
author: Brian A.

description: Careful because all the good shops, except the bonsai and pottery store close about 5pm.  Also, there are a couple shops away from the main "mall" but everything is pretty much in this one mall type building. There is a ton of eating places though.
author: Erin J.

description: When I came here to grab dinner with some friends, this place wasn't crowded. To be honest it was pretty dead. I'm not sure why though. There's a bunch of restaurants, which I didn't try all of them. There's gift shops, which is very similar to the ones I see in NYC, so to me it isn't really that special. They have shops with sweets, which was okay. I do have to admit they have pretty neat architectural structures. But if I return to San Fran, I might skip this location.
author: Sandy C.

description:
When your boyfriend is a well known Kaiju(i.e. monster) enthusiast, you take many trips to Japantown. He loves this place, I love seeing the twinkle in his eye when he comes to purchase his latest monster creation.

Now me on the other hand. I dig a lot of the giant monster shows for their psychadelic nature. I even have a few monster books. But as a whole, I avoid Japantown

Why? Well I was never much into manga, Japanese culture, or anything else to begin with. I never understood the cosplayers or anything along those veins. I don't care for many of the movies.

There's a reason why you'll find me in the Castro, because it keeps my attention. Japantown is better when I am here with my b/f. But alone...nah.
author: Lana P.

description:
I do enjoy visiting Japantown but I really don't know why!  LoL...

It's a great little spot but there are not enough variety of stores/shops.  I always feel like it's a little empty, like not much going on or something.  Plus there's always a "construction" type feeling everytime I go.  I dunno, it just seems like they're always doing something to fix something but then it never seems better than before.  Just always the same.

I LOVE going to the bookstores though and picking up a Japanese fashion magazine even though I don't understand a lick of Japanese.  Just the pictures are enough, their magazines are truly a cut above any magazine we have here in the states.  Even for a whopping $10.70 per magazine, it's worth it and I buy two every time.

The only place I've eaten there is Benehana's and it was okay.  The show they put on is cool but the food is not worth the price.  I guess it's just an experience and I guess the ambiance is good in the restaurant.  When we went there it was packed and we had to wait so we just walked around the "mall".

The little cafe's in Japantown are cool too.  They have good little snacks and boba drinks.  You can get that stuff in Chinatown though and more is going on.

Overall I just like going there b/c it's different (and for the bookstores).  They used to sell great knock off purses in one of the shops but I guess they probably got in trouble coz now they sell just the regular not good knock offs hehe.
author: Kay R.

description:
Japantown is a wonderful place to visit! Especially during the Cherry Blossom Festival! The only drawback of coming during the festival is that I wouldn't recommend driving here. It took me about an hour to find parking! That wasn't too fun!

There were so many people today that it blew my mind! I know of Sophia's Crepes being an awesome place to get a snack, but unfortunately for us we didn't get anything from there today. There were like 40-50 people in line! That must have taken at least 30-45 minutes to get a crepe. We ended up at a few of the food vendors outside and got some fried noodles and udon for lunch. I met a lot of cool people during the festival and I had a blast! The music was good. The atmosphere and the food was great! 

I will try to come back out here next week! Maybe taking Bart and taxi would be a better option.
author: Darryl P.

description:
Having seen Japantown's share of structural changes over the last few years, it remains one of my personal favorite. It's charm and appeal continue to endure despite of its aging design. The New People mall have certainly helped revive Japantown though its VIZ Theatre could use a few more quality movies. At times it looks like the new building was doomed to close down due to lack of business but with new events that are put out almost every month, it will surely thrive. 

The few remaining restaurants such as Mifune serves some of the best ramen and unagi don. 

Kinukunya Books Store has a great collection of magazines and books and mangas, my only advice is to bring lots of cash with you, because you will want to spend spend spend.
author: Jonathan B.

description:
I tend to have a "must find" list for specialized places such as Japantown. What I was looking for (AND FOUND) today was: 

Boat sushi (tasty tasty Nigiri in particular)
Daiso products for less than $3 (kitchen sponges in animal shapes)
Mochi in every flavor
An elusive series of english-language Manga for my best friend
Boba tea. And crepes. :)

And all of this indoors because it was pouring out! Lots of teens, very few tourists, super fun, and super cheap. Also, incredibly simple to get to, via #38 bus.
author: Kate K.

description: The Japantown Mall, Kabuki Hot Springs, the Sundance Kabuki Theater, New People shops - there are so many fun stops and shops to explore in Japantown - still looking for a knock-out sushi restaurant here, though...
author: Denise N.

description:
So after getting a bit lost and confused I finally made my way over to Japan town.  I didn't realize Japan town was basically a bunch of shops located in what seemed to be like an old school styled mall.  All the buildings are connected via sky bridges.  

There were cheap looking water falls and other tacky decorations inside.

There were lots of shops but most of them being very disappointing.  All it all a weird little area.  I saw the Crepe shop and that looked interesting but didn't get a chance to try it out.

All in all it was pretty scarce as far as tourists and visitors, I guess sometimes the path less traveled is not traveled for a reason.
author: David N.

description:
I heart Japantown.  It's a fascinating place.  Yes it's a little dingy around the edges, but the uniqueness of the shops more than makes up for it.  

The best incense store in town is here, the bookstore is just off the hook.  Pretty much the only place in town to get decent japanese pottery.

It's not a glamorous American shopping mall nor should it be.  It is quirky, different and fun.  I always enjoy my visits here.  

I do wish the owners would consider a major facelift.  The buildings are definitely dull concrete modern.  Something more in keeping with Japanese culture would be more appropriate especially in the courtyard with the big Pagoda.  The Pagoda is cool, but the lack of greenery and flowers really detract.
author: Russell D.

description:
101 is one of my favorite numbers. It reminds me of Dalmatians, driving, and ice cream sandwiches. And so, I'm a bit disappointed my 101th review is a 2-star review for Japantown. But I can't hold it in any longer! 

Japantown was a disappointment. A disgrace in the name of ethnihoods, and a dying attraction in this day and age. 

So enough mindless babbling bandrew! What's wrong? Well, it's just anticlimactic. The mall was limited to closed shops and empty restaurants. The courtyard was unimpressive and quite... how do I put this... stale, boring, bland, lacking credibility... It needs more 'Japanese'! 

I want to walk the neighborhood and break into song: "I THINK I'M TURNING JAPANESE. I THINK I'M TURNING JAPANESE. I REALLY THINK SO!" ... But I didn't. And that, kind gentle-person, is a problem!

I was also lost. What is there beyond the tower and the mall? There was no guide, no other attractions, nothing fun or cultural! 

Perhaps the only time to visit is the Cherry Blossom Festival, but I would love to see this neighborhood revitalized and instilled with an infusion of (loud) cultural attractions.
author: Andrew C.

description: I like how SF's Japantown is a lot spacious with more variety compared to the one in SJ. From cute little accessory stores, to creperies, to restaurants, and much more! I love to just browse around the little shops, pick up random stuff, stop by Daiso, and eat some good Japanese ramen, curry, donburis, or sashimi. Parking can get quite hectic over the weekend, but what do you expect? It's SF!
author: Hannah L.

description:
I'm sure many of the negative reviews of Japantown have merit. However, as a newcomer to the City, I found the place both intriguing and fun. I used to be one of "those people" who  was seriously obsessed with all things Asian. The Japantown Mall stores reminded me of that youthful preoccupation - in a good way. I'll definitely return for the ambiance...and maybe a few cute tchockies!

But the restaurants...yeah, the one we ate at (don't even remember the name) was pretty lack-luster. That's why Japantown gets 3 stars in my book.
author: Julia D.

description: What a cultural escape and oasis. Love the incense, the food, the hardware stores, the supermarket, stationary stores, teapots, etc. I've come here for 10 years for a peaceful escape from the city (check out the Kabuki spa too) and will miss it. I'll be coming here when I'm back in SF. I hope it stays vibrant and alive.
author: Renee M.

description: Probably, the best Japantown I have ever visited. Feels and looks a lot like Tokyo. Great selection of restaurants and shops.
author: James W.

description:
i love it.

i know, im japanese so im sure thats why im such a fan-- but this place has character. japanese communities around the united states are dying from lack of business, and i feel like its my duty to spend some moolah on hello kitty trinkets, expensive pens and pencils and yummy snacks to reconnect with my roots. 

this place is a must! :]
author: Erin N.

description:
Wow, I have to give props to and direct my friends Carl and Yves to Bridget D's review.  Yeah!  what she said.  

Read the other reviews, these guys know what they are talking about! 

(I know this is cheating review writing wise but I am trying to put together a list fast!  Sorry for my bad yelpiqutte)
author: Josie C.

description:
It's tons of fun....

if by fun you mean either hungry, dying to watch an independent film, or do some shopping - then yes it's hella fun. I remember it being such a nice walk across the street to pick up some sushi, or slurp up some udon, or look up some tattoo art work. They do sell those great wooden platform sandals...that go *clop clop clop* but be careful because they aren't as durable as you would expect...especially in the sand...like the sand found at ocean beach.. 

But they burn well!
;D
author: John-Michael C.

description: I love this place, lots of things to buy for the home, restaurants and how you'll feel that you're in a different world! I'd come here again.
author: Jackie A.

description:
For a place called Nihonmachi there sure are a lot of non-Japanese establishments.

I worry that some ignorant visitor will leave thinking that "we" were responsible for the cultural pox that is Denny's (we claim full responsibility for Benihana, however).  Or that the Japanese eat kim chee all the time, because, you know, "we all look alike."

I'm just sayin'....

Anyway, it is a great place for me to indulge in my genetic predilection for all things anime.  You can also find great skincare and hair products here such as Deeses, although you will pay a premium (you think the dollar is weak against the Euro?  Try checking it out against the Yen).  The groceries are excellent as well (somewhere in Heaven my Japanese obachan is livid that I paid so much for konyaku).

And there's the historic significance of Japantown.  That's right -- it's not just a shopping center.
author: d s.

description:
I LOVE JAPANTOWN! I can't believe my mom NEVER EVER took me here in the past 3-4 years that we've been coming to SF for the winter holidays!!! It's ALWAYS Chinatown and I am so sick of the same thing over and over again. She really tries to make it less boring for me and my sisters but dude, I've seen Chinatown and it's the same stuff every year. She always wants to go to take us for some Dim Sum and eat the "best wonton mian" ever but I don't like Dim Sum anymore since 4 years ago and wonton mian tastes just like the wontons she makes at home! but with mian! I want some SUSHI! RAMYUN! UDON! ANYTHING BUT DIMSUM AND WONTON MIAN!

I'm glad I finally got to come here. Me and my sisters wanted to spend forever here. Too bad the mother was rushing us towards the third hour for no good reason; so that could only mean one thing...I'm COMING BACK!!
author: Jenni Y.

description:
I love Japantown.. and I think I forever will.

I was afraid it would be gone after some news about it going down a few years ago, but I was happy to see it up and running!

For it to be threatened of being shut down, it was SUPER crowded when I went so I was somewhat happy to see that. :)

Lots and lots of stores! ..kinda overpriced, but whatevs.

Like others have said, it needs renovation. It has potential, but someone has to do something about it.
author: Christina Y.

description:
Anywhere that instant photos, candy, noodles (Sapporo-ya, baby), incense, fancy/cute stationery, cool pens, AND sparkly stickers live right next to each other is where I want to be. I like that I can find books instructing me on origami or how to enlighten my spirit, everything you ever wanted to know about manga (but were afraid to ask), furry cell phone cases, and everything CUTE ever fucking made plus Bruce Lee calendars that are 16 - yes 16! - months long all in a two block radius. (Don't try to understand the Japanese fascination with cuteness - the closest I ever got is that it is kind of analogous to Americans and pop culture/Americana/kitsch.) Clear? I didn't think so. 

Also, in case you didn't know -there is a "rock exhibition" that is always there. I don't know why it is there or who buys said rocks, but I love the entire concept. 

Going to Japantown makes me want to believe in an afterlife. Cuz then maybe the afterlife will be like Japantown.
author: Mokirobinson M.

description:
Yuck.  This place is old and decrepit and badly needs renovations.  Jtown Plaza is barren and when the wind from the Bay comes sweeping up, dang--does it get cold here.

I always get the feeling that this place is not what it used to be anymore, as with the diaspora of Japanese Americans assimilating and intermarrying.  There just doesn't seem to be a sense of community here.  Disappointing.

I do however, like Mifune's ramen and the Denny's open 24 hours, is the place to chill with the homies, although it is a tad run-down.

This whole place needs a renovation or an infusion of authenticity.  It's sad.  I avoid this place--it's not my recommended place when homies visit in the City, we just drive through past on Geary.
author: JC K.

description:
I love Japantown! Ichiban Kan. Kinokunya bookstore and stationery store. The little picture machine on the level below the bookstore. Cherry Blossom Festival. Beautiful Peace Plaza. The food. People who dress up as anime characters. Bonsai. Crepes. Cuteness. Most of all, I enjoy coming here because it reminds me of Japan on a small scale and that just adds to my love for San Francisco....


As a side note, I love Japantown so much that I decided to *BE* Japantown for Halloween this year. Sexy Nihonmachi. Yes, you heard right. A group of friends and I decided to become our favorite SF landmarks (Golden Gate Bridge, Lombard St, Ghirardelli  Square, Twin Peaks, etc) for the evening. So if that doesn't show my devotion to you, Japantown.. I don't know what does.
author: CHERiE Y.

description:
Japantown, Japantown, how can I describe thee?

So the first time I went to Japantown was when I was three. Yes, I remember. I have a very selective memory, thankyouvery much. I remember fountain type things, and visiting a small shop called Benkyodo (?). My dad worked around the area, so he had some mates. 

Eight years later, I decide to take a little trip back. It was very enjoyable, I had so much fun, but I don't remember much :\

I always make some sort of trip to Japantown.

Present Day, age 15, I went to Japantown with two of my friends, and needless to say, we had a blast. From PikaPika to crepes to Manga to IchibanKan (the devil of all Japanese stores), we got worn out. Everywhere you go, there will always be an oppourtunity waiting in Japantown.

Also, it's 3am. I don't know what else to say.
author: Kristin M.

description:
San Francisco's Japantown celebrates its centennial in 2006.

Japantown moved to the Western Addition district following the April 1906 earthquake that devastated the South Park and Chinatown areas, the original Japantown locations. San Francisco's Japantown is the first and oldest of its kind on the continental USA and was established when the first Japanese immigrants arrived in San Francisco in the 1860s.

With the relocation of the community came more Japanese businesses, shops, churches, schools, restaurants, hotels, and other organizations, which grew in the Western Addition and further supported the growth of the community.  The neighborhood took on a very Japanese character and before long became a miniature Ginza known as Nihonmachi, or Japantown.

Visit the centenntial website for information about celebration events:
http://sfjapantown100.org
author: Keith K.

description: I like visiting this place mainly for the food..especially Sophie's crepe! Also, the annual cherry blossom festival is always filled with fun...and good food from the street vendors.
author: Ngoc L.

description:
The best thing about Japantown is Kinokuniya--having studied Japanese, I'm a Japanophile waiting to burst out. Magazines, books, toys and art books out of control. Watch your wallet here! The Kinokuniya stationary store is also out of control amazing. 

That being said, most of the restaraunts are all pretty mediocre, with some exceptions. You're better off going to the Peninsula in San Mateo, where the japanese food is SPECTAULAR. The plaza itself is quite ugly, although I wasn't expecting a Disney version of Japan (SF Chinatown style).
author: Romy I.

description: I stayed in Japantown a couple of years ago when I visited SF. It was inexpensive and seemed like an interesting part of town. There isn't a lot in the area to do - the restaurants and stores seem to open sporadically and there isn't too much to do there. It is a good location to use as a base for visiting the city, although there aren't many places to walk to, so you would have to take public transit or have a car.
author: Mary M.

description:
The little town that used to be.  What used to be a great place to hang out, alas is a deserted ghost town nowadays.  12pm on a weekday, and there is barely anyone around.

I miss Japantown Bowl.  And what happened to all the shops in the mall?  Aside from the very few favorites, there's not much there anymore.   I don't eat at Japantown, because oddly enough, I find much better restaurants elsewhere in the city.  I rarely shop here, because the stores are limited - and only when I need something specific do I visit.  Usually I'll head upstairs to the Kinokuniya Bookstore, get what I want and leave.  The little supermarket on the corner?  That's the only place that is packed.  With lines 10 people deep, who wants to wait? 

I want to love Japantown again, I really do, but there little to draw me there as it is now.  Sad really.  With some change, I think it would bring back the crowds and be a place people can enjoy a small piece of Japan in SF again - and not just on festival days.
author: Denise M.

description: Unless something specific is going on, it's not worth the bus fare to this area.
author: Dan M.

description:
Japantown Center consists of several buildings, and has a nice plaza in the center with a large fountain, trees, and places to sit for a bit outdoors. However, it's usually a bit chilly and breezy for me out there, no matter what time of the year it is!

INSIDE there are Japanese shops, selling cool dishes, fabrics, decor for your home, jewelry, art, books, stationery, craft supplies, almost anything you can think of that was made in Japan. There are also many restaurants, which have been yelped by lots of Yelpers.

I just want to give the average person an overall view of the entire center. THere's ample parking below the buildings. I've never had a hard time finding a parking place. Also, there are public restrooms and those cool photo booths to take goofy pictures and have them applied to little stickers or the standard photo strips like you get at the boardwalk. There are hobby shops that sell RC vehicles and race car tracks and sets. There are bakeries specializing in Japanese goodies.

It's a really wonderful place to spend some time immersed in the Japanese culture! So far it's the best Japantown that I've been to. I still haven't found fresh mochi ice cream here, but I've gotten my fill of fresh mochi with redbean paste, which is my second favorite!

Check it out! If you haven't been there, then you're not fully Californicated.
author: Shari D.

description: Fun!!!  It's a place to sneak away in an underground mall.  Not really too much shopping places but what they have are speciality shops which r fun!
author: Kimberly P.

description:
Always entertaining.

I could browse through countless stores and buy hello kitty crap while eating some great noodles or sushi!!!!

There were even the little fish shaped red-bean-filled cakes made fresh.  OD on some of those and go watch a movie at the Kabuki.  MEMORIES! AWWWWWWWWWWWWWW
author: Joan E.

description:
Jtown to the many reviewers here may be just a place to eat and buy Japanese, but to me and few fellow yelpers it's a place I call home. It's where I went to school, played as a kid, worked as a teen..Today I still continue to build on those memories.

One great thing that has happened in the last week is the San Francisco Japantown History Walk. 16 permanent interpretive signs are placed throughout a 10 block area celebrating the 100 years of Jtown in the Western Addition. Go check it out. It's amazing. And that awesome Sensu. I love it.
author: umeboshi l.

description:
More like "Korea Town" am I right?

There's an air that more of the local businesses are being bought out by Korean businesses.

Maybe it's just me.

So what's to like?

The Pavilion thing is kind of cool. And the pedestrian mall (Buchanan Street) between Laguna and Webster is nice. Though a bit short.

There's a variety of shops that could have come straight out of Japan too: the purikura shop, the yakimanju stand, the crepe shop, and the local shabu shabu restaurants and karaoke boxes are all there.

It leaves me with one word that kind of ruins it all for me.

Ghetto.

Imagine taking buildings from the 80s and just putting Japanese stores in them. That doesn't really make it 'Japan Town' does it? It would be best if there was a sense, like an aura of a slice of Japan without the white stucco walls and cheap glass windows. One that isn't fitted in for convenience, but more designed with Japan in mind from the start.

Don't get me wrong, I think the stores are great.

I just think they're out of place. Like a bull in a china shop.
author: Jeffrey C.

description: A visit to Japan yields the alluring smack dab next to the ugly-- it's funny how Japan Town is no exception to that theme! I guess you'd have to spend some time in Japan to truly dig these malls, but you know what, I like them. Who cares about the buildings because it's what inside that counts. Take a stroll and discover the many businesses that sell things as unique as exotic teas, imports from Okinawa, and of course, the ubiquitous sushi and pan-Asian food. Go at different times in the day and night. You'll be surprised how things changes, how hidden doors open after dark revealing multiple karaoke, sake/beer and hostess bars. I've been a score of times and am still discovering new gems that I never knew existed. My recent discovery: Kappa. Good luck finding it. It took me 1/2 hour to locate this place and I am thoroughly familiar with the layout. It's a fun fun way to spend an evening, alone or with friends.
author: Brian J.

description: I rewrote this posting after realizing that my original negative review of Japantown would only drive people away from the place which I truly could make a turnaround for the better.  A common initial impression by people that has lived in Japan is that J-Town has very little resemblance of shops, restaurants, and department stores in Japan.  Shops, especially in urban cities like Tokyo or Osaka, are cleaner, organized, and "nice."  Many aging stores in J-Town are outdated and disorganized.  80% of the restaurants that serve mediocre food at J-Town would never survive in Tokyo where competition for quality food is fierce.  This was the view I had, until I started to look beyond the aging surface and realized that if I go there every other week, there must be positive qualities to the place.  After spending half a day looking at the stores with this new perspective, I realized that there are many unique shops and restaurants that everyone, regardless of your level of exposure to Japanese culture, should come and experience.  There are many "gems" hidden between mediocre restaurants.  I will create a "list" in Yelp to showcase some of these gems.  I still do believe in my theory that continuous revenue from tourists hurt Japantown as it keeps bad restaurants in business and doesn't motivate them to improve the quality of food.  Japanese tourists who cannot eat American food beyond two straight days rush to Japantown.  It's on their "How to walk around the Earth" guide book and they don't know about the "good" Japanese food in other parts of the town.  It doesn't matter anyways, because by this time, they are so desperate for miso soup and rice, tears start appearing in their eyes no matter what quality Japanese food they eat.
author: トモ T.

description: Japantown has a history.  It's culture is defined, unique, and vibrant.  It is clean, orderly, peaceful and serene.  The food is authentic and fantastic.  The people are respectful and polite, and the scenery is quite nice to look at.  Unsurprisingly, it's the exact opposite of Chinatown.
author: Tony C.

description:
From the Japanese cuisine to your fill of Japanese Anime related merchandise this is the place to be.

Whenever I come back to the Bay Area occasionally they would hold a car meet  (right in the main Japan Town Parking Structure). 

This is one of the many novelty's of San Francisco that especially the Japanese population would agree is pretty enjoyable. Especially with the anime con fans and of course the seasonal cherry blossom festival occurring as well.

Arigato Japan Town...Arigato.
author: Ryan M.

description:
We all have dreams right?
Well mine is hate to say it...the most AWESOME dream ever!
....my dream is to witness the day zombies attack.....
i know kinda awesome

So get this...I play a lot of video games in my life, and well I'm very fond of zombie games, and I have no clue why.  Last week my boyfriend takes me to japantown and we park on Geary Street and as we are walking down the hill around the mall to get to the other side I see an open door and assume it's a short cut...because we all know my lazy ass hates walking.  I walk in the door and it's surrounded by flys...I freak out I have OCD and I have big Asian hair so now I think their attacking my hair. I ran out so fast swatting my hands around my body I probably looked like a crazy woman. Once out of that horrid building I contiued to my destination...the MALL...while walking I see a bunch of pigeons EVERYWHERE. Now FYI I hate birds, birds poop, birds peck at your head, birds have scary eyes. But JAPANTOWN birds OH GOLLY...they made my DREAM come true. 

I take one good look at the birds, and they have dirty untamed feathers, their beak is sharped for the killing, and their eyes bloodshot red.  I've never been so excited for my life. I was squealing like a little girl I finally got to see a zombie...oh wait a zombie bird. So there I was in the middle of my dream and what do I do next...I kneel down on the floor and get my picture taken with the zombies.

WOW.
Thank you dirty japantown.
You've made all my dreams come true
author: Cristelle J.

description:
I am a huge fan of Japantown! Not just because I can fulfill my constant cravings for croquette curry and okonomiyaki and crepes, but because of Kinokuniya and Moritaya too.  

Kinokuniya has a bunch of craft books that are hard to find or need to be special ordered from other bookstores, as well as any manga you could want.  Well mostly any :)  

And Moritaya, well they are getting more overpriced as the years go on but they really are the only place I can find really good nail polish and nail art supplies.  

Pika Pika is like heaven to me, my friends and I have been going there since they only had two machines, and their selection now is like heaven!  We are shamelessly addicted to purikura.  Especially the most expensive ones... 

Ichiban Kan and Nijiya are cute little shops with things to snack on and useful items.  I miss Mikado, I haven't been to Japantown in like a month but I think they moved out, maybe it moved to Tanforan, at least that's what my boyfriend insinuates.  

As I said, I LOVE Japantown, but I am going to save my five star rating until the J-Pop Center opens up.  Come on, having shops that actually sell Lolita?  I'm praying it's as good as it sounds, and not more expensive than it is in Japan.
author: Meghan E.

description: No crosswalk at Geary and Webster. Stupid.
author: Karla B.

description: What can I say about Japantown, I love coming here probably cause of Sophie's crepes. Haha. Also to take pika pika pictures which is fun. If you are into Anime, this is the place for you. Other than that, I do love the architecture and everything seems to be so clean. Honestly, the bathroom in the mall is seriously one of the cleanest public bathrooms I've been too. Lol. Anyways, they hold the Cherry Blossom Festival here every year which is pretty cool. Usually when they have things like Festivals/Car shows, parking sucks. Usually the parking garage gets full to the point you gotta wait till people come out to go inside which the wait is forever. Also, parking in the garage is like $2 every hour.
author: Janice V.

description: Fun!!! I wish every major city had one. Food, stores and people.
author: John H.

description: Lots of great places to eat.  Cool history and fun walks.  A must stop area for tourists.
author: Jennifer L.

description:
I lived in Japan for almost eight years so going to Japantown is always like a little homecoming for me.  I love the Japanese supermarkets and also go home with a huge bag of things I can't get anywhere else - okonomiyaki mix, Poki, Mabodofu Mix, etc.  

There are also some fantastic places to eat there - all you can eat Shabu Shabu, Korean BBQ, Mochi!!!  I wouldn't come here for the sushi because there are better places around town.

Japantown was our first choice in our new San Francisco walking tours list.  I know we will be coming back again and again.  We went there first to get some mochi, then off to the Van Ness movie theater then walked back after our three movies were done.  It not far at all and a great place to go after a day at the movies!
author: Sean O.

description:
I always enjoy this part of the town, well maybe partially because I AM Japanese. I like the environment, and the mini J-town. 

There are a variety of Japanese stores, restaurants, markets, etc. I love going here to shop for food at nijiya market, or the 100 yen store. Kinokuniya is great for books, and you can't beat Andersen bakery (yummy deserts). 

Japan town is usually pretty clean, and safe. Never ran into any problems, and the people are usually friendly as well. Parking is always a bargain compared to anywhere else, AND you can validate as well! 

I will continue to return here. :)
author: Catherine O.

description:
