I love this neighborhood!  I used to go up to SF w/ my friends when I was lil' kid, so I could buy animae models and toys...fast forward to the present day.. I still see myself drawn to these stores w/ all the Japanese collectibles.  Only now, finding Robotech toys is a lot harder, and definitely more expensive.  

This place also has very delicious Japanese restaurants besides just sushi.  There's an amazing crepe store across from the bookstore in the second floor.  Oh yea, and I also found a very good book store, PaperTree, that sells very intricate and unique origami books.  Seriously, these origami models are incredible, and it definitely takes patience and skill to complete them.  If you're in SF, you definitely have to make a stop in Japantown and walk around and explore.  So much to see, so little time.
author: Minh V.

description: One thing that has stayed a constant and has never changed is Jtown mall. It's not flashy nor has it changed its style to look more artsy or hipster. Too bad the card store I used to go to here after high school classes are gone, but I do love the 'plain' and simple vibe I get from this mall. There's also plenty of places to eat inside although it could get pricey.
author: Gerard Y.

description:
I still feel the same as I did when I wrote my previous review, except now, I have to add--the bathrooms in Japantown's two malls are some of the filthiest in the city. They really make the malls seem seedy and horrible with the stench and messiness of it all. If these malls were actually IN Japan, they would be much cleaner than they are now.

Also, as I mentioned in my previous review, the "Pika Pika" purikura place is open and in business now; when I last looked at the prices, they were indeed quite jacked up. I guess the machines are really straight from Japan, but come on, who wants to pay $8 for purikura? I know in Japan they go for 400 yen (roughly 3-4 USD), but...really, $8 for small sticker pictures is too exorbitant.

Still a fan of Kinokuniya, Ichiban Kan, and Nijiya though. They're the closest you can get to actual Japan IMO.
author: Helene K.

description:
This is one stop shopping for all your Japanese needs. The book store has a great selection of magazines a books, all of which I cannot read, but the pictures are sure awsome. The video store too has a great selection of hard to find videos, I go there to pick up rare MMA dvds that are not released here. It really could use an overhaul though the layout is pretty terrible and some of the stores just seem outdated. Still J-town is landmark in the city and a cool place.

** here's a tip, if you want a "clean" place to hollah @ a deuce, go to the bathroom downstairs from the book store. They are newly rennovated and a little hidden so you can do the do in peace.
author: Fresh Young Balki B.

description: What would you call beauty?? I find beauty to be anything pleasing to the eye or touch. It could be a feeling that comes over you. That to me is beauty. In Japantown a tranquil relaxation is all around me. I bought a ukulele in Japantown and played it for hours. No one seemed to mind. No one bothered me. I normally come here alone. Sometimes I get food and go into the shops but most of the time I just sit alone and take in the city. I watch the sun set where I believe is called "peace plaza." Japantown takes away from some of the hustle and bustle of the city.
author: Bradley P.

description: I love Japantown.  It is as much fun as Chinatown and way less crowded.
author: Jennifer S.

description: This is truly one of the most underrated places in San Francisco.  Sure, from the outside, the boxy, drab, non-descript exterior is not very inviting, the restaurants border on mediocre, and the interior is just plain ugly, but Japantown is chock full of interesting surprises and items that you cannot find anywhere else.  From bonsai stores to karaoke lounges to a candy store filled with mysterious sweets, Japantown is best experienced by simply strolling and browsing the shops.  You never know what you're going to discover here.
author: Mike B.

description: LOVED IT! Japantown is great if you love the Japanese culture or are looking for origami paper. I wish I could have spent more time (and money) here.
author: Flora R.

description:
I used to work in J-Town for a now defunct non-profit graphic art studio. To me J-Town is not just a collection of restaurants and novelty stores and kitschy architecture that most visitors see. There is so much more to J-Town if you care to look. To me, it is also a community of people and organizations preserving and representing the history of Japanese Americans. Unfortunately, it seems to be a dying community, what with the high rate of out marriage and not enough infusion of immigrants from the mother country. So many places of historical value, such as the YMCA on Sutter and J-Town Bowl, are now gone. Still, J-Town is possessed of a vitality of JA spirit if you look hard enough. Once you've eaten your fill and bought your bagful at the dollar store or the stationary store, you might want to check out these places.

At Sutter and Buchannon is the JA Center of Northern California. Many cultural events are held there and they offer classes such as origami and ikebana. Downstairs is Kimochi where seniors can get a hot meal. It is the only senior lunch place in SF where seniors can sit down at a table, get a hot cup of tea, and be waited on for their Asian-style meal. I think lunch is only $1.50 so the line starts early, especially on unagi days. It might be worth your while  to comandeer a senior and check out lunch at Kimochi! 

Near the corner of Sutter and Buchannon is the National Japanese American Historical Society, another place I used to work at but before they moved here. Go in and check out their rotating exhibits. If you are doing research on any aspect of JA history, they have an archive you can request to use. Their photographic collection is amazing.  They also have oral histories. Fascinating stuff that most Americans have no idea about, especially during the WWII period.
author: Kara P.

description:
Definitely a sight to see in San Francisco! We visited for 1 week from Chicago and went to several different stores and restaurants within it. -Mikayo sushi (in the square) was a little pricey but well worth it.
-The row of restaurants inside the mall, can't go wrong. 
-Kinokuniya Bookstore was amazing!! Magazines in  Japanese! Books     in both Japanese and English!
-Little kiosk in the middle of the mall... shaved ice. Yum.
-The crepe place looked great, but was so crowded we didn't go. It would probably be worth it if you could brave the crowd.
-Lots of little trinkets for you to take home with you.

The memorial square is really criticized, but it was really a cool place to see. Cherry blossom trees and lots of people. The fountains are beautiful!
author: Ashley G.

description: Despite this location being a lot smaller than LA's little Tokyo, they make up for it by offering a good variety of book stores, restaurants and shops.  Lots of bakeries, creperies, book stores, pikura (sticker pics?), knick knack stores and lots of places to eat w/the typical fare - okonomiyaki, ramen, udon, curry, sushi, etc.  There's even a nail salon that offers 3D nail art.  I could seriously do a lot of damage if left alone here for a few hours.  There's even a japanese style bath house here (onsen)
author: Cynthia A.

description:
I grew up in the east bay, so this was the closest place to Japan that I experienced, growing up.  As a kid, I learned traditional Japanese folk dancing and would perform at the Cherry Blossom Parade, Nihonmachi Street Fair and Hana Masturi in Japantown at the Peace Plaza.  So good memories.

What is convenient about JTown is the underground parking structure right below the buildings and so cheap.  I have parked, run in and run out to the Yasukochi Sweet Stop, http://www.yelp.com/biz/EfkCyCaKoUFVdkRoi2prMw across the street to get  their coffee crunch cake and left under an hour for .40.  Sweet! 

But why do the external stairs to the street always smells like pee...what is up with that!?!?!
author: Deb N.

description:
Omg. everything I need. Hot baths, cold soba, dirty anime, clean products.

-Japanese BBQ at Juban
-Sukiyaki accross the street at Shabu-Sen
-Dessert at Sophie's Crepes
-A haircut at Japan Center Beauty Clinic
-Japanese-caliber 99c store shopping at Ichiban Kan
-Books at Kinokuniya
-Japanese stationary (nuff said)
-A 3 hour soak at the hot tubs at Kabuki
-A movie at Kabuki movie theater
-Groceries on the way home at Nijiya for DIY sushi
-Plants at Katsura Garden
-Misc antiques in the back of Asakichi
-Ogle Japanese Antiques
-Buy a really dirty DVD for later

Bliss. I do it almost every weekend.
author: Sita B.

description:
I go here to get my Japanese textbooks at the Kinokuniya, and that's about it.

The most fun you'll have is making fun of the white teenagers wearing Naruto headbands and shouting "BAKA!"
author: Center J.

description:
Some things never change. Japantown is one (that should). I've been going to Mifune for nearly 20 years and while its nearly great, its the lone highlight except Kinokuniya (yep, that odd duck who wears the industrial-strength face mask still works there).  

If you do go, don't look to close -- overall, the mall can appear downright nasty. As you walk around, the staff leave all sorts of gross things out for folks to see (on our last trip I got a peek into the kitchen at Osakaya - tubs of chicken on the floor??). 

The outdoor Peace Plaza is a nice place to hangout - now all they need to do is renovate the inside.
author: Shawn C.

description: I didnt really like this part of SF but my girlfriend Love's this spot i have to take her there every time we are in the city we have to stop by the Hello Kitty Store they have in the Mall.And look at every Store one by one dam there is noting really there to see thats if you are in to japanese food and Hello Kitty this your place to be but not for me they need to make more Store's around there.Then i will be over here all the time :) J/K
author: Michael M.

description: A couple years ago you'd find quite a few vacant store fronts in this area.  Luckily now that the economy is starting to pick up a few more businesses have opened up here.  Japantown is a fun place to hang out at with all there shops with authentic merchandise.  It has a Chinatown feel but without the crowds and messy streets.
author: Jesse C.

description: I was so sad to hear Chicago didn't have a Japantown. I heart Japantown in SF. I love hanging out here. It's not for everyone but if you appreciate Japanese culture, you'd enjoy it here. It's fun to take an afternoon to see what Japantown has to offer. It's just one of the amazing neighborhoods the city has to offer.
author: Elisa C.

description: i felt like i wanted to buy everything here. there were a bunch of little shops and a lot of places to eat. I wish that i didn't just eat dimsum in china town before going here because the food looked good. had some space so grabbed a crepe and it was delish! but this place was smaller than i expected.
author: Darlene G.

description:
Up until yesterday, my only visits to this neighborhood were grocery related. I am constantly in search of pre-packaged Onigiri, which I am told I can find here, and still haven't. 

Anyway, my cousin was visiting from Texas (how many reviews have I mentioned Texas in so far? Anyone counting?) and yesterday was her last day here. We decided, on a whim, to go play in the photo booth in the mall around 8:30 PM. Thankfully, although the stores were closed, the mall doors were still open to restaurant patrons (and photo booth nerds like us) and we wandered the halls until we found them. In case you're wondering, they're downstairs from Sophies Crepes.

I was in Japan in 2003, and walking through this mall and seeing all the restaurants with their window displays and curtained doorways really reminded me of my experience there. Ironically, the mall did not remind me of the malls in Japan, but the little side streets lined with eateries and shops. 

Ok, the photo booth. Let me just say....amazing! Confusing, but amazing. It's not one of the sit on a stool with a blue curtain behind you and get a strip of four shots kind of booths. No. This one lets you take 6 photos, 2 at a time, with little breaks in between. It lets you choose the color balance (our choice was 'beautiful skin'), it's super roomy, there are about 5 backgrounds to choose from, and then, at the end you choose your favorite four and add cutesy hello kitty borders to them, and THEN the machine prints them out in your choice of print styles and it prints them in such a way that everyone in the picture can get copies of all the shots. WOW!!! The only thing is, the instructions are spoken by the machine in Japanese...so it can be a bit stressful at times.
author: Vanessa R.

description: Um....maybe I went on a wrong night or something, but I remember coming up to the city with my mom back in the 1990s to visit her old neighborhood and going to japantown bookstore and the other shops there. Granted, the bookstore is still awesome, and that little toy shop. But what happened to the cleanliness of this place, it was dark, humid, and the floors gleamed a dark brownish grime color. Not exactly the nicest environment to take a stroll through. Maybe hire a new superintendent? Lol. Still fun though, I probably wouldn't have noticed if I had one or two more beers.
author: Jeremy B.

description:
Aesthetically, the place is not especially Japanese, but there's a good variety of shops in the area that offer a melange of Japanese things (toys, lamps, furniture, lawn ornaments, books, music, et cetera).  Some good Japanese food to be had here, though not the best by too many standards.  It's a passable ethnic neighborhood that sadly has shrinking tourist appeal and is slowly closing down.

On the plus side, it's far superior to the festering hole that is Amerika-mura (America village) in Osaka.
author: Mike O.

description:
Every time I get a chance to sneak into the Kinokuniya bookstore I do.
I love the Japanese fashion magazines and Manga. The second place I head for is the Insence store.  They offer a great selection of beautiful Japanese incense. None of that hippy crap - just pure subtle lovely scent for your home. Third is noodles - Big hot steaming bowls of Udon or ramen at Suzu. Yeey Japantown.
author: JJ C.

description: hmmm...Still a good place to window shop. Lots of knick knacks and interesting items. I'm a bit sad to see that Japantown is looking a little run down....time for a facelift!
author: Chummy S.

description: We took the VERY crowded bus from Union Square on a Sunday morning.  We didn't make it past the restaurant mall and the little "dollar-store."  It's a relaxing retreat from the hustle and bustle of Chinatown.  We're definitely coming back again to finish the rest of the town.
author: Jessamine A.

description:
One of my favorite landmarks to visit in the Bay.  Japantown, ah, where else can you get car fresheners, scarf down some nigiri and crepes, and check out the music store to listen to your favorite Asian pop stars?  

I've been coming to this place for a while now, and it never gets old when I'm there (probably because it's not that often I do).  Auto Freak is always a must stop for me.  I also like visiting the Kinokuniya Stationery & Gift store and the Kinokuniya Bookstore.  Sophie's Crepes is also a good spot to visit to fulfill your sweet tooth's cravings.

I usually hit up the Mifune restaurant.  I've always liked the food from here!  I've also been visiting J-Town around Christmas-time during the past couple years, because they have plenty of stuff you can buy as gifts.  

oh, and how can I forget the Nijiya Market?  Snacks galore!!!
author: Marc B.

description:
Without the bowling alley originally at the corner of Webster, I believe Jtown has lost a lot of its charm and humbleness. The original Peace Plaza, where the Peace Tower is standing originally had a patio like atmosphere with running watter down the sides of the building. 

Fast forward to present day.. its kinda well boring! :( Sorry to bash it, but the Peace Plaza looks nothing more than an open area for people to smoke their cigs and teenagers to gather. 

The Japanese bookstore that is Kunikunya is the best for manga, and I'm thrilled that they offer English adaption of Manga as well ;) 

Everything else is well still the same. More little small botiques that  most of Chinatown.. well it was a good place.

I still love Mufune-don on the hotel side of the mall for food. Overall, a semi-good place to go still to kickit!
author: Wilson L.

description:
It's so tiny. That is an instant 2 stars.

But there is some great curry, grocery, and crepes to be had.
author: Ashley B.

description: This place needs a redo.  I lived in this area for 4 years.  There is nothing exciting about it.  The only place that makes this place cool exciting is Playground.  You have to be drunk to appreciate Japantown for being so dead.  The best place to eat here went out of business.  I miss Hanu.  Idiots.  The sushi in this town sucks.  Its sad.
author: Fatty A.

description: Fun outing for the family! Be sure to hit the Dollar store, eat some sushi, and grab soame food at the Japanese market to make your own Udon noodle soup at home.
author: John G.

description:
I LOVE J-town! 

It has a variety of fun stores, restaurants and a beautiful plaza where you can hang out and people watch. They have street fairs and you can pick up awesome dishes/bowls. Everything is cute and there's something for everyone. 

SAKE!
SUSHI BOAT RESTAURANT! 
BOOKSTORES!
CREPES!
ORIGAMI STORE!
SHISHIDO!
ICHIBAN KAN!
THE STORE WITH ALL THE COOL LATERNS AND SAKE SETS! 
the list goes on....
author: Gladys C.

description:
There are great stores in Japantown that have things I can't get anywhere else, like certain DVDs or model building kits. I know that is nerdy, but sometimes you just need a fix, aight?
Anyway, there is always something to eat and something to see here, so it's a great way to spend a couple hours.
When there is not a major event, parking is a breeze in the garage.
author: sibani b.

description: I love anything Japanese so of course I love Japantown! Cute desserts, cute Japanese items, characters, and just so much to see. Enough said. :D
author: CJ J.

description:
I've always enjoyed going to Japantown. It's true that the common spaces of the mall could do with some sprucing up, but I don't think there's any other place in the city where you can find this combination of shops and restaurants (if there is, please let me know!).

My favorites are Mifune (certainly not a high end restaurant, but good soup) and the sashimi restaurant whose name escapes me (not Isobune). Andersen's bakery is also a good spot. The other real gem of the store is the Kinokuniya/Maido stationery store -- an amazing collection of pens and little desktop tools, including some very hard-to-find ballpoint pens like the 0.18mm Signo bit.

UPDATE: I love Soko Hardware, too. It's on the corner of Post and Buchanan near the Peace Plaza
author: Pat T.

description:
It's nice to know this place is here if I ever need a kimono or Ikebana training. It'd be a great place to take out-of-town guests. It's pretty everytime I go, even today when it was raining.

 I like the grocery store for tasty snacks, like Pocky in every flavor.
author: Rachel B.

description:
Okay, maybe someone has to show me around "J-Town" and point out the good spots, because I've tried to find a reason to come here other than a couple good sushi restaurants and my favorite store to get Sanrio goodies...

But other than that, I haven't found much Japanese "culture" in Japantown. Driving or walking through it, I never feel like I'm in a part of the city comprised of Japanese characteristics. It seems like Japantown is defined only by a mall consisting of sushi restaurants and places to feed your anime appetite, but as for a true neighborhood, like Chinatown for China or North Beach for Italy? Japantown really doesn't measure up.

But with all of these rave reviews, I get the feeling I've missed something...
author: Sophie D.

description:
Are you an anime-nut and only recently just loved anything Japan?

yeah, J-Town already has quite a bit of that..

Japantown has my appeal for making me feel somewhat like I'm back in Japan..
Somewhat..

Japan culture can still be found here, with quite a bit of events held here, and the little shops around..
Unique shops, restaurants, karaoke bars (i should just stop there: karaoke is huge in japan)..

And for you Japan-culture nuts, there's CDs of J-Pop, DVD's, models, toys, collectibles, games, etc..

Despite it not being as it has been before, it still holds a place in my heart for emulating a Japanese experience..
author: Nicolo T.

description:
Well, it's one of the destinations in the city, that you want to visit out of the curiousity, but even if you don't - you wont miss much.

Pretty average stores, that look like other stores in the same area. 

Pretty cool for just walking and browsing for some gifts or nick nacks.
author: Cat of a Donut J.

description:
Oh how i ADORE Japan Town. My boyfriend and i go every few weeks (and have done so for 6-8 months now) and we are constantly finding something new. We are "starving students" so anything we do for fun has to be pretty cheap. Japan Town is perfect because you get a lot of "bang for your buck," as they say.

5 Favorite Places:
Sushi Boom - Filmore St, Always fresh and delicious. They have a lot of vegan sushi options. This is our go-to restaurant!
Soko Hardware - Across from the Peace Pagoda, lots of cooking/kitchen supplies like rice cookers, chopsticks, pottery and knives
Daiso - Not your traditional "dollar store" because its all Japanese Stuff! Bento boxes and accessories galore, candy, belts, socks, sponges, ALL JAPANESE and ALL CHEAP!
Kinokuniya Book/Manga Store - My boyfriend and i could spend hours looking through the epic amounts of books in this relatively small bookstore. Half of it is in Japanese characters and downstairs is a huge selection of manga (also, half in Japanese characters).
The Bonsai Store (Don't know real name) - On Post st in the mall. My boyfriend got his first Juniper bonsai here. They are super nice and have lots of supplies for bonsai and zen gardens. I mostly include it for sentimental reasons.

If you are looking to party hard, maybe stay clear of Japan Town. If you want a fun day trip, bring a camera to take pictures with the Peace Pagoda, some change for dinner and a few (cheap) souvenirs, and an open mind to learn what you can about Japanese culture in San Francisco.
author: Bridget D.

description: Loved the variety and the Japanese decor everywhere.  There is something for everyone here, food lovers, trendy people (check out New People), kids (lots of toy stores), young adults who like to drink, and people who just like Japanese culture.  My favorite thing here was probably all the choices in restaurants, it makes a food lover very happy. It's just too bad Japantown wasn't bigger.
author: Jackie C.

description: I heart Japan town!!  You can get a meal at Mifune, catch a movie at the Kabuki, and then an after movie crepe at Sophie's.
author: Manny F.

description: a very cool place to explore Japanese culture...the place is dull its not as great as chinatown
author: Derick A.

description: WOW! I went to the festival(cherry blossom) and really had A good time and re-discovered yet another beautiful part of Sanfrancisco.  All the girls where freindly . I had A lot of SOCKET TO ME(saki)some beer and i bought some cats that they let out of some bag....
author: OSEPH E.

description: Japantown ain't like Chinatown, that's for sure!  The town itself is in-doors and very clean.  Expensive stores and restaurants.  They also have cherry blossom trees which is very beautiful.  Overall, a nice place to visit, eat and watch a movie at the Kabuki Theater.
author: Chris R.

description: Japantown is no longer all Japanese restaurants and shops .. there's some Korean restaurants and shops . Japantown is not big .. it's only a few blocks but I like it . It has some good restaurants , supermarkets , and a great bookstore . Japantown is the only place in SF where you can take cute sticky pics . There's a Benihana and 3 shabu shabu restaurants which is awesome :) I think the most interesting store in Japantown and in all of SF is Ichiban Kan because they sell a good cheap interesting wide variety of import goods and snacks ... so if you are a tourist visiting SF , make sure you go check out that store . Only thing is that I think they should build more stuff in the other mall because it's kind of deserted and I feel like the space is going to waste ..
author: Eileen L.

description: I can only hope that Osaka's replica of an American town is more appealing and realistic than this unattractive tribute to our sister city and the country in which it's located. Did Japantown ever have a heydey? Since I first visited it in 1971, I have found it to be bland and coldly unwelcoming. On the few occasions I've been there, the main complex that houses the majority of shops and restaurants was so empty I could hear my footsteps echo in the halls. Some Disney-like touches might not make it more authentic, but at least they might add some charm to a place that feels soulless. As a tourist attraction, it's boring, and as a neighborhood, it's the least interesting in a city where most of them are vibrant and colorful.
author: Gourmet G.

description: My family recently visited the Bay Area during the holiday season and I suggested visiting Japantown (over Chinatown).  I had been to Japantown a few times in the early 90's and remembered it to be vibrant with lots of cool things to do.  This time around, I was quite disappointed and a bit shocked at how much the place had gone downhill.  Perhaps it was the time of year, or the day of the week that we chose to visit? We went there on 12/29/2011, which is a Thursday. There were people in the stores/restaurants, but there was not much else going on. If you're looking for specific Japanese items or a place to eat at (and are not particular about the quality of food), then this is the location for you to visit.  The peace pagoda even looked sad and gray, and the area around it did not seem well-maintained.  The malls need to be updated, and there should be a wider variety of offerings.  I really felt like we wasted time and money (the restaurant said there's no parking validation -- why is this  inconsistent?).  Maybe when the Cherry Blossom festival is in full swing, the place comes more alive, but based on my experience, I would recommend the casual tourist to skip this part of San Francisco, unless they really dig Japanese items.
author: Via C.

description: It's unfair to compare this 'hood to anything in Japan because it is a product of the Japanese-Americans who live and work here. Like the Cherry Blossom Festival - this place is an immigrant's remembrance of an idealized life in a world left behind for a strange and sometimes uncaring land. It's a great place to take European tourists or friends visiting from the midwest, especially if this is as close to Japan as they're likely to get...
author: Quartknee K.

description: This is one of three Japantowns left in the US; the other two being in LA and San Jose.  This one is wonderful with the Japantown Center, Contetsu Mall, and Myako Mall; as well as the surrounding streets chalked full of shops, restaurants, the cultural center, and so forth.  Everything from traditional groceries to clothing to sushi and tempora and everything food can be found here.  Come for the Cherry Blossom Festival and Neomachi Street Fare as there are many food, arts and crafts, and other booths and festivities at both events.  It is a wonderful taste of Japantown in a small part of SF.
author: Brian S.

description:
it seems like they've made an attempt to make this place more lively within the last couple years, but it still seems kind of deserted without too many interesting things to look at.  except for the kinokuniya stores and a couple other shops, everything else just seems kinda 'blah' and boring.... 
even the restaurants aren't worth the trip to come here...
i wish there were more interesting and fun shops throughout the 'mall'
too many of the stores seem the same... just a mix of hello kitty stuff, music/dvds, and car accessories and older people's things...
maybe there could be a bigger stationery store, a japanese cosmetics shop, a younger people's clothes shop, electronics, some better restaurants....
there's potential to the place but i don't know if anyone's doing anything about it
author: charlotte s.

description: J-town is great for cute lil finds, good eats to stationary to festivals. Cherry blossom festival and Nihonmachi Street Fair are always a fun time!
author: Yan M.

description: I see alot of 1 stars on here, or very low ratings but i love this place.  I haven't been there for about 14 years or so.  I couldn't even remember what it looked like then.  I just remembered back then there was not much to look at, but when i went there yesterday, it's completely different.  There's alot of small gift shops.  I LOVE these cute gift shops.  If you love Sanrio and all those japanese animation stuff you'll love this place!  I'm gonna have to take my sister soon.
author: Annimated L.

description: I like Japantown a lot. I like it because it is cleaner than most of the "towns" in San Francisco. I like it because theres plenty food and cute little shops here. I like it because theres usually a good amount of people here. I like it because it puts me in an extra good mood when its sunny. Even more if there is a fair going on.
author: Elaine H.

description: This place really is a cultural hub for the Japanese in SF. The Chinese have Chinatown and, to a lesser extent, Clement Street, but Japantown's where it's at for the Japanese. I've been coming here my entire life, and I never run out of restaurants to try, or shops to peruse. Parking can be pretty difficult, but it's worth it to use the big lot next to the hotel. Most restaurants will validate. The Cherry Blossom Festival, which is held here annually, is a must-see.
author: Krista F.

description:
I LOVE Japantown! It is the 'essence' of Japan... When you are unable to be in the real place, there is a transplanted representation here, that captures only a small whiff of it's true self.  I say that because it has so many people from Japan , speaking the language, selling goods that we have never seen before, written in Japanese, transports me in my mind to that field of rice, that tea garden, OH STOP ME... I want to go so BAD! 
Make sure you don't overlook the little store that sells the antique woodblock prints, KILLER! The other, there is a large antique furniture store. DO not miss it! it has all sorts of cool stuff that can be integrated into any decor you nay have at home- modern or rustic! (not just furniture) Their grocery store has amazing things in it, you just have to take my word and check it out!  The other  Not to miss is the Hardware store across the street. I can't say enough good about it here, so it will get separate treatment!  Some of the Places to eat are the BOMB! Do NOT get lured into the usual everyday ones we Americans think Japanese food is... Go downstairs and try the little place in the corner...
I had a dish called modern yaki OH GOLLY GIMME MORE!
author: Jan C.

description: Cool Japanese shops, a Korean bar, expensive as hell anime and a Denny's that will make you wish you had never been born. What more can I ask for?
author: James J.

description:
i lived in this neighborhood ALLLLLL my life
and i LOVE it here
..
ok.. so i lived in outer sunset for a brief 3 month period... but it just made me appreciate and love jtown alllll the more..

i love how you can walk outside and find just about anything..
well.. anything i would want.. :D
haaaaaaaaaaaa~

the only downside..
it's pretty expensive..
and there are always a BUNCH of WAPS walking around..
stupid stupid wannabes..
author: monica c.

description: I don't know how you can live in San Francisco and not visit this place at least once a month. There are so many restaurants and stores to explore its just fascinating to me...
author: Nicolas H.

description: My father-in-law, who is Japanese and grew up in Japan, and my mother-in-law, who lived in Japan for about 30 years, now live in Georgia but, every time they visit their grandchildren in San Francisco they have to visit Japantown at least 3 times in a week. My father-in-law wants to buy a condo and retire there. My mother-in-law can't stop talking about this place. So of course on my first visit to San Francisco I could not possibly go without visiting Japantown. I was a little skeptical but, as soon as I stepped out of the car I smelled home. We eat a lot of traditiona Japanese food at home and it was such a wonderful, comforting smell. Everything in this place is authentic. It really is a wonderful place to visit if you are interested in Japanese food or culture. It was convenient for us too because we were able to pick up some zarusoba and sembe for my children, who are very picky eaters but, love Japanese food.
author: Ellie S.

description: I've been here a couple times while cruising thru SF and both times Japantown reminded me of  semi-deserted ghost town where old Western shooting duels take place...except Asian.  The shopkeepers are around, but where are all the people?  Japantown has some perks, including a great Japanese bookstore (Kinokuniya), inexpensive but decent eats (ex: Mifune), and Ichiban Kan, land of cheapie cutsey home goods and things you never knew you needed -- but for the most part it's a isolated little strip that's really meant for tourists who'd be better off getting a taste of real "Asian" style by heading to SF's thriving Chinatown instead.
author: Andrea L.

description: Its about time i visited Japantown, Ive always wanted to come but always get lost!!  I wanted to find hello kitty stuff, thats about it!!  We went to the mall and had a blast..so many new things and cute stores to browse.. I LOVE IT!
author: La La T.

description: Oh, I love this place. All the Japanese restaurants, crepes, stationery, markets, etc make my day. I love the Tuna crepes. OMG, I'm craving for crepes just thinking about it! It's a fun place to go on a weekend. Sometime people even dress up as their favorite Characters!
author: Joe C.

description: I love it here, one of the places where me and my girl can sit, walk, talk, hang out, eat, relax......you get the point.  Kinokuniya has all the mags from Japan except for my favorite one so that sucks but still, japantown is one of my favorite places to hang out.  Ichibankan is also the cheapest place to get my favorite brand of ramen, only 45cents per pack.  Aloha warehouse is also close by to remind me of home and benkyodo, the manju is to die for.  Japantown will always be my place to hang out.
author: Art W.

description: I love how the street signs have secondary signs in Japanese.  I stayed in the area for a long weekend and I loved walking across the street to get wagashi (wish they had more than two flavors a day).  I wish the crepe place was open.  If I had had shabu shabu in addition to conveyor belt sushi, I may have hit my Japanese food trifecta.  The bus stop is also convenient.
author: Ai M.

description: Clean and quiet.  It's like a piece of Japan transported to the States.  I live nearby so I always end up here for food, shopping or walking when it's raining out.  Kabuki theatre, Kabuki spa, Cherry Blossom Festival and many more things await.  Don't forget Japanese food.
author: Corey V.

description: THis is cool place to go to!  My wife and I stopped by here yesterday to pick up some lunch on our way to the beach.  Lots of shops and places to eat!
author: Jay A.

description: I'll happily give the full five stars once management in the mall bothers to renovate the filthy bathrooms. I love you Japantown but your restrooms are worse than that famous one in Scotland.
author: Master Squirrel S.

description: Japantown I love you so much for your stores, service, food, events and sometimes the cute men walking around :D Even though I have gone to school in SJ Japantown for 6 years, I prefer the SF location because it's 5 million times bigger.
author: Jessica T.

description:
My friends of mine told me that it really shows Japan - well and none of them is from Japan.  For me, it doesn't look like Japan at all.  All imitations. 

But I was again very surprised that this opinion came from people from all over the world - it didn't matter how close they were to Japan originally.  

But I like this place a lot and I go there a lot to get some Japanese grocery done.  I may get bored of it one day though.
author: T T.

description: Spent a great Sunday with friends hanging at the cherry Blossom Festival. Always a good time.
author: David R.

description: Japantown to me is as every bit as good as its always been as the other people have written here, and its still my homebase no matter what. But recently the security detail has been lets say more overzealous in there duties there. Not to say we don't need security there, but the security company in Japantown has recently hired some young thugs that patrol the center like the Nazi youth. One of these little punks by the name of  Alan actually harassed me for carrying (yes, carrying.) my dog into the center, and I was only going to the garage. Another one of these youngsters patrols the garage  like a regular policeman even though he obviously isn't, and I've witnessed him harassing regular people in the garage who he thinks might be lingering too long. I can give more examples, but its one of the small changes in Japantown that I've seen that I don't like. If one of these brown uniformed punks  messes with me with their gestapo tactics again, I'll definitely take them to the courthouse. Patrons beware when you deal with these guys.
author: Andrew D.

description: This "mall" (aging shopping complex that reminds you of the 80's seems more applicable) contains the Kinokuniya Bookstore to browse through magazines I can't understand (gotta love the pictures though, Japanese mags are so much more visually striking than the junk we read while waiting in line at the supermarket), Nijiya Market to grab fresh and cheap sushi, Tanpopo for the best ramen in the 7X7, and the Kabuki to catch sneak previews of films in a crappy theater. What's not to love? This place is also being sold and the aforementioned Kabuki is closing down, so enjoy this welcome distraction from everyday life while you can.
author: Ramon T.

description: I LOVE IT!  From Kabuki to the memories of having gone there in 2nd grade for a field trip.  I have little to say, but I dig it so much.  Fantastic community.
author: Uncle Fishbits Aeneas X.

description: Japantown is awesome. I stayed at the Kabuki hotel and got their suites with the deep Japanese tub bath, went to a Karaoke place and sang a few hours, saw a movie at the Sundance Theatre, got a nice japanese sushi dinner, and did alot of store browsing and did some picture taking. Mind you this took a good day to enjoy. It's a great place to hang, have fun, and relax
author: Charlene C.

description: I love this place! Lots of places to walk around. Small shops and places to eat at. Lots of places for Japanese culture as well as Japanese goods and festivals :]
author: Olivia K.

description: I love all the stores there! I haven't been there in a while but I will probably drop by this weekend for the cherry blossom festival.
author: Bianca B.

description:
sophie's crepes.
ichiban kan.
benihana [hate to admit].
and a bunch of other cute japanese boutiques!

sooo cute!
author: Rosalee C.

description: Japantown is an awesome if small neighberhood in the western addition with many awesome japanese shops and the kabuki cinema as well...also I love the convenience of the safeway here...this little piece of Geary is awesome..
author: Francis K.

description: Love love love this place!  I wish it was as big and booming as China Town, but I will take what I can get.  I love that there is a parking garage with cheap parking and an awesome mall.  I love you Japantown!
author: Jenna M.

description: Shops and goods from Japan.  Very nice atmosphere for young and old.  We had breakfast there and enjoyed hours looking in stores.
author: Corinne d.

description:
pros...this is the place to get your fix of all things japanese.  most of the shops are just cool and very unique in what they have to sell.  i mean where else can you just live off of wind chimes, and koh (fine japanese incense)?  and how cool is having a store or restaurant on a bridge?  they have almost everything in about 4 blocks...bookstore, food, specialty stores, anime, car freaks, hello kitty, snack shops, etc.  everytime i'm in san francisco i always make it a point to visit here. 

cons...well you have to be really lucky to get some street parking, but you still have to pay!  you can usually find some pretty good parking in the underground garage, and yes, you still have to pay.  but the prices here are pretty inexpensive for this city.  the other part is that there are a lot of non-japanese shops around the area, (read korean and chinese), but these cultures are in japan, so are they really out of place? just making a remark.  and there is the odd denny's across from soko hardware too.
author: Joel G.

description: I have never spent to much time in Japantown until this past weekend.  The weather was amazing so we grabbed some small japanese snacks and enjoyed the weather at the Peace Plaza.  I really enjoyed it =)  The Peace Plaza does not offer much but it's a nice place to take a break, eat your snack, and people watch.
author: Christine S.

description: I love Japantown in San Francisco. It is much bigger and has more shops than the one in San Jose for obvious reason. It reminds me of Little Tokyo in Los Angeles, but I think this is much better 'cause it seems more modern. Lots of Japanese restaurants and other types of restaurants, and it seems that the prices are not too pricey. They are typical of most Japanese restaurants I have been to. I did not go to one, but definitely if I were going out on a date, this would be on top of my list. And the shops, they definitely make you feel like you are in Japan. And definitely the experience won't be complete without going to place called New People. Check out my review about it. So since I am more than a fan, I will definitely give this a five star rating. I will definitely come here a lot whenever I get a chance. Yes, some place are pretty pricey, but I am sure you go to Japan, it is probably pricier (in addition, you gotta pay for a plane ticket plus your hotel). :)
author: Christopher R.

description:
very hard not to like this area.  pretty decent job in creating a japanese atmosphere and providing a variety of shops that offer different japanese products.

the outer lying streets have many korean establishments, which isn't a bad thing, but if you're in JAPANtown, you'd probably want more japanese eateries.

haven't been to an event here yet, but looking forward to it, since several people have mentioned how fun they are.
author: Bryce K.

description: it's pretty neat to check out, especially if you're into japanese stuff. there's stuff here that may be hard to find elsewhere.
author: Raj R.

description: My mom recalls being dragged here many times throughout her youth.  As a Hapa girl, her Japanese mom would be excited every  time, and yet every time they would leave disappointed.  The entire place is just sort of sad, and as my mom says, it's been like that since the beginning of time.
author: Emma H.

description: One of my fav places in SF.  I always bring my friends from out of town here and it never dissapoints.  Awesome bookstore, cool photo booths, and excellent food choices.
author: Maurice N.

description: woohoo, i love j-town! was just here last week with my roommate and a friend and we had a blast here. we started out having ramen noodles at tampopo ramen. (my noodles were very bland but i'm not a fan of noodle soups anyway so dont take my word for it) the plum wine however was excellent, i could've drank it by the gallon. mmm. afterwards we ventured across the street into the "restaurant mall". cool, a gazillion japanese restaurants all packed into 1 long buiding! along the way there are japanese stores with books, candy and other imported items. we cruised down to the end and decided to have crepes because i didnt eat my bland noodles and was still hungry. (can't remember name, sorry) immediatly we all errupted into a fit of giggles. it was the funniest thing! there are about 6 or 7 japanese photo booths.(if you see them you'll know why its so funny) we chose one and started posing for pictures with weird backgrounds. afterwards we realized the instructions were all in japanese so it took forever to understand how to get our pics out.... but somehow we managed. before we left, i tried to steer everyone into that great little karaoke bar for some singing, but i was overruled. damn. next time i sing! next time for sure.
author: Michelle I.

description: i love this place! it's culturally rich but not very catered to tourists. it's like oakland's chinatown, it's for the people, not tourists. It's a nice place to go and i always go back to just hang out.
author: Amy T.

description: it's beautiful and cleanning place.I'm looking for a New Japanese'CD-then I found-but too expensive.
